title: Overpriced and tired.
text: From the outside this hotel looks majestic, inside though, is another story,  it is old, tired, worn and dirty with the worst lifts ever and if you're lucky on your 10th swipe of your key card it might move. For the price of this hotel, you'd expect more than a dusty room, a bathroom with grotty grouting, at the very least you'd expect to get slippers and a robe..nope. The rug in my room was tatty and threadbare, there were holes in my mismatched bed sheets!! Not even a welcome bottle of tap water, no glasses, mugs, coffee/tea, they at least brought up a kettle when I asked though. The fact that I had to go the store to buy everything to make my stay more comfortable was so disappointing. Sadly, the only positive was the location.

title: Very disappointing
text: I've stayed here several times, back when it was called The Desmond Tutu to last week. It's sad to watch a property run down - elements that could be charming become repulsive. There are too many factors for the one star rating to list - here are just a few: dirty bathroom floor; one bath towel each, no hand towel, wash cloth or bath mat; dirty yellowed white gauzy curtains; the door to the room can only be closed by slamming it ; broken furniture; mismatched bed sheets; nonsensical room pricing (smaller rooms cost more); $4.50 coffee; no lobby or reception desk. It feels like no one is in charge.

title: Coffee and a washcloth, please!
text: My daughter and I were very comfortable at this hotel during a weekend visit to NYC. However, it was a surprise to find that the hotel "lobby" is primarily occupied by a third-party commercial coffee/cocktail bar and its neighborhood customers, with no complimentary coffee or drinks offered to the hotel guests. At least a complimentary morning cup of coffee with one's hotel key or a voucher, and possibly even an afternoon/evening glass of wine, would have made the whole arrangement less off-putting for hotel guests. Barring that, put coffee-making facilities in the guest rooms (there were none). Also, I have come to expect, especially at a 4-star hotel, a washcloth along with a bath towel and a hand towel for each guest, but in our room there were no wash cloths and only one hand towel for two people. Otherwise we very much enjoyed our stay at this hotel.

title: Dirty and Overpriced
text: I was astonished at how different this hotel was from the way it’s advertised. This is not a 4-star hotel. Our bathroom had drop ceiling tiles with water stains on them and thick dust around the edges along the wall. The bathroom floor was visibly grubby. The bathroom light fixture was the cheapest kind you’d buy somewhere like Home Depot. The towels were scratchy and cheap feeling. The lampshades in the room were both stained—gross. One of the lamps didn’t even turn on. There was a visible tear in the duvet cover. We had requested a room not near the elevator when we made our reservation via the hotel’s own website but our room was (you guessed it) right by the elevator. Oh! I almost forgot: you cannot adjust the temperature in your room—we had a window a/c unit that barely worked and a wall thermostat that didn’t respond to our attempts to modify the temperature. Plus, the windows paired with the window a/c unit let any traffic sound right into your room. The entire experience was so very disappointing, but since we were only staying for one night, we decided to just go through with our visit. In the end, we paid about $526 for the room rate plus taxes and fees for a room that felt like something at a sleazy motel. Honestly, we burst out laughing after we checked out and got outside. I’ll never stay here again.

title: Charm, history, and warmth in the heart of Chelsea
text: Charming and warm. A treasure in Chelsea area of NYC. Steps to the fabled High Line, and walking distance to many NYC highlights. The rooms were historical and oozing with antique touches. We had two queen beds, a large wardrobe, a desk area and a window seat. Staff was super friendly and accommodating. We arrived a little early and our room was already ready. Can't wait to come back.

title: Nice room but tub drain didn't work
text: Room was comfortable and pretty, but the bathtub drain didn't work. The reception agent was gracious and said it would be fixed while I was out at dinner, but it was not.  Then the repairman arrived ~9pm and woke me up to fix it.  Unfortunately he didn't listen carefully to the two issues, said he had fixed one but didn't actually test it, and in the morning I found that, in fact, he hadn't fixed either problem. Gave up at that point.

title: Such a disappointing experience
text:
I’ve never actually written a negative review for a hotel since I’ve had really great experiences for the most part but this place really rubbed me the wrong way. I was in NYC for the holidays and obviously understand things are a bit more expensive but for over $800 a night this was nowhere near close to worth that amount when I would’ve gotten better service/basic amenities at a Marriott Courtyard or whatever equivalent.

To start with, whenI was outside looking at where the entrance was to check in, the bellman looked like work was the last place on earth he wanted to be and  just looked at me and pointed to the front door when I had a 50 lb suitcase and two other bags that I had to take down the stairs and through two doors myself. For what they and calling yourself a luxury hotel, that is unacceptable already soured my stay before I even walked in. The “lobby” if that’s what you want to call it is basically a coffee shop with someone assisting with check-in. Not my thing personally but if that’s what you’re looking for by all means go for it. When I was inside, the staff was friendly and helpful with my check in.

Our guest room was clean but again for the price and it being a “four star” hotel, I was pretty disappointed. Two of the outlets in the room next to one of the beds didn’t work, the TV remote was not synced up to the tv so it was very difficult to change channels and the cable wasn’t working so the screen was constantly flickering. The bathroom having just 2 towels and a small wash cloth for 2 people staying there wasn’t enough. Again at other places I’ve stayed with similar ratings, there are extra towels, a towel for the wet bathroom floor by the shower (I came close to falling when I got out of the shower), bath robes. I understand it is an older building which is part of the charm but it felt extremely minimalist and not up to the level of a luxury hotel.

The hotel is in a great location but for what they charge it isn’t close to worth it and there are so many better options.

title: very average
text: average hotel  - looks cool from the outside and the ambience in the common areas is good. The rooms are 'vintage' style but are in desperate need of remodeling. AC unit super loud, missing tiles, not enough lighting. Staff at the coffee bar was not particularly pleasant. It was not worth the money and I would not stay there again .

title: Super Charming Hotel right across street from High Line Park Walk
text:
The Highline Hotel is very charming from the outside-just the right combo of outdoor lights and a red hippy van outside called Cheeky. :) Amazing coffee, chai and pastries served to tourists and neighbors, which turns into a bar at 5:00 or so. Very friendly and professional staff. 
And the mattresses there really are awesome! The hotel recently won recognition for having the best mattresses. They are made by Wright Bedding in the US. They even have a QR code in your room with $300 off if you want to get a Wright Bedding mattress for yourself!
Hotel also conveniently located one block from Cook, a farm to table restaurant and Empire and awesome diner.
AND VERY CONVENIENT TO WALK ACROSS THE STREET TO THE HIGH Line PARK. WHAT A GREAT USE OF URBAN SPACE!!

title: Had hoped for more
text: While the Chelsea architecture and small neighborhood feel were appealing, the overall hotel experience was disappointing.  Rooms were small and have very few amenities, poor lighting, and not particularly clean.  It seems like the hotel has potential as a historic building but little was done to renovate and modernize for it's guests- dim lighting, musty smells and thin walls.  When I requested water at check in, I was told I could walk to a CVS.  I ended up leaving after one evening and found a hotel, with amenities and much better customer service.  Overall, I was disappointed with the level of care, cleanliness and overall customer experience.  Would not recommend, especially if looking for a reliable, consistent hotel for a business trip.

title: Do not stay here
text:
Communication was awful. Advice given was awful. Room cleaning was substandard. Price unreasonable for the tiny room.
Everything is extra. You have to pay for a morning cup of coffee.
I asked for advice on getting to the airport. They have bad advice and then Gabe no help in arranging transportation
Do not stay at this hotel!

title: Good location a bit overpriced
text:
If you have a high standard, then you might look for another hotel. But location is great near the high line and hudson. 

The beds are amazing for good recovery after a long day. Unfortunately the area is pretty loud during the week and the windows are old. 

Coffeeplace nice to have, but unfriendly staff.

title: Disappointment
text: Don’t stay at this hotel unless you want to experience a room that seemed to be furnished with thrift store finds and tattered and threadbare carpets.  Room and bathroom was dimly lit, headboard which was rattan seemed to be dirty and stained.  Curtains were in need of being cleaned or replaced, no washcloths, paper or pencil/pen to write a note and all woodwork needed to be painted.  Very very expensive for what the room quality that we received.  Overall, very disappointed with the hotel.

title: high line NYC
text:
perfect out of the way hotel.   But also near shopping and some good resturants.
Clean, and quite.   Staff is super helpful 

jwekjhfwfjenggkrkmgl  lkjflkewlfklewkflk  fkjklfjlekmglemlgmelgreqg,lg,erl,ger,g/,er/,/re,/er,/,

title: Do not stay in the first floor
text: Rooms in the first floor have absolutely no sound proofing, meaning you get to enjoy the cafe music throughout the night. This means firing off the coffee grinder at 6am (a good wakeup call!) and the trumpet riff / jazz soundtrack coming from the cafe endlessly. I literally was unable too sleep.

title: STOP!  Don’t book here.
text:
Be warned and please read the most current reviews.  Also, beware when you book, mine said it was refundable up until a certain point and it wasn’t.  

The only good thing about this hotel is the restaurant on the next block, Cookshop.  We were in NYC for 4 days/nights and ate there at least once a day.  

Now for the bad.  This place doesn’t have a bottle of water ANYWHERE!  Even to purchase.  The CVS a block away is the place they send you for anything you need including umbrellas to borrow in the pouring rain.   The pillows are hard as a rock with no fluff at all to them.  I actually took the case off to see what in the heck was in there.  The rooms are just old and dated.  Scratched up old furniture.  Not charming.  

One of the staff, Christian,in mixed company (not that that matters), discussed sex and rape with another male guest as offensively as I’ve ever heard.  I’m still upset with myself for not speaking up.  

And disparaged people still wearing a mask as “still wearing a rag on their face”.  

He encouraged us to call out Mr. Morris by name in our reviews.  He feels bullet proof to any consequences, I think because of their union.  

I will say that the room cleaning staff did a great job each day while we were out and there was another more timid lobby staff that was kind.

title: Overpriced with no services at all
text:
This is a run down, dated hotel with no facilities. At the room rate   I paid per might you’d at least expect a bottle of water. Alas nothing. There is a coffee bar in the lobby which is used by locals so have to queue with them to get a coffee, no priority and lack lustre service. 

The room I had smelled of stale cigarettes and had torn curtains that let in lots of light. The one saving grace is that it wasn’t on the street. The air con unit however was noisy and despite me turning it off made large grinding noises at regular intervals through the night. 

The night porter was less than friendly- being greeted by him eating fried chicken playing his phone out loud upon arrival was the icing on the cake on an overall poor, overpriced hotel.

title: Beware - no facilities at this hotel
text: This hotel is super expensive for what it is.  There are no facilities at all.  No breakfast, no room service, no reception/concierge to speak of, no laundry offering.  You literally get a room which is ‘charming’ if you like a run-down look but nothing else - no in-room coffee making facility and for the rate - over $500 per night they do not even give you a bottle of water - but you have an empty fridge.  It is really extraordinary that they charge so much for so very little.

title: Not bad, dreadful
text: If the Adams family ran a hotel ... No water in the empty fridge in the  room  - when I asked the porter I got the response “ we don’t do that” - in fact no drinking water available at all when i arrived at night . The toiletries in the bathroom not replenished leaving no soap or shampoo . The night porter was watching TV on his phone so loud it prevented me from sleeping   .  The room rate is over a $1000 a night and I have stayed in better youth hostels - avoid

title: Unique Chelsea Property
text: I have really mixed feelings about this unique NYC hotel. On the positive side, it is a beautiful 19th century building on a wonderful street in Chelsea with quick High Line access. It is very dog friendly (if you don't love dogs of all sizes don't stay here..) and the quirky charm oozes from every dusty nook. On the negative  side, the hotel is priced like a luxury property (my bill for four nights was close to $3,500) but the amenities are like a budget hotel. Namely, the sheets are cheap, the beds are way too soft and the bathrooms are mediocre. That said, I like this hotel but I won't stay here again. Insider tip: don't stay in a room which ends in the number 2 (i.e., 22 or 32) as they face 10th  Ave which is exceedingly noisy. The rooms in the back are very quiet and much preferable.

title: Poor customer service and plumbing problems
text: Upon check-in I showered in a bath that did not drain.  When I offered to move before unpacking, I was instead asked to accommodate an engineer (who was professional and apologetic) twice before being told that the drain was hopelessly blocked.  The front desk, Christian, advised that I would not be moved to another room, but that I could use the bathroom across the hall.  Absurd, insulting and unacceptable.  It is a beautiful hotel with a customer service problem.

title: Could be so amazing, but...
text: super cool location and great antique vibe, but my room had water damage in the ceiling and flaking plaster off the walls (and onto my business suit and shoes - not good).  also, my bathtub drained very slowly - asked to fix it and no one showed up.  Old building converted to chic hotel is an uber cool idea, except that it also needs to function in a modern way.  otherwise, the staff is lovely and kind, the building and decor is seriously cool 1890 gothic chic, great lighting and grounds.

title: Very decent 2 night stay
text: Stayed for 2 nights, and while it is a bit of an older building, it was still nice to live and sleep in. The checkin staff was very friendly, place stocked with basic hotel amenities (soap, shampoo, conditioner, towels). House keeping replaced my towel and overall very nice experience.

title: BED BUGS- DO NOT STAY
text:
Beware BED BUGS
I recently stayed at the high line hotel over labor day weekend for a fun trip with my boyfriend. 
The morning we came home we discovered bites all over our legs and arms - it was confirmed by a pest company today that we contracted bed bugs from the high line hotel. 
Since leaving I have been trying to get in touch with staff at the hotel to no avail- have probably called 10+ times. I even emailed the team letting them know of bed bugs in my room given new guests are likely already staying there. 
Overall was a good stay until this was discovered and clearly there has been little care or follow up since it occurred. I would have expected a lot more from this hotel. 
Safe to say I'll never stay here again and would recommend you don't either.

title: Bar Lounge : de qui se moque-t-on ?
text: Nous nous sommes arrêtés au Bar Lounge qui prend place dans une enceinte verdoyante très sympa. Seulement voilà , nous souhaitons prendre un verre et on nous demande de regarder la carte avec le QR code, jusque là pas de soucis mais c’est quand arrive la commande que l’on a une forte impression d’avoir été trompés : la carte indique « bottled beers » et que vous sert on pour 9 usd ? Une pauvre canette en Alu avec un verre plastique …une canette n’est pas une bouteille verre et on attend un peu mieux d’un lieu pareil qu’un verre en plastique…que dire des olives commandées (aussi pour 9 usd) dont la moitié étaient molles et croquées à moitié … bref du grand foutage de gueule !

title: Truly wonderful hotel.
text: I booked a room at the High Line Hotel for my elderly parents, and they (and we) could not have been more delighted. From the unique character of the building and rooms to the friendly staff and the feeling of an inclusive community, not to mention how well pets are treated!, we were utterly charmed and deeply grateful.

title: Boutique Chic
text: Loved this property. Location convenient, lots of restaurants in the area. Great staff, easy check in & check out. Loved the coffee bar and outdoor seating. Room was clean, quiet, and met expectations.

title: very bad smell in the room
text: The first room they assigned me had a very foul smell, it seemed that it had not been cleaned for a long time or that there was something wrong internally, the next day they changed my room and it no longer had that smell but the bed really was very bad, it was sunken and didn't really let rest properly

title: When People Ask When Are You Going Home, I say what are you talking about I am home.
text:
When People Ask When Are You Going Home, I say what are you talking about I am home.
As a native I am very picky. Being at the High Line is like being back in NY when I lived there.
Love the staff and the neighborhood feeling.

title: Great location BUT...
text:
I stayed here with my adult child who was in town on business. The main reason to stay at this hotel is if you have business in the area. While it's quaint and built about 1845 as part of a church, then used as a conference center before it became a hotel.

We found the people at the front "desk" very nice and the outdoor areas lovely. Unfortunately, the rooms are small, there is no counter space in the bathrooms other than the top of the toilet and the room isn't very clean...becasue it's quite old. There are great bath sheets but no washcloths and the tv was not easy to use. 

The closest subway station is two avenues over and three blocks north, so very walkable. You're right next to the High Line, close to Chelsea Market and Pier 57. A few blocks away is Meat Packing and West Village.

Personally, I'd rather stay in a lesser location and be more comfortable.

title: The hotel is old and musty
text: I never post reviews but this hotel was beyond disgusting. It was like staying in a hotel that hadn't been touched in over 100 years - the rooms were musty and I didn't want to even sit on the furniture. The lighting was so dim, it was impossible to put your make up on.

title: ladies overnight trip to NYC
text: Found this location by chance on a google search. So happy we did.  The location was lovely-right on the High Line and blocks from Chelsea Market.  The hotel itself was quirky and fun.  The room was spacious and clean.  Only complaint was the heat in the room however as it was unseasonably warm, the air wasn't turned on yet, so not the fault of the employees.  We truly had a great time and would happily stay here again.

title: HVAC system needs to be modernized
text: This hotel does not have a modern HVAC system as a result they have a heating season and cooling season. Should their be a warm spell during the heating season they have no AC and can only blow warm air into the room. The only solution they can offer is to open a window. The windows do not have screens so bugs fly in the room, plus since it is only a 5 story building you hear all the street noise, which can be quite loud. This makes it hard to sleep as the room is loud and uncomfortably warm. For these reasons I cannot recommend staying here, which is shame as the location is great.

title: Nice from the outside, average on the inside
text: The hotel is conveniently placed and a very nice building from the outside. The terrace is very nice and it has this trendy vibe from the outside. From the inside (I have stayed 4 times in this hotel) it delivers the another experience. Mine went from getting a room above the terrace with very minor sound isolation, to having a room behind the ice machine for the outside bar. More recently the room had very dirty windows. I appreciate the location so I come back BUT for a hotel of this price my feeling is that the place wants to appear trendy BUT the service and amenities are below average.

title: Convenient location but that is about it
text:
I haven’t ever written a negative review before but we did not have a great experience. The plumbing is super loud and the rooms shook when toilets in other rooms were flushed in the night. So don’t plan on any decent sleep. The air con also shakes. When staff weren’t stood bitching about other members of staff and guests they were very friendly to deal with. My room wasn’t very clean and didn’t have any working lamps. The elevators were a terrifying experience and the keys to our rooms stopped working constantly. I also discovered on my second night that the automatic lock on the door doesn’t actually lock the door and it had been unlocked for the entire stay at that point. I then had a new room which was fine but not that clean, especially when I found a previous guest’s dirty socks on the floor at the side of the bed. It was generally massively over priced for what it is, especially when you can’t even get a cup of coffee. There was a barista you could buy crazy expensive coffee from but they were only open after 0800 and they complained about the staff that usually work there throughout trying to get a coffee. 

So all in all I would not recommend it. 

The only good points are that it is super close to the exhibition we were attending, there are great dogs that hang out in the lobby and it is super close to the lovely Empire Diner. None of those things make it worth staying in though really.

title: Good effort but would not stay again
text:
The hotel came highly recommended to us so we looked forward to staying. The best attribute of the hotel is its location in Chelsea. It’s fantastic. The rest was underwhelming. The hotel, in a
Repurposed wing of the Episcopal seminary next door, is certainly shooting for an old New York aesthetic and in some aspects it succeeds. At the same time the experience, even when embracing it with goodwill, is death by a thousand cuts. The hotel is likely more pleasant in warmer months when it’s outdoor space would allow guests to sprawl and take in the lively street scape. In the winter the pinched lobby feel claustrophobic (oddly a gorgeous interior staircase—clearly once part of an entrance—with cast iron balustrades is closed in and unseen; it serves only as an emergency exit. Sad design choice.  Hotel Customer service is lamentably inconsistent, a surprise for a high concept hotel at this price point, and the glacially-paced elevator is almost a character in the hotel’s narrative, so often do waiting guests commiserate together about it. Our third-floor room was bright because of the lovely and enormous window looking out onto 10th Avenue. Heeding previous comments I requested a room on a higher floor on the back of the hotel but none was available. It was a situation I would come to regret. The bed was exceedingly comfortable and the small bathroom adequate (one can only do so much with a repurposed seminary dorm room). The ornamental fireplace added charm. Oddly there was no comfortable chair just a hard chair at the antique desk. The room size was also adequate (it is Manhattan) though it would have been better served by a queen-sized bed rather than a king, which made it feel cramped. The comfort of the bed cauls not compensate for the noise level, which made sleep impossible. As we knew it was likely to be loud we take responsibility; we would never stay at the hotel again simply because of this. The morning coffee bar and it’s evening cocktail companion were nice touches, though the prices seems excessive for in-house services. The stay was fine but there are better options in the neighborhood. Overall, the hotel merits a “meh.”

title: Worth Every Penny
text: This is the most beautiful, homey hotel we've ever stayed in (across four contents and forty years!). The beds were so comfortable our sleep was, for the first time ever, better even than at home. The hotel coffee shop is so warm and inviting you wish you weren't on vacation and could just hang out a bit. Decor, amenities, view, and layout were all brilliant, topped only by the absolutely spectacular service. It couldn't have been a fluke because every single staffer was exemplary. We checked out of a high price point hotel across town because of the opposite experience, choosing to take our chances ANYWHERE else... and thank goodness we did! If not for our stay in Chelsea, at the High Line, our trip would have been if not ruined, then nowhere near as memorable. It ain't cheap, and that's an issue for our family for certain, but in our case we regret not a penny of this stay.

title: Truly a gem
text:
This is probably the nicest hotel I stayed at in NYC.  I love old places with character and the High Line Hotel fit the bill.  The hotel staff went above and beyond. I am definitely booking again in the warmer weather! 
Our room was incredibly spacious, two closets, a huge bathroom with a table to put things down on, a seating area with a fireplace (non working).  Little touches like a desk embosser and old phone just added to the quaintness.  I would wholeheartedly recommend staying here.

title: Stay at another hotel
text:
My wife and I just returned from a 3 night stay at The High Line Hotel with another couple. We have stayed at a dozen or so hotels in NYC over the years and this was the only time I felt ripped off. Over $700 a night for a 3 star hotel, at best! Do not be fooled by the glamorous photos on the website. The other recent negative reviews are spot on.

Pros: friendly staff, comfy bed, great coffee downstairs, convenient to Chelsea Market, and a really cool old building.

Cons: no A/C, tiny room with one nightstand (because there was, literally, 12 inches on my side of the bed), horribly inadequate lighting (one bedside table lamp, one desk lamp, and one BARE ceiling bulb), old, dingy carpets and rugs, paint chipping everywhere. Never in my life have I stayed at a hotel with a BARE ceiling bulb without a fixture. Wow.

I wish I could remember the source I read that recommended this hotel because I would write them off forever. Boutique, yes, luxurious and sexy, no! The hotel may have been great when it opened but it is in need of a serious overhaul.

title: Beautiful old house but run down and very noisy - not worth the money
text: A beautiful old house but unfortunately also very run down and with many weaknesses. It reminded me of the neighboring Jane Hotel. The noise from the street was extreme because the windows were not insulated. You could hear the conversations in front of the house and he wind pulled so strongly through the window that you had to turn on the heater, which in turn is so loud that you could only sleep with earplugs. The reception was also not occupied as described from 7h, but in most days only from 8h, coffee was often even later. Once I came downstairs and a dog was upright with his feet on the counter of the service area, the staff tolerated this. When it rains, the water is in the entrance area. A small bottle of water costs $6!!! This is an outrage for hotel guests in my opinion! The door to the hallway is also not insulated and you can hear everything that happens in the house there too. Overall our room was also very run down. Compared to the "Standard High Line Hotel" in the neighborhood, this hotel falls far.

title: Beautiful rooms, not great service
text:
Well, it is a stunning building in a great location.  However, our prepaid cocktail situation never happened and the line for the coffee cafe was ridiculously long and serving the tiniest coffees!
Staff was v friendly and helpful and that does make a big difference.

title: Not recommended
text:
This hotel was really disappointing and missed all marks. The windows didn’t close or lock, the room was stuffy and smelled badly, the light in the bathroom was flickering or out the entire stay, the bed was very old and lumpy, the couch was broken and I found a small bug on my arm when I woke up my last morning. 

On the plus side, check in was easy and the staff was pleasant.

title: Quaint but lacking many of the basics
text: No airconditioning in the room i had.  No glasses for drinking water.  Windows are operable (which is rare/nice in NYC) but there were not protective bars (so you arent going to leave them open at night if you were on the ground floor).

title: Poor quality for an expensive room
text: The Hotel needs a massive renovation. Rooms are ruined and not properly maintained. The service is pretty bad for an expensive Hotel. The bed, mattress and blankets are low quality and the rooms are not maintained.

title: Style over substance.
text: Good location, nice room, rubbish mattresses, no facilities, a part time bar , part time baristas. Think that not even having a concierge desk, just the poor staff perched on a stool just isn’t a great welcoming experience. Style over substance.

title: Unfortunate short stay
text: Room way to small and very dated with zero amenities like even coffee or drinking glasses.  The room didn't feel clean because it was so dated.  This hotel needs a major remodel of rooms and common areas.  If this is hip and leave me out.l.

title: Meh...the guest rooms really lacked style or real focus on details
text: The rooms DO NOT look like the pictures.  No services in the room, no mini bar, no usb ports, furniture in sitting area didn't fit, but they crammed it in anyway.  Coffee maker was provided upon request, but I was told I was on my own to buy coffee, cream, sugar, etc..  Need maintenance to take another look at just finishing calking windows.  Looks like a 5 year old did the caulking.  No thanks High Line Hotel.

title: terrible stay, don't go!
text: water temperature not controllable. shower was either luke warm or scalding with no way to control it. cold water tap was warm or scalding, no way to control. no food/water/snacks in hotel after the coffee bar closes around 4 PM. I couldn't drink tap water because it was scalding. Rugs old and frayed. not nice.

title: Broken AC and glass
text:
The AC in the building was broken or off for most of my trip. It made for terrible sleep. I tried opening the windows, but biting bugs flew in and the city noise kept me up.
I also found broken glass pieces by the bathroom door which were missed in the cleaning prior to my visit.

title: Great location, awesome historical building and that’s all. Dated noisy rooms, Overall poor value for money
text: Usually either stay at the NOMAD (now the Ned) or Equinox.   Choose the hotel based on its great location and historical nature of the building.  Which was excellent. But unfortunately that is where it stopped.  Rooms are dated and with an old window air-conditioning unit, our 5th floor room was noisy and uncomfortable.  In hindsight, we should have read previous reviews, especially management’s responses to the ones that were honest in their feedback.  That should have been our que.  And yes, I should have read the fine print on the facility fees, but really $34 for Wifi and luggage storage ?

title: BEST NYC HOTEL
text: This hotel is not only in the best location it provides that home away from home feeling each and every time I stay! Their staff is so friendly and helpful. The amenities like the bikes and gym access are great along with the cute outdoor seating.

title: Awful hotel
text:
The outside and lobby is charming. Then I headed to the elevator to my room…elevator smelled extremely musty and it was humid. Unfortunately, my room wasn’t any better. The room was very dim, old, dingy and creepy. The area rug underneath my bed was tattered and torn. The hardwood floor was creaky in certain areas and the closet looked like something from a scary movie. 

But set all that aside because the worst part was hearing what sounded like a facet turning on in the room next door EVERY 20 minutes 24/7!!! The sound would last for 2-3 seconds but it was so loud that I couldn’t sleep. At 3:30am, I finally called the front desk and asked to be moved in the morning. They offered me earplugs in the meantime. Long story short, after explaining my situation several times and being told I would be moved, it never happened. Needless to say, I wore earplugs every night. Although, I probably needed earplugs anyway because the A/C was incredibly loud too. 

I’m EXTREMELY disappointed in this hotel and with the management there.

title: Drab and dark.
text: The re-do of an old Episcopal seminary could have been spectacular but it wasn't. The place is dated, cramped and has terrible lighting. Dusty old furniture, rugs, weird books on the mantelpiece. Couldn't possibly recommend this place.

title: Great location, and charming, but there's no coffee, and the 5th floor AC is abyssmal!
text:
Pros: Charming place. Great location. Cool outdoor restaurant. Nice staff.
Cons: The AC on the 5th floor is complete trash. If it's hot, DO NOT STAY ON THE 5TH FLOOR. The rooms are small. This probably annoyed me the most: not only is there no coffee in the room, but if you want coffee, you have to throw some clothes on, go down to the lobby, order it, wait, and then pay. Yes, it's excellent coffee. But for $350/night, they should do better than this. At a minimum, a voucher for the coffee should be provided. (The coffee bar is separate from the hotel.)

title: Great hotel but don’t stay on first floor
text: Th Highline Hotel is comfortable, well appointed and relaxing as long as you are situated above the cafe noises of the first floor. The front patio and back garden patio make the hotel far more private and relaxing than most places in NYC. Although the hotel lacks a proper restaurant, it is surrounded by excellent places, many of which do take away. Finally, the Highline is right across from access to raised railway Highline Park. A great place to stay in Chelsea!

title: Not a 4 star hotel experience
text: You can get a better experience for the money you are paying here. Conditioned Air was broken and all they could do was take me a fan. I had to keep my window opened, with all the street noise. The reception is not a counter, you have to look for the one employee there and they did not talk one to the other: I had to explain what I talked to the other employee and they were pretty confused with my requests. Oh, and I still did not receive my stay receipt.

title: Not worry the price
text: The hotel is very nicely decorated; staff is very nice but the beds are incredibly uncomfortable. Not to mention having to listen to the loud droning of my rooms window unit AC. If the hotel was half the cost, I wouldn’t complain but the value just isn’t there.

title: Likeable and quirky, but without all the facilities of a modern hotel
text: I liked the old building, individual rooms and the large bathroom. And the check in\out experience was so much more efficient than other hotels normally offer. I would stay here again if I was in this part of NYC and not looking for a hotel with a restaurant\room service.

title: Inflexible, Unresponsive, Never staying here again
text:
I'm sad to give a negative review to one of my formerly favorite hotels in the city. I have stayed at the High Line Hotel many times over the last 7 years, encouraged friends and coworkers to stay there, and planned work trips around this location so my company could stay here.

I was planning to fly from my honeymoon in Europe to New York. I had booked 2 nights at High Line. Unfortunately, I tested positive for Covid and could not fly back to New York. I emailed the hotel with proof of my positive test. I wanted to see if I could get a refund or a credit for a future stay. Not only did they decline this and charge me $600, but they took days to respond to the first email and they NEVER replied after that. I even followed up twice asking for a reply - nothing.

I will never stay there again, and it makes me very sad. This is below bare minimum customer service. They do not know the value of someone who stays at the hotel & loves it.

title: Zero Service at a Four Star Price
text: Come for the historic architecture, leave with no customer service. I booked a suite at over $600/night and was dismayed that 1) the hotel could not even comp a water bottle a day, but had the audacity to suggest I walk to Gristedes, the Kroger of NYC 2) not a single offer to assist with baggage to and from room or car service 3) no management on site overnight. And if you need management, you'll have to wait but expect zero resolution on their part. Look and go elsewhere.

title: Friendly and welcoming service and lovely rooms.
text:
I had never stayed at The High Line Hotel before, but it comes highly recommended by my colleagues who have stayed there when we visit our local business in NY. I was greeted by a very friendly and helpful receptionist upon arrival and was given a lovely room with all amenities.
The hotel does not have a 'traditional' reception in that the bar/coffee bar is outsourced to a third party who runs the service. It turns out that the coffee is so good that it has become a bit of a destination to locals that grab their coffee on their way to work. I can also vouch for that the coffee was of excellent quality. :-)
I stayed for four nights and felt quite at home by the time I left. I highly recommend this lovely hotel with wonderful staff in a friendly and rather smart area of town and will definitely come back some other time.

title: Great location, pretty rooms, poor temperature control
text: We stayed in a king room for a long weekend and the location was perfect. The hotel and room were very pretty, but the rooms were very stuffy. We were told the AC was not on yet (it was 80 on the day we arrived), so the room was quite hot. You could open windows, but there was no other way to control the room temperature. The unit in the room was essentially just a white noise machine.

title: NO MORNING COFFEE
text: I would give the hotel a high rating but for the fact that there was no coffee making ability in the room or on the property.  The Intelligensia coffee shop was closed both mornings despite being told that it would be open for coffee and pastries.  There was no apparent reason why the coffee shop was closed two mornings in a row and why there wasn't any back up set up for people to get a morning cup of coffee - the closest coffee shop is a long block away.

title: Don't stay here if you want to sleep.
text:
This used to be my go-to West side hotel. Sure, there's no room service, front desk or gym (I think there's access to an off-site place)... but it's so very charming. Most importantly, they have good sized rooms with two queen beds that are very comfortable-the ability to get a good night's sleep while traveling is key. Unfortunately, if you end up in a room on the front side of the hotel facing 10th avenue you will feel exactly as if there are three lanes of traffic running right through your room. Even more unfortunately, they will never guarantee requests will be honored. I booked the room over the phone this time and begged for a quiet room. The person I spoke with volunteered to put us on the back side of the hotel, gave us the room number and said he would mark it "Do Not Move" so that we would definitely be in that room. When we arrived we were led to Room 2- second floor, right on 10th Ave. It's not an exaggeration when I say it felt like we were right in the street. It's an old hotel and there was an AC unit in the window without any seal so essentially the window was open to the street. It was awful. I really didn't want to have to deal with the situation and was hoping I could just make it work but I could not. When I went to talk to the employee about it they told me that 1) there was never any note in our reservation and 2) they don't know why I had been moved from the room we were originally assigned and 3) their policy is that they will never guarantee requests. I started to check for rooms at other hotels because the thought of spending even one night in that racket was unbearable. They then called to speak to us but the room phone did not function. The person working came up to the room and offered to move us for the next two nights. Having no other choice, I thanked them. 

Once we moved to the new room life got measurably better, It was notably quieter. Sadly, the only option for food or beverages, the coffee bar in the lobby, was inexplicably closed both Saturday and Sunday, which was very inconvenient. At one point there was no hot water working in the hotel. I don't know what's going on with this place but it's not worth the considerable sum they charge for a room. There are so many nicer, easier, quieter places to stay. It's bittersweet to give up what I like to describe as your rich old aunt's haunted mansion- but with friendly, erudite ghosts, but give it up I shall. You should, too.

title: Don't stay here
text: Small rooms, NO service - front desk people do not answer the phone.  No water glasses in room and staff refused to bring them. Beware, NO AC in some rooms and they don't tell you  that. Worst place I have ever stayed in NYC.

title: Wonderful Location and Amazing Staff
text: This is my 3rd trip to the Highline and I absolutely love the location and staff.  Christian was amazing at checkin and we had a wonderful discussion on the history of New York City among other things.  The meat packing district is in walking distance and the Highline Park is just stunning.  I highly recommend!

title: 4 days was not enough
text: From our late arrival to our late-ish checkout, the H L H Staff was excellent. The hotel is definitely Not your ordinary hotel. What it may lack in "high-end" amenities, it makes up for with ambiance. Unfortunately, our stay was in March with it being cold and rainy but they have a wonderful area for "residents" to use in back and in front when the weather permits. The High Line Hotel is quite charming and welcoming. We would stay there again.

title: Classy and nostalgic hotel in the meatpacking district!
text: Historically rich Hotel with a ton of charm and allure.  Julie at the front desk was tremendous, she explained the history of the hotel and the founders of the original land.  My daughter and I were blown away!  I will return in the spring when the outdoor bar opens!

title: Lovely Hotel in the meat packing district
text: Love the Highline and this is my 3rd visit this year.  Rooms are always so clean and very spacious.  Love love the coffee bar in the morning. Big kudos to the housekeeper on the 5th floor and the doorman from Tibet!  I’m not great with remembering names but these folks made my stay!

title: The Charming Highline Hotel
text: I work for Google a few blocks away from The Highline Hotel.  It’s such a charming and quaint property- love the feel of the lobby with their coffee bar in the mornings.  Daisy the front desk clerk is amazing as well as Michael the bartender- he is a gem!  I will be coming back to Highline again.

title: Hotel has fallen apart- all because of rude staff
text: Stayed for seven days, had multiple rooms booked for my company business travelers as well. I have stayed at the high line hotel a number of times before- never again. The staff was extremely rude and not at all with the most basic requests. The rooms aren’t worth the attitude and complete lack of service. Go to the Dream or Gansevort.

title: Incredibly bad - read recent reviews!
text:
I checked in here at the end of Oct and was put in a dirty, paint peeling, very dark attic room with barely room to walk or stand up. The rug was ripped, the bathroom dirty, and the room was unacceptable.

I immediately went downstairs to ask for a room change and was told there were no rooms. I told them I couldn't stay there as it was unacceptable. They said fine and that they would remove charges. I found another place to stay that night.

Of course they charged my card, and despite multiple calls to the hotel and the assurance someone would call me back to fix it, they have not, and I spend $410 on a room that was uninhabitable.

Avoid at all costs.

title: One of the worst hotel experiences we've ever had
text:
I'm posting this review having written to the hotel 4 days ago on return from our trip and receiving no response. This shouldn't have come as a surprise given the non-existent service we experienced throughout our stay at The High Line.

The hotel has removed all amenities and services. When I say all amenities, I mean there wasn't even a bar of soap in our room or a glass to fill with water from the tap (let alone bottled water, coffee or any kind of food or room service). When we arrived in the evening after a flight from London, we were advised that we could go to CVS if we wanted water. The following day was thanksgiving and CVS was closed. 

Three days out of the four we stayed, there was no hot water in the morning. When we went downstairs to enquire on the first day, we were told that you have to run the tap for up to 15 minutes for the water to heat up! On two subsequent mornings when we tried this and there was still no hot water, we were advised that the boiler was out. On our final day, having had our plans delayed for the third time because of the lack of hot water, we informed reception that we needed to go out and would check out later in the evening before our flight because we needed to shower before travelling. When we checked out and I enquired about compensation for the bad experience we had had during our stay, the receptionist stated that they had generously waived a late check out fee... 

There only ever seemed to be one member of staff in the hotel at any given time and each of them was equally indifferent and unhelpful. No one offered to help with our bags and there was generally no proactive effort to make us feel comfortable or welcome, I requested to speak to the manager several times during our stay and was advised each time they would call me, but they never did. On the final morning, when we did manage to see the manager in person, he was just as ambivalent as every other employee. 

On top of all this, the rooms are tired and dark. There is a certain charm to the decor, but it feels worn and uncomfortable and there is no sound proofing. The net curtains were torn and stained brown. We spent the entire trip trying to avoid spending any time in our $900/night room. New York is a great city, but our experience at the High Line put a real dampener on it. I couldn't recommend it less and still have an angry feeling in the pit of my stomach about being thoroughly ripped off. I really wish we had left and found another hotel on our first night. Never to be repeated.

title: Quite ordinary
text:
Just got back from four amazing days in NYC where we had chosen to stay at The High Line Hotel in Chelsea as we have previously visited the hotel's coffee shop and fallen for the hotel's charm, ambiance and location.
The hotel is still charming and in a very nice location but seems a bit worn and we have rarely experienced, with few positive exceptions, such an absent staff who in no way seemed particularly interested in the hotel guests.
Seems there was a pretty indifferent atmosphere at the hotel though with a positive experience of the evening bar where one felt very welcome.
The rooms were nice and cozy but we lived facing the street and there was a relatively high noise level.
The hotel is expensive and we simply do not think we experienced value for money

title: Unfortunately not worth the price
text: We really wanted to like the hotel but the level of service and their upkeep of the hotel was underwhelming. It was not worth the price of the rate they were charging. We won’t be coming back unfortunately.

title: Grand Stay
text: We spent two nights here, wonderful charming building. Beds comfortable, room a nice size, convenient location. The lobby coffee shop was closed due to covid, but we had great lattes outside in the converted bus- and evening drinks in the same patio area.

title: Not all we hoped it would be…
text:
We booked the High Line months ago, having successfully secured Billy Joel tickets for Madison Sq Gardens.
When we arrived for check-in, our confirmation number didn’t exist. The Manager explained our booking was the victim of a company computer system update, but that they had managed to find us a room - albeit not the deluxe king we’d booked. Not the most auspicious of starts. But they did mostly resolve the issue.
The room was on the top floor, with a comfortable king bed and a spotlessly clean bathroom. While nicely furnished in a retro manner (like the rest of the hotel) there was a lack of any in-room drinks making - coffee or tea.
While there was a great coffee bar on the premises (a London bus in the front courtyard that opened early mornings and an in-building one that opened later), it’s very popular with dog walkers and passers by - so there was always a long queue. So an in-room coffee machine would be really useful.
Finally, the hotel is an old building. Great in terms of ambience and style, but not great at keeping the NY street noise out. The windows aren’t brilliant for that, so if you’re a light sleeper, this might not be the hotel for you.
All in all, great location and nice enough place, but not good enough in several areas for the money. We won’t be coming back.

title: High line needs a major  facelift
text: Stayed there 10/10 to 10/12. Hotel is in a great location if you are wanting to be in Chelsea. However...., the rooms are poorly appointed, the rooms are dark with very little outside light, the bathroom bathtub caulking had mold. The TV did not work,  elevator was broke while we were there so we were taking  the stairs. Staff is friendly, but some of their  comments suggested that staff is frustrated by the  focus on booking the hotel and not allowing staff to get into to rooms to maintain or upgrade. For this priced hotel, I would expect much better

title: Vastly Overpriced and Zero Amenities
text:
What a disappointment! I paid $500 for a room that was small, musty, old. The threadbare couch, the rug with chunks cut out of it. So underwhelmed.

And there are absolutely no amenities for some reason. Where most other hotels have reinstated things like food service, don’t expect any of that here. Even trying to have coffee in the morning — Intelligentsia doesn’t open until 7:30!

Staff were wholly ambivalent and couldn’t have cared less about me as a guest.

Wouldn’t ever stay here again.

title: Not a great hotel and not worth the price
text: The outside of the hotel is very pretty, but it’s really not worth the price to stay there. The rooms are tiny, rugs ripped, sinks cracked, and paint bubbling/cracking on the walls. You also have to ask for them to clean your rooms & bring new towels. If you request anything to be brought to your room they will probably not do it, so you’ll have to go pick it up yourself.

title: The High Line Was the Low Point of Our Trip
text:
On our most recent trip to the city, we were highly disappointed with our stay at the High Line Hotel. Having previously stayed at the property several years ago, both the quality of service and the hotel itself are seriously diminished. They stuck us in what was clearly a former boiler room located literally in the lobby (Rm #6)  and across from the elevators. 

When we inquired about switching rooms, the woman who checked us in, was dismissive, unhelpful, and unfriendly. She couldn’t be bothered to check on the availability of any other room, merely saying that the hotel was fully booked. We were checking in at 4pm, so it was highly unlikely that all the rooms had already been allocated. Don’t worry - there wasn’t a single person behind us waiting to be checked in, so time was not of the essence. Unfortunately she was the only available staff to communicate with. Later in the evening when we explained that the AC did not seem to be properly working, the same woman told us it was “ motion detecting and energy efficient” and that it would start working after 15 minutes of being in the room. After spending an entire night in the room, I’ve never experienced a balmier 65 degrees in my life. The system clearly never caught on to the two humans and a dog who were in there as it continued to blow warm air at us. It’s ok - the people directly on the other side of our window - where the bar is located - looked like they were enjoying the cooler night air. 

Hotel amenities were also sparse - one bar of soap between the sink and bath, no shower cap, and one stained robe (see photo). No extras in sight. There was nothing in the room that wasn’t nailed down. The dimly lit room was sparsely decorated, and unfortunately we couldn’t even offset with natural light without the guests at the bar being privy to our every move and nook and cranny. 

The misery of this room didn’t last too long because at 5:50 am the hotel staff were coming and going from the adjacent storage room, as they were getting ready for their day. As the room is located in the lobby we were also lucky enough to be part of every single conversation between the elevator and hotel front door. And while this hotel claims to be pet friendly, sticking a dog with every imaginable stimuli isn’t friendly at all. Even our poor pup didn’t get a good nights sleep. None of our issues were at all COVID - related, and I would suggest that the high line hotel adjust their prices to reflect their updated quality. I’m contrast - we stayed that the Greenwich Hotel a few weeks ago, and could not be happier with every single element of our stay. Highly recommend them, and really any other number of fabulous hotels we’ve stayed at. Sorry to say that high line is no longer among them. 

Photos: stained robe, disgusting bathroom tiles, missing hooks, gross sink.

title: Musty and rude
text:
Exterior is beautiful.

Room was musty, and all surfaces were damp. When we entered there was a dehumidifier running that was removed after we asked about it. Air conditioner was set at 65, room temp was about 83. Never lowered. Asked about the ac and musty smell, and housekeeping showed up with a febreze like substance. Did not stay the night, could not sleep. Moved. Night ‘auditor’ on duty was rude and kept my travel agent on hold for a long period of time when working on a solution. Literally grabbed the phone from my hand and was condescending. 

Will never recommend this hotel; will never stay here.

title: A magnificent stay at The High Line
text:
I rarely write a hotel, restaurant or purchase review, but our stay at The High Line Hotel from June 30 to July 4th was so remarkable that I felt it important to give credit to the hotel staff, the installations and location .
STAFF: Daisy and Rosalyn at the Front Desk couldn’t be friendlier and more accommodating, and that extends to the rest of the staff: the outdoor morning  coffee baristas, the person who makes sure your bicycle is well inflated (the hotel lends you bikes and helmets free!), the cleaning staff, etc. By the end of the first day, everybody in this boutique hotel is greeting you regularly and making you feel at home.
ROOMS are super clean, bedding and mattress are luxurious and the room we stayed at was huge, not only by NYC standards but any standard. The building itself is beautiful (I believe it housed seminary) and it is surrounded with beautiful patios and a very appealing outdoor bar..
THE NEIGHBORHOOD. It’s Chelsea, with lots of art galleries, restaurants, the High Line walk, Chelsea Market, the new Whitney museum. This hotel is a little gem in a big city and one almost gets the feeling that you’re coming back home every night. The hotel is also readily accessible to the subway system. A 10 min walk to most stations. 

Thanks again to everybody at The High Line hotel for a great stay. My son and I had a blast and we look forward to being back one day.

title: Great Chelsea location, lacks service
text: I stayed at the High Line recently for a special occasion weekend trip to New York. The location is amazing - in the heart of charming and historic Chelsea. The building is beautiful and historic - connected to the General Seminary. The al fresco bar out front (not affiliated with the hotel) is quite nice. The hotel? Disappointing. There is no doorman to assist with luggage or hail cabs, which is customary for this level of hotel in the city. The hotel rooms need a refresh - the furniture is scratched and scuffed; my lampshade had been bashed in and not replaced. Light bulbs were out. The mattress is old. But the worst is the nonexistent and indifferent service. The lobby is very small. Due to Covid, a coffee bar that is probably usually quite lively was closed, and coffee service is set up outside instead. There were several large cardboard boxes piled on top of the closed coffee bar. But the real issue is that the one person manning the lobby is almost always seated looking away from incoming guests, staring at a computer, and rarely turns their head to welcome or speak to guests. New York was just opening up when we were there, and all restrictions had just been lifted, but businesses had discretion to require masks or not. So it was confusing all over the city. Upon entering the lobby for check-in, I was greeted with, “you need a mask.” Not hello, welcome, would you please wear a mask?” I was given a room on the first floor, immediately facing bar tables (full of people) right outside my window. From the street you could see into my room. All in all, not what I had expected based on reading about and seeing photos of the hotel. Let’s just say the lobby person didn’t handle my request to move professionally - she said there were no solutions and suggested I just close my blackout curtains the whole time. In fairness, the manager contacted me the next day and offered to move me, but this was after I had already unpacked and made peace with all the people right outside my window because I had been told I had no other options. Only after several days did I stumble upon the fact that there was an honor bar with bottled water, snacks, wine, etc. No one bothered to tell us anything about the amenities. I won’t be back unless I read about a major upgrade in the service level and refurbished rooms. It’s a shame, because the concept of the hotel with its historic ambience is so appealing.

title: Decorated in early garage sale
text: Unmaintained stained and scratched furniture, dinged walls and doors. cracks in the sink,, torn upholstery, we felt like we were in a "bowery" style cheap hotel. When I complained, they said it was "the look" they were trying to convey.  No hot water one morning, coffee available outside, overpriced and couldn't even charge it to the room.  Eat off the cart on the street, you will do better.  At the same time, comfy bed, good location, but way overpriced for what you get.  If you want to stay in your grandmother's spare bedroom, this is for you.  It sure was wrong for us.

title: Sad staff sours stay
text:
I thought I’d give the High Line Hotel a shot since I like the Chelsea area and it’s a pretty convenient location.

The building was charming, but the staff had no personality, which was apparent at the lobby checking in, where I experienced blank faces and almost cutting tones from the reception. It made
me feel like I was inconveniencing them!

I know that it must not be an easy time to work especially now, and that everyone has their bad days, but it seemed like throughout my multiple nights (4) here all the staff I interacted with visibly seemed annoyed, so I tried my hardest to avoid them at all measures.

Would not recommend, and would not stay again.

title: Violated
text: During a recent stay I was trying to hold space for intimacy with my wife. Someone used a key to enter room and violated our time together. My wife was beyond appalled. The reaction from manager on duty at the time was unacceptable. He said sorry. Nothing else. It’s disturbing that this event happened in a place we once held sacred. UNACCEPTABLE!!!

title: Good location, but service is extremely uneven
text: Great location and decent rooms at a reasonable price.  After 3 nights, I left my bags for safe-keeping as I went out for some meetings.  When I came back and prior to embarking for the airport, I asked to use the bathroom facilities.  The front desk said that none were available and I would have to do without.  After a long and lively debate, the front desk finally called the janitor to open the bathroom facilities on the ground floor.  It should not have taken such energy to use the bathroom after being a guest in the hotel for 1 night, much less 3 nights.  It reflects badly on hotel management.

title: Needs room updates
text: Cold showers, pillows need replacement, antique doors beautiful but difficult to open and loud open and close. Resort fee seems inappropriate as there are no resort amenities which may be due to COVID to be fair. Online third party booking service (guestreservations.com) pulled a bait and switch, added on over $250 in a booking fee on top of hotel charges,taxes and resort fee!  They rebook from Priceline. Hotel should drop them!

title: Lovely oasis in the middle of a bustling City
text: A great spot to kick back and feel like you've left NYC. Cute and quaint. Lovely rooms, wonderful court yard and across the street from the High Line and close to so many great places. A real neighborhood feel. Easy walk to the West Village, Chelsea Market, Whitney and Hudson Yards.

title: Unhealthy BLACK MOLD and they still will not move my room
text:
I was horrified to see mold and disintegrated plaster walls when I walked into my room. I immediately went downstairs to change rooms at 5pm and was told I could not be given a new room because I had washed my hands in the room. Pretty much a necessity in COVID times when arriving by plane. 

There is clearly an active leak and mold but was told it was just the new paint (what?how? ) and that I couldn’t not be moved as the maids had left at 4pm. Mind you I had to wait in the lobby upon my arrival bc my room “hadn’t been serviced” well after 4pm and the maids service items were still in the hallway. I saw plenty of availability and rooms advertised online when I checked sites but was given zero accommodations beside a room full of black mold. I was told I could talk to an absent manger after going to dinner at 6pm and afterwards was told the manger had left by 9pm. No one has reached out in any way to make this right in fact was told if I moved rooms I would most likely be DOWNGRADED. 

I thought I would take a bath to relax but found what looked like gobs of toothpaste (ugh!) caked around the sink. Sleeping in my clothes with windows open and angry as all hell. A simple switch is the basic thing to do in this situation and would have made a huge difference to me - a guest staying for TEN DAYS. Unbelievable.

title: Many better options in NYC
text: I would never ever stay here again.  The official check in time is 3pm, but I was not able to get in until 4:30pm.  I never received any apology for the delay in the room preparation.  I got a lame excuse for such delay, but no apology.  The explanation for such delay and inconvenience was that the hotel was fully sold out, which meant the hotel was fully occupied to the extent permitted by the current covid rules.  My take on this sorry excuse is that if the hotel is not ready to accept guests at the published check-in time because the house keeping crew cannot handle the demand, then it should not accept that many guests.  The reception also told us that they were doing the best they could.  Well, their best was not good enough when the guest had to wait 1 hour and 30 mins to get in the room she/he paid for.  Such excuse is only valid if the guest is asking for something he/she is not entitled to have. The reception kept telling me to wait 10 mins more.  When did 10 mins start to mean 90 mins?   Having said that, one room out of 2 rooms I booked was ready on time, but not without trouble.  The reception gave my mother the wrong room number and the keys to the wrong room,, so my mother had to go up and down to get the correct room number and the corresponding key.  The reception kindly reminded me that the other room was ready when I complained about the delay in getting my room.  I had no clue as to what she was trying to tell me.  There is a reason why you book 2 rooms instead of one.  It's because you want your own room.  If I wanted to share a room with another person, I would have booked one room and pay for one instead of two!  The reception staff also told me that she had tried calling me when the room was ready which was between 4 and 4:30.  I never received any call from the hotel that day.  I even took a screenshot of my incoming call history to prove that no such call was made.  To add more stress to the situation, when my mother (72 years old) and I tried to use the restroom in the lobby, we were told to go elsewhere because the restroom was closed.  I told her that we were guests of the hotel and she said that it was recommended that we use the restroom in our room....  At that time, not one room was ready for our use....  Further, the restroom was occupied by someone and we were waiting for that person to finish using the rest room.  I was totally confused at that point.  The rest room is open for some people but not for us???  There are so many hotels with 4 stars in NYC.  There is no reason for anyone to stay at the highline hotel when you can get better service elsewhere.  To name one, I stayed at the Ludlow Hotel in NYC one month ago and all of the hotel staff members I encountered there were friendly and PROFESSIONAL.

title: Not what I expected!
text:
This was my first visit to see my daughter in 15 months. She has just to 21st moved and the High Line is a block away. 
I was excited to have a close hotel. 
The staff was mediocre at best. And the management has not returned my call about an charge to my room. 
It was a very disappointing experience.

title: quirky boutique hotel mid-Chelsea
text: early 19th century building converted to unique hotel; excellent location in Chelsea neighborhood, friendly staff. Cafe run by independent company serves good coffee in lobby or in pleasant outdoor area.

title: Simple. Chic. Friendly.
text:
I have visited the Highline for coffee in the morning on other visits and this time needed a place to stay where I could bring my senior dog. It was such a cool experience. It's not like a normal hotel with bells and whistles and room service. It feels more like you are staying at a really stylish friend's house. 
The staff was so friendly and accommodating and spoiled my dog Delores every time they saw her with kisses, pats and treats. The room had such interesting vintage furniture and I adored the history of the building itself.
Highly recommend!

title: Room felt tired
text: Shabby chic felt more chic pre-COVID. We stayed here once in 2019 and loved it. This time the room felt tired and dark. Wanted to see more emphasis on safety during COVID. However the bed was extremely comfortable and the location is great.

title: perfect stay
text: We stay in lots of NYC hotels and this one was really special.  We had a gorgeous corner king deluxe room with a fireplace and views onto the High Line.  The room was huge and filled with really nicely curated vintage furniture.  All of the design elements were really thoughtful; loved the wallpaper behind the headboard especially.  Was surprised to see others' feelings that service was lacking; it's a pandemic and most of the usual hotel services are unavailable anyway but the check in process was friendly and helpful.  The hotel made for a lovely and romantic stay, a must for anyone who would be into a historic property with just the right modern updates.

title: Enjoyable, but missing a personal touch...
text:
We enjoyed our stay, but were really disappointed by the aloof service and lack of amenities. The receptionist wasn’t particularly friendly or helpful. When we had a couple items delivered to the hotel since they don’t have room service, we were told to pick them up from the lobby ourselves as they wouldn’t bring anything up to our room. I had mentioned in the reservation that we were celebrating a birthday and it was not acknowledged at all.

The room itself was beautiful and spacious, but sparse - not much besides a bed and some basic furniture, would expect more thoughtful touches from such a well rated hotel.

title: Great atmosphere - perfect for a night staycation
text: The ambiance of the hotel was very charming. It was the perfect choice for our Valentine's Day staycation in the city. The friendly and helpful staff was a plus! Would definitely recommend and will be staying here again.

title: a gem
text: Highly recommend -- if you do not like your stay here then it is your problem, not any fault of the hotel. The staff is AMAZING. The rooms are exceptionally clean, communication is superb, and I felt extremely safe and taken care of.

title: Full of history, skimpy on service
text: If you're an independent traveler and don't want or need much service or hand holding, you'll enjoy The High Line Hotel. I've long been curious about it - I used to work in the neighborhood and came by often for their (awesome) Intelligentsia coffee bar in the lobby. Location is fantastic - steps from the High Line, couple of blocks from Chelsea Market. The rooms themselves are all different - mine was a deluxe king in the corner (lots of windows!) on the 5th (top) floor. The decor and details are lovely - beautiful antiques, eclectic mix of furniture, love the wallpaper accent. The bed is huge and comfy, and I liked the nice-sized writing table for one day of working remotely. Bathroom is HUGE and toiletries from CO Bigelow are a nice touch. The downside of The High Line is a total lack of services - no restaurant or room service, and not even any mini bar at the time of my stay (Feb 2021), which was disappointing. There's not a front desk per se - one person with a tablet essentially - who did the barest minimum. (I didn't even get the receipt via email that I requested at checkout.) All in all if you're looking for a well-appointed room in a fantastic locale with good coffee - you'll be very happy here! But luxe services/being waited on, this is not the spot.

title: Disappointing stay
text: While nothing went wrong  per se, I was disappointed with the furniture and decor. The room vibe overall felt old and dusty, as opposed to charming and cosy like I was expecting... Very grateful for the room upgrade but unfortunately I wasn't impressed with the experience overall. The lobby is beautiful and bed was comfortable.

title: Amazing!
text:
Perfect West Village location with lots of great stuff nearby... Chelsea galleries, Cookshop restaurant, Intelligensia Coffee on site. It’s so beautiful!  Also, the staff are all amazing hosts - helpful and very friendly!  I also have to call out Julie specifically for graciously fulfilling an unusual request!  

I will definitely be back!  :)

title: Nothing but love for the High Line Hotel
text: This Hotel is a gem. Everyone should stay here at least once. The location, the design and comfort are everything you want in a boutique hotel experience. I stayed for five days and was sad to leave. I look forward to my next visit.

title: Great stay for a native New Yorker
text: I now live out-of-state but wanted to visit family with my partner and make a weekend trip out of it. This was such a fun place to stay—convenient location, friendly staff, and very Instagram-friendly.

title: Great  getaway weekend still can happen in NYC  for us
text: This beautiful hotel was a retreat well needed for us. the lovely setting of outdoor patio serving drinks and great ambiance, a beautiful courtyard on the other side to have some peace of mind and feel like I am away and safe, polite and helpful staff, comfy rooms in a great neighborhood. We walked each night to 9th avenue for good dinners and walked to the Whitney for a great art exhibit. The High line was open in one direction to take a nice walk on a beautiful Saturday.  If you are like me, and wanted a retreat away from the electronic buzz.. this place provided that easy , safe, lovely setting.

title: Dated But Charming
text:
So I will start with the positive. The place is charming with a beauty outdoor patio for you to grab the perfect cup of espresso by Intelligentsia. The rooms are big and the address is central if you need to be downtown. Bed comfortable. Soap and shampoo by Bigelow which I love. And water pressure in shower is amazing. Upon check in. We were upgraded. Thank you. 

Now, no one to take luggage to the room. No room service no breakfast at hotel or even lunch. AC didn’t work they even brought a fan and changed the filter and still no go. Had to leave window open and then there is the noise of all the construction on the Highline. On Night two of 4 I asked to move my room please and was ignored. Wrong person to ignore. No one should be ignored. Better to say we can’t accommodate sorry. Saw rodent run across patio dinning area freaked me out so closed window there is no screen. Didn’t sleep well at all. Staff not attentive. Again wanted to love this spot and come back. 

What they need to do to up their A game in the hotel industry and do it now. Yes I’m an expert so I will share. 

Keep all the charm. The building the fixtures the antiques especially rugs  and furniture in the room. DO NOT MODERNIZE this beautiful building. 
Morning this patio is packed... so silly distance of course. It’s a great opportunity to be able to provide some food more than just a few muffins and morning pastries. 
Perhaps an avocado toast a ricotta toast and egg salad toast things that can be easily made and quick. 
Upgrade or heating and air-conditioning units make sure that things work in the room including light fixtures which was another issue in my room. It’s New York City so rodents are expected. Have someone take my luggage up to my room I know it’s an extra expense but the state wasn’t cheap you can certainly have someone socially distant and wearing gloves taking up the luggage so I don’t have to take it up all the stairs before I get to the elevator. 
Fix all the cracks on the floors in the rooms the ceilings the bathrooms nobody wants to see that it’s kind of gross you can still look vintage but I have a clean finish. 
Up the age bracket of the people you have handling the front desk or just train your current stuff a little bit better in hospitality I get it that this is like a BoHo chic property but still being that all this is happening on the Highline right now you’re going to get the upper scale guests staying here might as well get them to come back. 
Overall as much as I’d like to give it a four out of five I’m really at a three 3 1/2 and that’s because the outside bus is the biggest attraction to this place. Just look at the pictures.

title: Special NYC experience
text:
My wife and I opted to take a one night staycation and stay at the Highline Hotel for our wedding anniversary. We mentioned that we were celebrating our wedding anniversary and all of the staff and management treated us so kindly and made us feel special from the get go.

We enjoyed some great Intelligentsia coffee in the courtyard, sitting on the English bus in the garden.

Hats off to the hotel designers. Everything is done tastefully and is of high quality. The grounds, the access to the Highline (we booked online due to Covid), the vibe, the room, the  bed, the linens, and the bathroom all made for an excellent experience.

One area for improvement- we were hoping to be able to access our Netflix on the smart TV, but we didn't have any luck and the staff wasn't sure. No big deal. 

We were hoping we could ride the hotel bikes, but we learned that the program was suspended due to hygiene concerns regarding Covid. We were disappointed, but ultimately glad the hotel management took precaution and implemented safety measures. 

Kudos to the staff. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay and are looking forward to the next time!

title: Absolutely Fabulous
text: The High Line Hotel is exquisite. Elizabeth assisted me with many questions I had before checking in and provided exemplary guest services throughout my stay. Thank you so much Elizabeth for assisting me with recommendations and for making my stay so wonderful. In addition to the phenomenal guest services, the room was gorgeous and pristine, I can’t recommend enough, and cannot wait to return often.

title: picturesque hotel
text: Nice hotel with great quirky rooms.  no room service, no minibar in room and skeleton staff, but great location. I would stay there again but make sure to be very clear about what type of room you want.

title: Great hotel in a perfect NYC location
text:
I loved the High Line Hotel. The hotel is beautiful, with an incredible courtyard for a morning coffee. The room was a nice size for a NYC hotel. Our room faced the courtyard and was very quiet. The bedding and toiletries were excellent. 

In addition to being a wonderful hotel, the location is perfect. You are right near Chelsea Market and the High Line. Decent walks to many, many wonderful neighborhoods with great food and bars. We will be back!

title: Disappointment in the heart of Chelsea
text: My daughter and I had a timed ticket to visit the High Line.  Afterwards, we wanted to have a cocktail and a nosh.  Signs leaving the High Line suggested supporting local businesses, and the High Line Hotel with it's outside Garden sounded like just the thing.  What a disappointment!  I understand drinks without food is not allowable at this time, but to have limitations on what counted as food without any guidance on the menu was a bit much.  The service was horrible.  From the hostess, to our waiter to the other waitstaff on premise who finally waited on us.
