- A spacious courtyard in back 
- A nice bar/restaurant out front
- Huge basket of snacks and tray of liquor tempting you in the room
What I thought was missing:
- Odd check in process - standing next to someone while they punch in your info on a dated looking screen on an old laptop did not inspire confidence in the infrastructure of the rest of the hotel
- SLOWEST elevator I have ever encountered - reminded me of the one in my Mom's condo in Florida but even slower - I used the steps when going down but that isn't an option for going up - due to security I guess you have to take the elevator
- No real indoor lobby - just a few benches
- No breakfast - they do have a coffee bar - don't be in a hurry
- Wrong address on Uber App - if you just type in the hotel name on Uber the driver will think you are several blocks away - be sure to double check

title: Hotel with character - and super comfy beds!
text:
Great location, awesome historic hotel with character.  Bed was incredibly comfortable.  Room was quiet and comfortable.

Quirky unique lobby and rooms.  Coffee bar in lobby was nice.  Only thing missing was ability to have breakfast to room.

title: Great fresh air with real windows...thin walls...quite chic...
text: It is a lot like staying at a friend's apartment...not a huge amount of service--but everyone is very nice...I had a small suite on the courtyard, where the the windows open wide pulling in lots of fresh air...so nice...the air conditioning also worked really well. Internet was easy.

title: Favorite Hotel in NYC
text: I travel to NYC twice a month for business.  The Highline Hotel is a fantastic home away from home.  The staff are all warm, thoughtful and helpful.  The rooms are the remedy for soulless, corporate hotels.  Comfortable, eclectic and amenable to all of my travel needs.  Arriving back to the hotel at the end of the day or evening, is like coming home to your cool neighborhood gathering spots.  Regulars at the bar with dogs in tow, the hotel is a place I look forward to returning to again and again...

title: Romantic and Sophisticated Getaway
text:
My partner and beloved spent another fantastic weekend at our favorite stay-cation getaway in Manhattan, The High Line Hotel. We met on the patio having 5-Star coffee from Intelligentcia May 2017 and have enjoyed the property ever since. The Golden Hour is a huge summer success. We celebrated our anniversary in a private corner two-top. We've always enjoyed great service and a perfect night's sleep. Our favorite room is romantic and sophisticated with local dining options and spacious classic-NYC style that captures the soul of the city. Nicolas, the property manager, is true professional and a great asset to The Hotel! 

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️-We 💚 The High Line Hotel NYC

title: beautiful, comfortable, friendly hotel that feels like home
text: We have stayed in several hotels in NYC for our productions (photo/video shoots) and The Highline Hotel is by far my favorite.  It's great for long stays as it really almost feels like an apartment (just without a kitchen).  The rooms are comfortable and beautiful, it's quiet at night and the staff is friendly and helpful.

title: A wonderful oasis in the midst of Manhattan and Chelsea
text: We came for a weekend getaway to celebrate our engagement anniversary and my birthday. The hotel and staff could not have been better for a quick get away. The architecture of the place is amazing and we were so close to everything we wanted to do. Right on the High Line and easy walking, subway or cab access to the rest of the city. We'll be back!

title: Chic and Coffee
text:
Those two words come to mind with my stay at the high line hotel. Love their coffee bar, nice lounge with WIFI and good coffee.  Hotel itself has an old world feel but chic , rooms are smaller in size but good for. one : few day stay. Has a safe and a fridge included with black out curtains.  Stacked Bar / Snacks loaded in room ( Fee).  Very close to the highline itself and pier 57.  Walking distance to Chelsea market too. 
My only disappointment was that I wasn’t able to select my room type , i booked via hotel tonight and it’s “ hotels choice “ so i didn’t have the option to select double beds.  In speaking to the hotel, they advised they only have a limited amount of rooms with double beds.

title: Landmark  on a hype district
text:
Ever since we walked the high line years ago, wanted to be guests at this hotel. Despite the expectation were high it didn’t disappointed us to the slightest,
There are always a special vibe when enjoying a landmark “inside out”
Regular size rooms (NYC size, any other place they will be small), original bathrooms with inordinately wide and deep bath tubs (really they worth time to enjoy the experience).
Clean and very professionally managed.

title: Don't compromise. Stay here. Really.
text: So, I travel a lot both U.S. and internationally. I stay in many types of places from AirBnB to local boutiques and 5 star resorts. I don't give 5 star ratings lightly. This place deserves it. Starting with the bellman who met us out on the curb when we pulled up and advised us on parking, the the check in staff and lobby coffee bar ... room was luxurious but chill, very quiet too which is critical to me a lite sleeper. Great location and patio out front to relax, but make reservations if you want dinner, it's always packed. There are so many options to stay but I won't bother experimenting anymore, will stay here for business or special occasions both.

title: Minable
text:
Deux chambres, six nuits, grosse note, on demande un Check out pour 15:00 pour une chambre: 200 usd.
Ce n’ est pas comme ça qu’ils vont nous revoir.
C’est vraiment considérer les clients comme des vaches à lait. A éviter!

title: Great for Gallery Hopping. Expensive.
text:
For us the location was perfect. We wanted to be near as many art galleries as possible, and we spent one entire day checking out exhibit after exhibit quietly tucked away in the blocks near the hotel.

The hotel is a funky appealing mixture of old and modern. We were warmly greeted by the staff and checked in via laptop, no desk! The mosaic-tiled lobby is small and packed with hipsters perusing their laptops and phones. A coffee station/bar is off to one side. The space gives way to a generous patio out back, with numerous tables and chairs surrounded by a courtyard wtih large leafy trees.

We were quickly and cheerfully check in. Room 1 is a King Suite, gargantuan by New York standards. Wood floors,. The ceilings are high, there is wooden molding everywhere, the furniture is second hand, but in a good way, not shabby. The bed is completely modern, a veritable cloud of crisp white linen comfort.

We had a seating area with table, couch and two chairs, various side tables, a desk with chair and stool, flat screen large TV, The mini bar and fridge is cleverly housed in a mid-century modern cabinet. I should add, they should call it a maxi-bar. Man was it packed with every kind of booze you could want. Check the price list provided before you start popping those bottles!

The room has huge windows covered by sheers and velvet floor-length curtains. Beyond the windows is a quiet grass filled courtyard dotted with large trees. Serene space, accessible through the hotel's aforementioned patio.

The bathroom was enormous and I loved it. Old New York bathroom black and white tiled floor. Sparkling clean new sink encased in a generous marble counter. A nice little selection of amenities, plenty of towels, large fluffy robes and slippers. I padded around in the robe a lot, loved it for lounging. 

The shower is spotless, could use a grab bar. Terrific water pressure. Shower curtain did that billowy thing that gets a little irritating when it sticks to your body. Bench in the bathroom very handy for laying out clothes. Could use another bar to hang towels.

The lobby features a coffee station that converts to a bar at night. A wonderful caramelized-sugar aroma greeted us every morning from the lobby.  I ordered an oat-milk latte and was bowled over. I ordered two the next day!

If you exit the hotel and turn left, you'll get to a small grocer that has provisions. For the mini-bar averse, this grocer will save you some $$$. Good beverages, made-to-order salads and sandwiches. You can get what you need here to tide you over. I even saw them cutting wheat grass for a fancy fresh juice. They call themselves Chelsea Market, but don't be fooled, this is not THE Chelsea Market, more on that later.

Of course the High Line walkway is right there, across the street from the hotel and down one block.

Don't miss the Chelsea Market. It's amazing and about five blocks from the hotel. We were looking for Los Taco restaurant and didn't realize it was inside the Market. The CM is an amazing indoor complex of cool shops, specialty vendors, eateries and watering holes. What a find. We loaded up on amazing tacos and had dinner in Manhattan for under $20.Mind you, we were eating off paper plates, standing up at a table shared with strangers, but, still, it was delicious.

The room was quiet and comfortable, the hotel is charming, the staff is friendly. Two nights cost us upwards of $1400. This was a splurge for a big birthday. For that much money, I want 24-hour room service and the ability to make coffee in my room. Despite the many positives, my next splurge in Manhattan will be with a hotel that offers more bang for the buck.

title: Cool Boutiquey Hotel
text: Great place to stay, central to so many places. Loved the furnishings. The antiquey/retro feel was warm and inviting. Great little coffee bar downstairs, could smell the coffee wafting up into my room in the morning. I would certainly go back next time I visit NY!

title: Fabulous!
text: We stayed at the High Line for our wedding and it was a wonderful experience.  The staff was extremely helpful and friendly.  The hotel itself has boatloads of charm and was the perfect setting for our wedding weekend.  The coffee bar in the lobby is a great asset in the morning and the outdoor restaurant is the front is a lovely place to have lunch.  There is also a courtyard in the back that is great for sitting with friends and relaxing.  The location in Chelsea was also very convenient and, as the name suggests, is right next to the High Line itself.  The only criticism that I could think of is that the rooms are on the smaller side, but it is New York, so that should pretty much be expected.

title: great choice for the location, but know that other NYC boutiques offer MUCH more
text: Great location if you want to be right atHigh Line and Chelsea galleries.  Historic brick building, relatively large rooms, comfy beds, retro decor.  Good coffee bar (Intelligencia) is lobby.  And nice shaded courtyard restaurant in summer.  But, it's NOT a full-service hotel - no valet parking (and limited nearby parking options), no room service, no gym.  Furnishings/decor are more 1920s-1950s comfortable than designer.  Bathrooms have vintage tile, but old-school tub-showers.  Windows aren't triple-glazed so 10th Ave noise is an issue. If you are arriving by cab/uber for a night or two and just want to enjoy High Line and Chelsea galleries, it's perfectly fine.  But if you are driving or want some place with more (more style, more service, more special touches, and just more memorable), I'd suggest The Greenwich in Tribeca or maybe Crosby Street in Soho.  Either one is a definite couple notches above.

title: Wonderful hotel!
text: I stayed at the High Line Hotel recently for 4 nights. The room was extremely comfortable and a great size by NY standards. It was also very quiet. My room looked out on the courtyard. Everyone who works at the hotel was very nice and I enjoyed being able to get coffee in the lobby every morning. There is also a beautiful courtyard and a restaurant that looked good, although I didn't try it. The hotel furnishings and ambience are also great. I liked that the only thing open to non guests was the restaurant, so you didn't have random people coming up and down in the elevator. Will try to stay here whenever I'm in NY!

title: Best Hotel in Manhattan
text: We have been staying at the High Line Hotel for years now.  We have also stayed at many of the "popular" hotels in Manhattan.  We recently stayed again at the High Line because our relative moved back to West Chelsea, and we are so glad!  This hotel is the most comfortable, spacious, charming. cool hotel in NYC. The staff is awesome, and the perc of being able to use Equinox is amazing. Great coffee/pastry bar in lobby.  We love the High Line Hotel.

title: Great New York stay
text: Fantastic hotel, great helpful staff, fabulous bicycles, beautiful dogs in the lobby every morning, very agreeable stay.  I came with my family, also very teenager tolerant !  Great restaurant facility on the street level with calm backside area to enjoy a drink or tea with friends.

title: Great location, and the nicest staff!
text: Had a great stay, really enjoyed the curated rooms with nice touches - fun wallpaper, a coloring book in my room, and a very comfortable bed! I was impressed with the follow through and communication of the staff when I accidentally left my jewelry in the room after leaving the hotel (and NYC). They were quick to call me back, and happy to help ship my things back to me!

title: Beautiful Hotel in a Great Location!
text:
We wanted to stay in a unique hotel close to The High Line. We definitely found it!
This hotel has beautiful rooms with lots of little features, including robes, slippers and a working rotary phone (great for stumping the kids!). The staff was friendly and very helpful; they guided us with recommendations for local restaurants and directions to nearby attractions. I would definitely stay here again!

title: MAGIC GEM & PUP WONDERLAND BY THE HIGHLINE, NYC
text: What can I say about this amazing hotel? From the decor, which is steampunk-lite, elegant, and cozy, to their comfortable, spacious rooms, to their lovely, quiet courtyard, to their 19th century red brick monastery vibe, to the best espresso in NYC, to their fantastic locale in Chelsea right by the Highline, to the most important thing of all: DOGS. After coming to NYC for many, many years, this is by far my favorite hotel. The staff is great--warm and friendly and helpful, and I just love it. I can't think of one thing I'm unhappy with. It's pretty much the only hotel I stay at now. As for the restaurant, I haven't eaten there, so I can comment on that, but the rest, well, go see for yourself. Cheers. Mira Bartok, Author/illustrator

title: Sanctuary
text: About 6 years ago as my husband and I were strolling in Manhattan we happened upon a cool brick building that stretched on for an entire block. As we followed it around the corner we found to our pleasant surprise that it had “turned into” a hotel!   We walked in and booked a room there and then for that night.  It is such a wonderful escape from the pressures of everyday life.  Over the years it has become our home away from home whenever we want to celebrate a special occasion or just get away and enjoy some quality time in a peaceful, serene setting.  I have also spent weekends with my girlfriends and celebrated a bachelorette nite here as well.  It always feels like home.  Staff couldn’t be friendlier and accommodating!  p.s. best frozen Negronis too!!! ❤️👍❤️

title: Best Hotel in NYC!
text: Amazing hotel Robert and Nalani who work there are are simply the best!! They made my daughter and I feel like fairy princesses!! We Can’t wait to get back there!! World class hotel with extraordinary staff!! Bravo

title: Poor Choice of Summer Restaurant
text: My family and I visit the hotel on a regular basis. Intelligentsia is our coffee of choice and we use the garden as our second home. The hotel's open door policy to their outer space has been a great addition to our community. This is why it has been so frustrating to see the attitude of the restaurant to its clients. They close the garden at early hours in the morning to prepare for lunch while tables are left unused all morning. They have also taken the bad habit of placing signs on the ramp which make navigating with a stroller very difficult.

title: Awesome
text:
Such a great hotel in a great location. Th3 bar is also cool and you can get up to the Highline in about 30 seconds!! 

The suite we had (No#2) was fantastic and we couldn't fault it. Coffee and pastry down stairs was good, there is also a good one over the road. The Cook Shop is great for breakfast.

Christian was also so helpful to us. He's a credit to the hotel.

title: Great Stay
text: My husband and I just stayed at the High Line Hotel over the fourth. The motivation for our trip was a milestone birthday for him on the 3rd. I contacted the hotel to ask if they would assist me with setting up a little something in our room upon our arrival to wish him a happy birthday. I asked if I might be able to purchase a bottle of champagne that they could put in the room, Nalani said they would be happy to help and would also include a selection of macarons and some nice bottles of water. It was all waiting in our room when we checked in. My husband was surprised and it was a lovely way to kick off our vacation. We enjoyed our stay. The location is great. The beds were super comfy and everyone was very nice. We would certainly stay at the High Line again.

title: Lovely unique hotel in a great neighborhood
text: We wanted a unique experience in contrast to the usual hotel chain we resort to. This hotel did not disappoint. It had an almost European feel and the staff was very welcoming and helpful. A great location near the High Line and Chelsea Market, restaurants, and not too far from the subway. The bed was so comfortable and the room had the feel of staying in someone’s home rather than a generic hotel. Since it was pricey we went with the smallest room which didn’t give us comfortable seating for 2 but other than that was fine. Next time we may splurge on a larger space.

title: Great hotel in a charming classic building
text: My last stay in NYC was NOT good, so I decided to try a new hotel.  High Line came through and made for a completely different trip.  Very friendly and helpful staff, a comfortable room with everything I needed, easy access to great coffee in the lobby and walkable to everywhere I needed to go.  I will stay here again!

title: Great hotel in the great location
text: The hotel is in the great location near High Line with lot of  nice restaurants and  caffe around. The caffe shop in the lobby is one of the best in thsi area. The room (I was upgrate to suite) was big enbough, clean and quiet. I like very much bad which was so comfortable. And the stuff were very friendly. I will definitely come back and suggest others to stay there.

title: Charming and Clean
text: The room was charming, clean and quaint. Very small however, that is to be expected in New York. Had lunch at the café located on the property. They also have an adorable coffee shop in the lobby. I would strongly suggest staying in this hotel.

title: Strange place
text: It's a great hotel if your idea of "great" is a youth hostel in Florence in the early 70s.  You walk into an over-crowded, tiny and noisy lobby -- these are all underdressed people poring over their electronic devices and looking as though they are waiting for a Greyhound bus.  There is no check-in desk -- no room for one, so you stand in the middle of the crowd (these are not hotel guests) and try to register.  Upstairs the hallways are dimly lit and smell bad.  Our suite was the size of a regular hotel room elsewhere, and the bathroom was tiny and dated.  The furnishings were straight out of Goodwill, and if they paid retail for anything in there, they got scammed.  The room was a strange shape -- not cool strange -- and in order to get into and out of the bed, I had to duck under an eve next to the window, (which was missing a screen).  The bookshelves were stocked with dusty old and honestly, who reads Voltaire on vacation?  Four bright spots -- the bed itself, which was comfortable -- the in-room a/c, which was easy to use -- the oversize bathrobes, which were super comfortable -- and a well-stocked mini bar.  But for $625 dollars, it ought to have a few good qualities, right?.  I like the fact that it's dog friendly, though an early morning barking match between a dachshund and a lab in the lobby was a rude awakening.  I kept thinking the place would grow on me.  The best I can say about it is that it was memorable -- in a bad way.

title: Not a hotel - a coffee shop for dog owners
text: The only thing going for it is the location - all downhill after that. Rooms are exceptionally noisy even by NYC standards - no double glazing; terribly noisy aircon unit - OK if you can sleep beside a 747 engine. Coffee shop has negligible offerings for breakfast. Restaurant opened while we were there - hopeless service - no drinks after 45 minutes so gave up on them. Dogs and their owners everywhere but taking all the seats so nowhere for hotel guests. Clearly hotel guests are not a priority. Avoid.

title: THE GOLDEN HOUR
text:
new restaurant review for all me' horses out thar!

let me tell you...it was exceptionally good given it was the first day!  

service was splendid my friends 

the chicken - super healthy and fabulous with the salad on side with light gorgonzola 

fries -had a nice touch of old bay 

shrimp - fresh as a daisy in Tennessee

outside and of course, with beautiful bistro chairs 

our first time there, the the unicorn was chomping at the bit....beast.... fermenting wine also is a favorite of mine

happy galloping out there to me'' horses!

title: New York City Charm
text:
Our reservation was not "found" when we tried to check in, even though we had our confirmation info with us. We were sent to "check out the neighborhood" and they would "contact" us when the issue was resolved. I believe they used our paperwork to create a new reservation but at least they took care of the issue. 
We stayed there for 2 days and had a wonderful time. The place is charming, fairly quiet (and we had a street-side room) and the staff was amazing. The amenities...robes, fabulously comfortable beds, umbrellas and bicycles made the experience even better! A fun touch was the set of colored pencils and coloring books about the hotel that were available in the lobby and in your room. The lobby was always fairly full of local people using the free Wi-Fi but there were tables and benches outside for leisure, too. The hotel is pricey but is in a convenient location and well worth a stay!

title: Come for the style, stay for Kim
text: The Highline Hotel has to be New York’s most charming and delightful place to stay. While the rooms are lovely, the beds are comfortable and the neighborhood is perfect; the best part of our stay was having Kim at the front desk. She made our engagement trip truly special and went above and beyond to make sure we were comfortable and happy. The hotel is lucky to have such a wonderful, bright person on staff. After living in NYC for 5 years, there’s nowhere else we would stay when we come back for a visit.

title: Cozy and charming!
text: Loved this place! Not a typical big hotel with the lobby and that is part of the charm.  The lobby is so understated in that it's really a coffee shop/bar with seating areas.  The check in is a person (so friendly!) working on a laptop.  The room was clean, the bed SO comfy, the sheets - crisp, almost like old-school starched white sheets - just wonderful.  The bathroom was really nice, with great toiletries.  I loved that this place is far enough west to be a bit out of the crowds.  Super charming, I would definitely stay here again.

title: Always love it here
text: Travel for work to NYC multiple times a month and am always happy to return to the HLH. The staff is absolutely spectacular and I love the atmosphere of the lobby and rooms. It feels cozy, like a home away from home.

title: I love this gem of a hotel
text:
This is the perfect spot to walk all over Manhattan and particularly Chelsea.  

The staff are delightful and the rooms luxuriously comfortable.  

A real local neighbourhood feel as well. 

And the best barista in town.

title: Beyond Charming
text: Charming, cozy, home... This is what came to mind when i set foot inside The High Line Hotel. Staying in a historic building which retains in original qualities does come with some quirks. Maybe the original wood floors make some noises, but that's okay. Maybe the water pressure could be better, but that's okay. Maybe the rooms are on the smaller side, that's definitely okay at this property. That feeling of being in the comfort of your own home does not come easy when staying in hotels. The High Line achieved this for me. The check in process could be a bit smoother, but room is very limited in the lobby and throughout the hotel. Expect to rub elbows with fellow tourists. I will, without a doubt, be returning.

title: So cute! Easy to get around
text: This place is super cute, lots of charm, and the staff were great. Very clean, pretty spacious rooms for NYC and lots of unique character. I highly recommend to anyone looking to stay in the Chelsea area. While the subway isn't right outside our door, there are a number of lines not far away at all, making it easy to get around just about anywhere in the city.

title: Cozy & Quiet stay in conveniently located fancy hotel!
text:
This place is located in a very convenient spot in Manhatten and though pricey ($200 plus a night), is worth every penny!! They even have a fancy and tasty Intelligentsia coffee cafe inside! Every staff member we met was super generous, kind, and helpful which is rare to find!

My husband and I stayed here at The High Line hotel for our first night ever in NYC. We arrived around 12 pm and walked into the Easter event they were hosting for kids which was fun to see, and although the lobby was busy we were greeted immediately by Nicolas who was so very nice to us. Since we couldn't check in until 3 pm, they offered to hold our bags for us in a locked closet which was soo convenient. That freed us up to go exploring. After a long day we came back around 5 pm and got take out Pho from Omai down the road...so tasty and fresh. Since we were only staying one night, the gentlemen who checked us in kindly upgraded us to a nicer King bedroom, which was so awesome! The room was amazing, very clean, and quiet. The shower/tub was so great and roomy, and the water pressure was heaven. Our room faced the back of the hotel which has a really pretty view and does not face the street, so when it snowed overnight we woke up to everything covered in a blanket of snow. The bed was very comfortable, which was a nice surprise since most hotel beds are hard to sleep in (for me anyway) and the pillows actually functioned like pillows instead of flattening out after 5 seconds. Great room to relax in and to enjoy being in if you have time to spend :-)  Will definitely come back and recommend this hotel to anyone!

title: If you're cool you'll love this place
text: I stay here monthly for work and love it's unique qualities. At the end of a long day, coming back to the hotel feels like returning home. The staff is welcoming and it's a neighborhood fixture. It's in the heart of Chelsea but is quiet which is nice. The architecture is like no other hotel in NYC and it has a kind of refined, eclectic elegance. Love Mike the bartender and Kim at reception.

title: Charming, Comfortable Hotel in Chelsea
text: The High Line Hotel is gorgeous. There is historic charm and detail wherever you look. My husband and I stayed in the Standard Queen room, and it was much more spacious than expected! The room was filled with vintage details that made it feel both luxurious and homey. The room overlooked the front courtyard, but we were never bothered by the quiet buzz of people chatting over coffee and cocktails. We loved spending time sipping Intelligentsia coffee in the quiet back courtyard each morning. It was such a peaceful way to start our busy days in the city. At night, the café converts into a bar and serves delicious cocktails. All of the staff was friendly and helpful. We would definitely stay here again!

title: 3rd Time - As charming as ever !!!
text: My third time staying, this time with family for Easter and could not have been happier.  From the second we came in the greeting was warm and casual.   We were all given wonderful, large rooms ( a request for a special room for my mom was granted -  the 5th floor plus a sitting area that provided a great space for the 5 of us to catch up ! ) The charming decor, fab mini bar/ snack basket - windows that open!... onto a courtyard and  the most comfortable bed ever made the rooms a hit.  Situated steps from the High Line, a few blocks from Chelsea market  - the location was perfect. And the wonderful staff ( thank you Robert for printing boarding passes, tracking down forgotten clothes in closets. sigh ) were always there when you needed them, discreetly.  But there is something else at work here and that is in their overall decision to be a part of their New York neighbourhood.  They chose to have the coolest coffee house in town in town, Intelligentsia instead of a formal lobby.  Smart.   They allow dogs! They welcome local children ( and parents ) to their Annual Easter party!  This meant there was always a local to chat with if you wanted to or a couch to read on.  We never felt like tourists, just a bunch of regulars sipping on our coffees before heading out to do our thing...

title: Location, Room Size and Staff = Excellent
text: This hotel is great, we come to NYC twice a year and this was the first time we stayed at the High line.  It was awesome.  We booked a double room and it was really the largest room I have ever stayed in, except for a suite.  There was a fireplace and 2 closets with a large bath. The hotel is dog friendly, so hanging out downstairs in the morning having a coffee you are greeted by folks bringing dogs.  At night while enjoying a post-evening cocktail there are dogs there as well.  Of course, if you are not interested in petting and cooing over a dog, the owners all have leashes and both owners and animals are well behaved.  The staff are all friendly, ready to help or not.  Whatever your preference.  We will definitely be back.

title: Pleasant surprise.
text: Last minute decision to stay at the High Line.  Informal quick check in, decent size room with great shower.  Hotel is well located outside the bustle of midtown and close to Meat packing and Chelsea Market.  Older property with modern upgrades.

title: Great Old school Vibe
text: This place has everything I am looking for in a NYC hotel. It's a relatively small, old property. It has large rooms (by NYC standards). It has a barista that knows how to make a proper cappuccino and a bartender that makes you feel like a local. The sitting area out front is great on nice days, and you are smack in the middle of a great neighborhood.

title: Bargain Stay...
text:
I arrived after 9.30 pm on a Sunday evening. No one assisted me with my luggage. There was no visible reception desk or staff.

I was upgraded to a Deluxe King rather than the bargain entry level room that I had booked. The room had a vintage theme which i liked. It was interesting compared to some of the sparse hotel rooms that take the modern aesthetic too far.The bed was super large, high and comfortable.

The bathroom was vast and well stocked with even mouthwash. I particularly rate the Marvis toothpaste and CO Bigelow toiletries.

There is no room service and I was not going to venture out to a diner at 10 pm so had to raid the mini bar. At this price point, the lack of food and beverages offerings was disappointing.

title: Very comfortable, nice value, great location
text: This is a very comfortable, relaxed, well managed property. The room was well equipped and cozy. The price was great for New York. Highly recommend. There are excellent restaurants for breakfast within a block or two.

title: Weekend in chelsey
text: love the location.   could walk everywhere, to all the hippest neighbourhoods.   the High Line walkway was across the street-five minute walk to the Whittney, and meat packing distrct.   great neighbourhood for browsing art galleries.  good restaurants nearby, too.   area was quiet and beautiful.  room was adorable.   bathroom was adequate and shower was fine.  coffee bar was convenient in the lobby.  one criticism:  the bed was too soft and the pillows were uncomfortable.  we did not sleep well.  hope that helps.

title: Noisy Location...
text:
I reserved a room at this hotel a month in advance and kindly requested a quiet room facing the courtyard.  A few days prior to my arrival I called to confirm my reservation and was told my special request was in place and should not be an issue.  Upon arrival, I was told this request was not available. No apology was offered and I basically felt like I was in a 'take it or leave it' situation.  I was booked for 3 nights but only stayed one night since my room was on the corner of 10 Ave and 20th which is VERY busy with street noise.  I can certainly understand that a request for a specific room location can not be guaranteed but I was never told this when booking and was in fact lead to believe my request would be honored.  Be very careful if you are seeking quiet serene accommodations as the rooms here make you feel like you are facing a highway, at least on the 10th Ave side of the building.   

I would give the High Line another try if I could get a courtyard facing room but I now know this is not a sure bet when reserving a room which should be made clear.

title: Home away from home.
text: This hotel really does feel like a home away from home - if your home happens to be an incredibly stylish brownstone with the best bar and coffee shop downstairs!  Fantastic hotel filled with fantastic staff. Thank you for an amazing stay.

title: Nice small hotel in Chelsea
text: A great century plus old building that was a former seminary, now a small (60 rooms) hotel.  The Chelsea location right off the High Line (as the name suggests) is great for ready access to lower Manhattan and is much more sedate than Midtown.  The building is very cool and it was a nice reno job.  This is not a full service luxury property, but it also is not priced like one and is a good value.  There is no full service restaurant -- just pastries and espresso for breakfast at the small bar/coffee house that is also the very small lobby.  Still, that type of intimacy is part of the charm.  The room was very comfortable, albeit smallish (typical NY).  It was quiet, with a comfortable bed and good shower.  All in all, I would recommend it for a leisure visitor who wants to stay in a quieter area and get good value (but not necessarily for a business traveller, although I was there on business).

title: Best Hotel in NYC
text: The Highline hotel is a breath of fresh air in Manhattan.  It is a unique and magical property. The rooms are charming and comfortable.  The staff are friendly, knowledgeable and are always available for any needs or questions.  I cannot say enough good things about the Highline Hotel

title: Converted Gothic Seminary in the center of Chelsea's art district.
text: Warm and friendly, this oasis in Chelsea is a deeply calming from the moment your eyes adjust to the low, warm light of the entrance. You are greeted immediately by friendly capable staff and ushered off down long corridors with gothic windows to well and eclectically decorated rooms. The bedrooms have all the comforts you would expect in a top rated hotel with exceptionally comfortable beds.

title: Lovely Chelsea location
text: We chose a larger corner room which was very cozy and light filled.  Only comment about the room location was that it was a warm day and we could hear talking from the garden terrace during the day time (but very quiet at night.)  Very convenient to walk to the High Line, Chelsea Market and the Museum.  Complimentary bikes available during the season with West Side bike trails very close.  The staff was very friendly and cheerful.  I would definitely stay here again.

title: Nice, large room but rodents in lobby
text: The hotel is unique and well-located for visiting Chelsea (though perhaps not super location if on business). The historical feel and the large room were definitely upsides. When I checked out to catch an early flight there were several mice running around the breakfast area. Probably won’t return. Can’t get the squeals out of my head.

title: A Michigan girl on her first visit to NYC
text:
I don't have enough words to describe how great my experience was at The High Line Hotel. The location was incredibly convenient. I was able to walk to the Chelsea market, The High Line, every type of restaurant and bar, and shops without any trouble at all. The hotel itself is unique and interesting. The retro vibe and interior design works without losing quality. The highlight of my time there was the staff. Specifically Christian, Sasha, and Michael. They were all kind and helpful to a clueless girl from Michigan. The restaurant recommendations led us to the best food the area had to offer with minimal effort or research. Christian went out of his way to write down a list and even made a last minute reservation for dinner the first night at the hotel. Michael indulged my love of whiskey and introduced me to a boutique whiskey that has has an accompanying ice ball creator that was worth an entire video recording. 

My next time in the city there is no doubt I'll be visiting again.

title: Lovely hotel
text: I stayed only one night in this lovely hotel but it will definitely become my go-to place in New York from now on.   The rooms are absolutely lovely, the service is very nice.  The team is young and dynamic.  A must!

title: Historical simple elegance with quality features
text: The best place to come back to after a bustling day in NYC!  Quiet, cozy with unique ambiance.  Great location near High Line and easy access to all parts of the city.  Would highly recommend to anyone for a memorable stay.

title: Stuffy, musty, out of date, but trying way too hard to be current. Confusing!!!
text:
I had a room that felt like a musty old closet from 100 years ago. This is supposed to be a hip, trend setting place, but it's a frumpy, old dump.
The front desk staff was very courteous, but this didn't make up for the room.
I had requested an accessible room and there is no way it was accessible. I checked out early, but they would only refund part of my stay. Very bad!!!

title: My "home" when in Chelsea NYC
text: I love how this property and it's staff does hospitality!  I visited the High Line Hotel again this weekend, and (as has been my past experience)  received a warm, friendly and efficient welcoming.  I also felt that my patronage was well appreciated.   The room was immaculate and well appointed.  The staff very friendly.

title: Perfect location for the High Line and exploring Chelsea
text: Great location (very close to the wonderful High Line, and the Chelsea Market). Smaller room than expected (for the price), with a very small shower room. Large comfortable bed (but only enough room for a bedside table on one side). Nice view from the room out back (residential space & gardens, quiet). Limited facilities for a premium hotel: no breakfast (though the coffee bar concession is great), and limited public spaces (apart from the entrance lobby which isn't big, and the gardens which would be great in summer but obviously not usable in mid-winter). Friendly & helpful staff. Would stay again, though I'd be more inclined to return if the hotel re-assigned some its meeting/conference/banquet space for general use by hotel residents.

title: All the character
text:
What a charming hotel! When traveling on business I like to feel relaxed by the atmosphere of the place, but I also want it to feel a bit "different". This checked those boxes. Why was I so delighted by the old fashioned embosser on the table!? Totally embossed myself a bookmark which I'm currently using. I've said it before and I'll say it again... it is ALL in the details! 

Full disclosure I was traveling on the expense account so I can't speak to price.

title: Great stay!
text: We had a great time, nice location, super friendly staff and character in the rooms.  The gym pass to Equinox was fantastic.  Really felt like the staff would go out of their way to help us.  Bar was cosy but expensive.  Definitely recommend it.

title: We ❤️ The High Line Hotel
text: This is our 2nd stay at The High Line Hotel and like a fine wine it gets better with time. The rooms are lovely decorated, the beds are sooo comfy and it’s very clean. The locatation is great, 2 blocks from a Sub station and in trendy, smart Chelsea, only a few blocks from Chelsea Market. Loads of choice to eat locally. Coffee house Intellegentsia is in the lobby during the day and has a great atmosphere with tourists and locals enjoying the fine choice of hot drinks, some also bring their dogs, which to me makes this hotel even more unique and cosy! The staff at the hotel are great, so friendly and helpful. Rosalie checked us in and is lovely, Chris on front desk was also so helpful and a great guy, Tenzin is the happiest guy alive and is a great Bell man, along with Javar. In the evening the coffee bar opens up as a cocktail/drinks bar. Mike runs this and is amazing. His drinks are incredible, much like his personality. Visiting him is a must in our opinion, great drinks and conversation to be had in the this cosy lobby. So all in all don’t miss out on this little gem in the big city.

title: Charming Hotel
text: We loved our stay at the High Line Hotel for Christmas. The decorated trees on the patio were very welcoming, the coloring books entertaining and the umbrellas in the lobby just what we needed on a rainy day. The staff was super attentive and friendly, Kim and Alvin made sure we had a very pleasant stay and an efficient check in and out. I particularly enjoyed the size of the room and bathroom, the linens and the cozy feeling robes.

title: Darling Hotel in Chelsea
text: This just became my new favorite hotel in New York City!  It's absolutely charming from the lobby to the rooms.  The lobby has a great coffee shop that locals stop in every morning for their morning coffee.  The rooms are charming and outfitted with a sweet fireplace and old books artfully arranged. This is my new go-to hotel.

title: Beautiful hotel
text: I stay at The Highline Hotel for business regularly and recently took my family there for a Christmas shopping trip.  The Highline is always very comfortable, amazing staff, great room. This is definitely a boutique hotel so so not come expecting it to be.  The lobby is tiny, there is no room service or anything like that. Small coffee shop that attracts a lot of locals and their dogs.  I stay here whenever I'm in Manhattan, love the hotel and love the Chelsea neighborhood. Can't go wrong with The Highline.

title: Ms
text: I stay in NYC often for work and always try to stay at the Highline Hotel. During the holidays it is particularly wonderful and the staff and team do an excellent job! The lobby and outdoor space is beautiful.

title: Upscale Boho
text: This hotel has it all: charm, great staff, historical building, and great location. The Chelsea Market, the HIghline Park/Walk, and many great restaurants and galleries are just steps away. The hotel is in a former seminary and has many great architectural touches.

title: Disappointing
text:
was really excited to stay at this hotel. The vibe of an older property and a firmer seminary seemed very cool. 

The reality was disappointing. The lobby is tiny. Filled with locals morning until night drinking coffee and talking/working on laptops. Everyone brings their dogs and strollers and just hangs out all day. Very cool for a coffee shop. Very frustrating for a hotel Guest. I literally could never find a place to sit in the lobby. And had to step over strollers dogs and children to get in and out of the front door. 

The only reason I gave two stars Is that the staff is friendly and helpful. 

I definitely don't recommend. For

title: High marks for The High Line Hotel
text: This is a stunning hotel and as different as you can get from your cookie cutter New York hotel.   So much history and a fabulous team who will look after you.   Coming to New York - look no further.   With only about 60 rooms it is intimate and cozy.   A must do...

title: Christmas in New York!
text: My wife and I stayed at High Line Hotel for the first time last weekend - Friday/Saturday for a weekend away to enjoy NYC - this hotel is great. We chose it because we’d been to a wedding at the hotel - such an excellent space for weddings!  Wonderful boutique oasis in great location with easygoing great service.

title: Charming and quiet
text: Quirky hotel that’s a nice alternative to the corporate cookie cutter. Our 4th floor room facing the courtyard was dead quiet.  As others have noted, things can be a bit worn around the edges. For some, it may seem a tad shabby, but for others (like us) it simply adds to the sense of history and charm. Great location and a great place to stay if you are a dog-lover, as the lobby is quite the gathering spot for local hounds.  Very friendly and helpful staff. We would definitely stay again.

title: Great character & history, but still older.
text:
Pros: Great history & character, in a quieter part of Chelsea, near the Highline and Chelsea Market. 
Cons: Lobby always very crowded, property is a renovated dormitory so rooms and VERY small, lobby/rooms are outdated. 

We had a nice stay here. The rooms were extremely small and the lobby is always crowded with people (their coffee bar is very famous!). Comfy bed. Relatively quiet for a NYC hotel. Great outdoor space and coffee bar turns into a bar at night. If you are looking for a charming hotel that is different from the typical NYC-style stay you might like it here. It was a fine hotel but we won't stay here again.

title: Chic boutique hotel in a great neighborhood!
text: We love the Intelligencia coffee every morning and lounging in their lobby. The hotel was so comfortable and cozy. The rooms are small but that's expected for NYC. And, although they are small my husband and I thought the rooms were very comfortable and the bed was great! The staff was very friendly and welcoming as well. This hotel is also dog-friendly!

title: Charming, comfortable hotel!
text:
We were delighted with our stay at the High Line Hotel.  In a city filled with minimalist, post modern hotel rooms, it’s refreshing to stay at this hotel, which is in a re-purposed seminary.  Our room, which overlooked a courtyard, was impeccably clean, spacious, quiet and comfortable, with crisp white linens on the bed.  And the black out curtains totally eliminated any ambient light which could have disrupted a good night’s sleep.  Initially we were concerned about our room’s location next to the elevator, but we heard no noise, probably because the old building was so solidly constructed. So we woke up refreshed and ready to explore the charming Chelsea neighborhood.

Although there is no restaurant in the hotel, delicious coffee and pastries are available in the lobby.  (In the evenings, the coffee area becomes a bar).  The hotel is an easy walk to lots of great eateries, the Chelsea Market, and of course, the High Line.

All of the staff members we encountered were unfailingly friendly and helpful.

We look forward to our next visit!

title: excellent time
text: The room was comfortable and service was impeccable.   We loved the mood of the front lobby and found everyone who worked there to be very helpful.   We found the whole experience to be an excellent one and would go back.

title: Like visiting Great Aunt Mabel...
text:
The Highline Hotel, a former seminary located in Chelsea, the heart of the Art gallery area, is a charming and quirky place to stay. It’s kind of like staying at your Great Aunt Mabel’s Brooklyn brownstone, not  for everyone but quite up my alley. My room facing the lovely courtyard festooned for the season with bales of hay and heaps of pumpkins, featured ebony stained wood floors, a bricked up fireplace with a mantle full of old books and bric a brac, a threadbare oriental rug, granny type furnishings, and a rotary dial phone but with all the contemporary must haves like a good minibar, flatscreen, WiFi and safe. The bed was a bit saggy and my sheets had small rips, not so good.
My biggest gripe was the bathroom which featured a small pedestal sink and no shelf for toiletries, and no magnifying mirror. The toilet paper holder broke. The closet wasn’t lighted either. Please, Aunt Mabel, you can do better on these important details!
The charming small entryway suffers from the popularity of the coffee bar which means that it is overflowing with locals cozily settling into every nook and cranny with their latte, computer and canine companion. I could barely squeeze out the door at some times of the day.
In spite of these details that do not quite work, I enjoyed my stay. It provided a cozy and welcome respite from the energy of the city.

title: Very unique and lovely!
text: Stayed here on first-ever Macy's Parade visit and loved it.  Great room, lots of history.  Wish we could have seen the refrectory but it wasn't open.  Great little coffee shop in the lobby.  Right outside High Line Park in Chelsea.

title: Great experience
text:
My wife and I spent a long weekend at The High Line Hotel for our anniversary. I’ve never stayed anywhere like it: a low-rise boutique in New York City, where the hotel’s peers in price and service are high-rise chains; decor that’s soulful and thought-out, not corporate focus-grouped; staff that’s friendly and natural, attentive but unobtrusive. 

I tend not to need or want anything more than a clean room that doesn’t smell weird at a hotel that’s in a decent part of town, but this place overcame my prejudices against places that offer more - in this case, much more. Our suite was the most compelling hotel room I’ve ever stayed in, from the art on the walls to the unique layout of the space. I even noticed fixtures and molding and other little details I never pay attention to.

My only regrets are that I didn’t get to explore the halls more or get a drink at the bar in the lobby.

All’s to say: if you’re looking to spend a bit for a special occasion, go here.

title: We loved the Highline Hotel
text: We had a wonderful stay at the High Line hotel. It’s beautiful and unique. Great outdoor space (large spacious garden patio with festive pumpkin decorations). Beautiful decor in the lobby (which doubles as a cool bar/coffee shop with oriental rugs and nice lighting) and in our room. Great block with restaurants and easy high line access. We will definitely come back here next time in nyc.

title: High quality at the High Line
text:
I recently traveled to NYC with my senior mom.  I chose this hotel for its proximity to the High Line, a destination I was eager to see.

At check-in, on a Friday afternoon, the lobby and courtyard were packed.  The first comment my mom made was "This is a 'young' hotel."  And it's true, it did feel a little hip for a traditional hotel.  The small lobby with funky-cool decor and old typewriters has a daytime coffee bar that converts to a bar in the evenings and there are bespoke bikes available to borrow for hotel guests.

There is no restaurant in the hotel or associated with it, so it's just the coffee bar with a few pastries (but no bagels!) for food options.  There is a popular restaurant next door that had an hour-long wait Friday evening and a 30 minute wait for Saturday brunch.  We skipped the hour wait for dinner, but did stick it out for the brunch and thought it very good.  The room also came generously stocked with a tray full of snacks and a fridge full of drinks, all for the typical price for such conveniences.  But there is a bodega just a block and a half away where you can get less expensive versions of the same things.

According to the website and the staff we talked to, this hotel used to be dorms for the adjacent seminary.  The layout seems to jive with that.  We were on the third floor very near the elevator, which made me anxious, but I honestly never heard or was annoyed by hallway noises.  Likewise, I did not hear noises from the next rooms either.

The air conditioner in our room was on the fritz, but the hotel staff acted quickly to remediate it.  The hotel was full that evening, but they offered to move us to another room the next day.  We ended up staying in the original room (our choice) after they installed a window unit.

To note: there is a city bus stop nearby, but the nearest subway stop is several blocks away.  We ended up hailing cabs for most excursions, which wasn't the cheapest option, but certainly made things easier for my senior mom.  And this hotel may not be 100% accessible, as there were a few steps down into the hotel lobby and I didn't notice an alternate entrance or ramp.

The hotel was very nice and generally quiet, and the staff eager to help.  The bed was comfortable, too.  The proximity to the High Line was great (and the room even had a beautiful book all about the High Line).  I would stay here again, but not with a senior companion.

title: Ideal place to celebrate a special event
text: Booked three rooms to celebrate a family birthday. What an ideal location to enjoy family and mark the passing of a special occasion. Could not imagine a more beautiful, relaxing, accommodating hotel.

title: Favorite Hotel in NYC
text:
I travel to NYC once a month for work... There is absolutely no other place I would stay in the city.  Low key, chic and fantastic location.  The staff is great.  The rooms are eclectic, tasteful, comfortable and set a lovely tone.  Great local hangout as well.  Dog friendly and wonderful morning coffee bar, that morphs into a cool bar in the evenings.

Such a breath of fresh air in juxtaposition to the bustling, corporate hotels... Cannot recommend more highly!

title: Excellent property with great staff; wish they had on site dining option
text: Amazing and unique property. Lovely room with high end amenities. Only shortcoming is lack of food. I arrived late and was hungry but there were no dining options. I had a good coffee in the morning but would have appreciated a full breakfast.

title: 5 star quality service
text: The quaintness and attention to detail of this hotel is really what charms a person to stay at the High Line Hotel. The staff and the service is what keeps you coming back. David and Daquan, you guys were the absolute best and made my boyfriend's birthday one to remember. You both went above and beyond to make our stay impeccable. Your accommodations were perfect with a front view room and adorable rotary phone. LOVED IT! Highly recommend this hotel and definitely name drop this duo when you go, they are the best!

title: Very nice boutique hotel in a great location
text:
Corporate meeting services booked me here for an event.  The lobby is a bit odd in that it's more of a coffee shop with a small spot to check in.  The room was a nice surprise in that it had a very nice updated bath and a super comfortable bed.  My room, #46, looked out over a side courtyard and it was very quiet.  The wood floor looks original and is painted, with vintage worn persian style rugs.  Here is a pic from another traveler if my room.

https://www.tripadvisor.com/Hotel_Review-g60763-d4283443-Reviews-The_High_Line_Hotel-New_York_City_New_York.html#photos;geo=60763&detail=4283443&ff=283369007&albumViewMode=hero&aggregationId=101&albumid=101&baseMediaId=283369007&thumbnailMinWidth=50&cnt=30&offset=-4&filter=2&autoplay=

From the room map on the door my room was a bit larger than average.  Staff was very friendly and helpful.  Nice stay.

title: A True Gem in Chelsea
text:
Trying to find a unique property in any unfamiliar location can be challenging, especially when you are relying on the internet. Couple that with very strict requirements and expectations may leave you with virtually no options. I contacted The High Line Hotel through their contact link on their website and received my first response very timely. From that moment forward, no matter my request or question, I was never left without an answer. 

I would like to mention a few people that helped me make my 2-day event perfect: 
Madeline Aguiar - Sr. Sales Manager; Tara Lissade - Director of Special Events Sales; David Quins - Front Office Manager and Andy Patel - Director of Special Events Operations

My expectations would not have been met without this team and their extremely professional staff. 

The Hotel: Location is not in the chaos of areas like Times Square. It's in quaint and lovely Chelsea. You can grab a taxi from any of the three major airports (LGA, EWR, JFK) and get to the property. It's within walking distance of the Chelsea Market which is a food emporium along with some shopping. It's steps away from the High Line, which is a wonderful 1.45 mile elevated walking park that is created on the former NY Central Railroad. I encourage you to look up the history of the building - you will be amazed. One of the most amazing facts is that the story 'Twas the Night Before Christmas was written at the High Line Hotel. I understand Christmas is extra special and the decorations are spectacular. I was here in the fall and there was over 800 gourds and pumpkins of every size decorating the property - it was just lovely. The exterior and interior is extra special. If you love historic, wonderful, charming and a boutique style - this is the place for you. Pick up a book or two, sit in the front courtyard or back courtyard and have a cup of coffee or a cocktail and just enjoy the scenery. Note: the restaurant was closed for the season.

The Room: There are only 60 and they are spacious - not at all what you would think for NY. The beds are to die for and pure charm is oozing from the wooden floors to the old fireplace (no, they don't work) to the windows to furnishings. Again, plenty of reading material if you are a book person. I had plenty of closet space (two closets in fact). The bathroom was roomy with plenty of towels and toiletries. If you are concerned with the lighting (too dark), take note - the wall switches all have dimmers - you can adjust as needed. The only negative that I have to mention is the bathroom shade was broken (in the down position) and it was stained. I was actually quite surprised by this. The furnishings have some paint chips and dents but this IS NOT a negative - this adds to the look and feel of being in a building that was completed in 1895 (originally a seminary and a portion of the building still is - again, look up the history or ask someone at the hotel).

My reason for being in NY was for business. I planned a sit down plated dinner for 36 at this property with a bar set up outside of the room we ate in. I also had a breakfast, lunch and snack the next day along with an all-day meeting. The rooms were set up exactly as I needed and a special mention to Andy who saved the day by finding me the right connection to their video equipment. Service on all levels at this property was outstanding. 

It won't matter why you need to come to NY. I encourage you to book at The High Line Hotel - you will not be disappointed! Remember, everything is a walk or a taxi away.

Safe travels!

title: Still a great choice in Chelsea
text:
We recently stayed at the High Line Hotel for a second weekend. The location can't be beat--right off the High Line park, and very close to great galleries and restaurants in Chelsea.

If you haven't researched it yet, the High Line Hotel is built in part of the old Episcopal Seminary building (another part of the same building is still active as a seminary). The rooms are quite spacious, especially for New York. On this visit, we had a standard room which was quite large. There was plenty of room for a king sized bed, a small sofa and sitting chair with a coffee table, and a small desk. Because the guest rooms were created from seminary rooms, the proportions can be odd but this really adds to the charm, in my opinion. Our room happened to be at ground level, right on the corner of 10th Ave and 21st St. I was worried about traffic noise but they must have triple-paned windows because we heard nothing from the street. In addition, they have heavy velvet drapes which also block our light and sound. In fact, the only issue we had with sound was hearing the thumping bass from a wedding party occurring elsewhere in the hotel.

The hotel has two courtyards--one on the exterior of the building, where there are cafe tables and an Intelligentsia Coffee truck, and another on the interior of the building with built in benches. Many neighborhood residents come here for the coffee and the wifi, often bringing their dogs. The whole hotel is dog-friendly, even offering a bowl of treats by the door.

We really love this place and will come back again. Not the cheapest place but definitely high quality and friendly.

title: Noisy and bright
text: This was our second stay at this Hotel.  Our room was excessively noisy.  Every clink from the cafe, voices in the lobby and hall seemed to be amplified.   The street light came in making the room too bright at night ( despite closing the curtains).  No hair dryer.  Very uncomfortable pillows.  As soon as the cafe started getting ready for business, the smell of coffee was strong in the room.  Should not be a full priced room with all the inconveniences.   Very disappointed.

title: Wonderful
text:
Not the cheapest hotel in NYC but well worth a stay, the attention to detail and little touches are wonderful.  Comfiest bed ever and a fab mini bar ! We borrowed bikes (free) and cycled up and down the waterfront 
 Great bar too and friendly staff.

title: Lovely place
text:
Great location, great staff. It's nice and quiet, but also cozy and friendly. The rooms are quite big compared to others in the area, and the beds are very comfortable. There are two great patios that are nice to work at, or just hangout and grab a coffee in the morning, a drink at night. It's close to Chelsea market, The Highline, Soul Cycle, Equinox, restaurants, and plenty of other walkable spots.

I also forgot an item of clothing in the closet, and they shipped it to me! Really wonderful hotel, highly recommend!

title: Didn't want to leave
text: By far, my favourite NY hotel. Great location, great staff, great room. I especially enjoyed the outside area and using the Equinox gym nearby which was spectacular in and of itself. Will try and be back here asap!

title: unexpectedly great
text: I booked a room at the High Line Hotel because of the location. I was pleasantly surprised by how great the hotel is. Super always friendly helpful staff. Clean, well stocked room that felt like a room in someones home rather than a hotel. The outside terrace and bar are fun, the neighbourhood is great.

title: Amazing Hotel
text: Once again this Hotel gem delivers an amazing New York experience. This hotel is perfectly situated in Chelsea with lots of nice restaurants close by. The staff are very friendly and I fell welcome every time I check in. Housekeeping made an excellent job in keeping my room shipshape.

title: Quaint hotel with some rough edges
text:
The High Line Hotel is very neat.  It's in an old church and has a lot of character.  Old wooden floors, an old elevator with a door that closes to operate, an old working rotary phone in the room.  Neat.  The rooms are large (not New York large, large by any measure).  The water pressure was amazing. There is a nice courtyard in front of the hotel and a very comfortable lobby inside.  There is coffee most all day and cocktails with a full bar at night to be enjoyed in either location.  We wanted to love the High Line, but didn't.  

What we didn't like is that the High Line is rough in too many areas.  The linens are poor quality and the mattress even worse.  The mattress had sunken spots, so the solution was a thick comforter under the bottom sheet.  The bed was one of the worst I've ever slept on and the combination of the duvet on top and the bulk underneath was awful  The rug in our room was worn through due to foot traffic/vacuum/etc.  The bathroom, while nice, had a gouge in the toilet lid and poor caulk work.  The furniture has rub marks on virtually every edge (even the newer furniture).  Our overall impression was that the High Line missed great by just a little more invested in the maintenance and renovation.

title: A step above the ordinary
text:
As a frequent traveler, the grind of being on the road can take its toll.  Waking up day after day after day in a hotel room can be draining.  Not so with the High Line Hotel.  I’ve stayed here on multiple occasions from 1-2 nights to as many as 8 nights.  From my very first visit, the staff was warm and welcoming.  It feels like you’re at your favorite aunt’s house not a hotel in the middle of a bustling city. 

The lobby and patio as the perfect place to sit and unwind after a grueling day walking the city or crunching number while sitting behind a desk.  The rooms are quaint in keeping with the era of the building and have just the right amenities.  The Intelligentsia coffee bar in the lobby with breakfast treats converts to a bar in the evenings - just the right ambiance for a quiet drink or nightcap.   

And for those of you looking for more to do...steps away you can find world class dining, shopping, views, bars and nightlife. 

I highly recommend The High Line Hotel to anyone looking for a step above the ordinary in NY.

title: Nice find in NYC
text: From the moment I arrived, the staff was incredible friendly and helpful. I loved the vibe in the lobby as it's more like a cool coffee shop and the outdoor courtyard was great for working in the sun. I would definitely stay here again!

title: Second visit still a wonderful hotel
text: We arrived just after midnight from a long international  flight.  Our welcome was quick and efficient plus made even better by getting an upgrade.  The hotel is very central to all of Chelsea and lower west side. Staff are very good and went beyond expectations at times. Rooms have a huge advantage the windows open!  There is a pleasant courtyard at the back of the hotel.  Air conditioning very efficient.

title: In the middle of Chelsea
text:
An old seminary, now a botique Hotel with vintage rooms. By vintage, I mean comfortable with nostalgia.
The staff was very accommodating and pointed out the lay of the land, with recommendations for sights and restaurants. 
Very quiet for having a Main Street in front. 
Good coffee shop/bar in the front 
Dog friendly

title: Beautiful Hotel, Drunk on Happiness
text: Took my 6 yr old daughter to NYC for a girls’ trip. With so many choices in NY, it’s hard to narrow down to a few choices. Ultimately picked here because of the beautiful design overall (not your cookie cutter hotel), the location (close to metro, the High Line, Chelsea Market...) and can’t beat great espresso served in the hotel lobby. They gave my daughter the cutest coloring books while visiting (a book full of NYC highlights and the other one was full of things you see while staying at The High Line Hotel). My daughter was literally drunk on happiness during our stay. The photos say it all.

title: Amazing service
text: This was my first time staying at The High Line Hotel and I loved it - so personal and the staff always went above in beyond. At checkout the bellman helped me arrange a car because he knew I'd be cutting it close on timing to the airport - and when I arrived back to the hotel after my meetings to gather my bags, slightly frantic, not only was my car waiting, but he had already packed all my bags in the car and was watching them for me - knowing I'd be racing back. Loved this place and looking forward to my next visit - it was much quieter than hotels I'd stay at in the past. The outdoor spaces are beautiful too!

title: Be picky about your room assignment
text:
If you are assigned room 51, turn around and check out immediately. It has to be one of the worst rooms in the entire building. While it's on the top floor, the room is located directly across from the incredibly loud elevator and is facing 10th Ave, which sounds like a highway no matter what time it is. Even though the room has double-paned glass windows, the traffic noise sounds like the windows are wide open. The hotel does not proactively provide earplugs (only when asked), which are basically required if you are looking to get any sleep in room 51. Earplugs should be given by default to all rooms, or at least all rooms facing 10th! Additionally, I was not told about the free guest pass to Equinox during my stay nor were we given slippers in our room. During our 2nd and 3rd nights, housekeeping removed the rug towel in the bathroom and never replaced it. Room 51 also has a tiny bathroom, but a large, walk-in closet.

Each room comes with a bluetooth speaker but the one in room 51 had a broken USB cable and didn't charge. I had to use the USB cable I brought to charge it. Additionally, all the power outlets are old and awful, all my chargers fell out of the outlets! (for Macbook, iPhone, etc)

I stayed here during NYFW so the place was sold out (as were the rest of the hotels in NYC), but I was finally able to move rooms for my 4th & 5th nights, to room 56 which is FANTASTIC by comparison. Room 56 has a spacious bathroom and a small closet. It is silent at night because it's not facing a busy street. This marginally redeemed my stay here.

If you value sleep and rest, demand a room facing the courtyard and refuse to stay in anything facing 10th ave or a room on the 1st floor. If they can't accommodate you, go elsewhere.

title: FantasticDog Friendly Stay in the City!
text:
We stayed at the High-Line Hotel in the midst of a cross country trip that included 25+ states...The High-Line Hotel was one of the few memorable stays we had along the way.
The High-Line was a totally chill place to stay with dogs ...a great location and fantastic outdoor space, but dogs are welcome to hang-out indoors as well. Overall the hotel could not have been more dog friendly!

title: Another great weekend staying at The High Line Hotel in Chelsea.
text:
Another great weekend staying at The High Line Hotel in Chelsea. The building, a former seminary, is beautiful and they have converted it into a hotel in the best possible way. Architectural details have been preserved and restored, with minimal replacement of features. The rooms feel like someone walked out 90 years ago and they've just made the room up fresh for you. Beds are cushy-comfy, and while our room had lots of natural light, the curtains were ample to accommodate sleeping in late. 

The decor is very cool, lots of period items sourced. There is a fabulous coffee bar in the lobby, which transitions to a small bar at night. We didn't try the bar, but the coffee was really wonderful. Open patio front and back - quieter to the rear, more energetic to the front. 

No room service, but plenty of food in the immediate area. [Highly recommend Juban for Japanese less than 2 blocks away.] 

Service is exemplary in all areas.

If you are going to consider this hotel, the suites are lovely, but not created equal. We've now seen all the suites (rooms 1 through 5) and you will want 1, 2 , 3 , or 4. Room 5 MUCH smaller and not worth it. Go for a regular room instead.

title: Great Boutique Hotel Experience
text:
This hotel has it all when it comes to a boutique experience.  It's a small original building that makes you feel in another era.  The rooms are beautifully decorated and hace details covered when it comes to comfort and equipment. The smell of Lobby is of fresh coffee and there is a continuous traffic of interesting people.  The location is close to perfect since you are walking distance from many attractions of Manhattan: HighLine, Hudson, FlatIron, Meatpacking & West Village.  

You get access to Equinox

title: Vida de cão
text: O hotel recebe cães e donos em seu café. Contei mais de 10 cães em uma tarde. O ambiente fica marcante. Não recomendo para alérgicos . Quartos grandes e antigos, precisam de manutenção. Pena, tão perto do Market !

title: Great little garden area for relaxing coffee stop
text: We stopped to get some Intelligentsia coffee to enjoy sitting in the garden area of the High Line Hotel. Delicious coffee and cool garden area tucked away off the street near the High Line. Plenty of seating and wifi. We were able to use the restroom inside the hotel. The hotel itself looks renovated and historic. It might be an interesting place to stay. It was busy inside the lobby area. I recommend stopping for your coffee in the garden area. I had iced chai tea. It tasted wonderful on a warm, sunny day!

title: Mix feelings : nice garden but noisy, limited and inefficient service
text: Just arrived from Europe: jet lag but not really possible to take a nap as our room is just beside the very noisy entrance hall on the ground floor and obviously above the laundry. Not possible to change they said. Hope the bar is closing at night otherwise it is going to be hell tonight. They alleged that they upgraded us from standard to de luxe! Excellent bedding and good location though for visiting the art galleries (purpose of our visit) and free rental bike but much too expensive for the room and the very limited service.

title: bonne expérience
text: très bon rapport qualité prix; bien placé, près de la high line, chambres spacieuses, propres, jolies; l'hôtel est un ancien couvent; personnel charmant mais pas toujours efficace à part les managers. très bruyant cela dit;

title: Chambre sur jardin
text:
Nous sommes arrivés aujourd'hui dans cet 
HOTEL que nous apprécions et ou nous venons régulièrement depuis son ouverture !!!
Nous réservons toujours une chambre côté jardin la 10eme avenue étant trop bruyante
et sur ce côté nous ne pouvons pas dormir
Nous sommes très déçus car nous avons une chambre côté avenue !!'!!!
La réception devant nos protestations nous  
à assuré que nous aurions demain une garden' room
Attendons pour voir !!!! Mais ce n'est pas sérieux

title: Amazing Hotel
text: Don't tell everyone...keep it a hidden gem. I love the cozy rooms. The food at the wedding in the hotel was soooooo delicious, and looked like artwork.  I want to have my wedding there just for the food. lol

title: Best Hotel Experience in NYC -- Hands Down!!!
text:
I've been traveling to NYC over the past 30 years for both leisure and business.  Far and away, the High Line Hotel was the best hotel experience that I have encountered from the high end (Plaza) to the swanky (Gansevoort) to the usual suspects in mid-town...The High Line Hotel has them all beat.

The High Line blends the perfect amount of comfort with hip.  It's relaxed vibe lets you steal a slice of peace and quiet in one of the best cities in the world - and with loads of luxury touches along the way.  

The staff is attentive and seems to genuinely care that you're getting what you're looking for.  Having just dropped our youngest off at college, the person at the desk immediately recognized our fragile state as newly hatched "empty nesters".  So a round of cocktails "on-the-house" got our new adventure started off on the right foot.

Rooms were beautifully appointed.  The craft coffee is a brilliant way to meet the day.  And the Hotel's neighborhood bar allows you to kick back with a cocktail (or 2) to finish your day.  This is now my "go-to" hotel when visiting NYC.

To the staff and management: Thank you for your incredible hospitality!  See you soon.

title: Vale la pena parar para picar algo!
text: Hermoso lugar, bien estilo americano, se come muy rico, hay algunos platos, pero bien para picar, (el pan está tremendo!) en verano comer afuera es una realmente hermosa parada! La atención es inmejorable!

title: A great hotel on the High Line
text: I love the low key vibe of this hotel. If you are looking for modern groovy music pounding hotel this is not your spot. However if you are looking for a hotel that wears its style in a much more mellow, old style way then this would be your place to stay. It has that vibe of being your wealthy great grandparents city place with a hipster/Chelsea vibe thrown into the mix.

title: My favorite NYC home away from home
text: I have been staying here for the last 2 years for business travel, a few times a year. It's become my go-to favorite hotel in the Chelsea/Meatpacking area. Rooms are charming, clean and cozy - filled with character and well-designed details like beautiful Arts and Crafts wallpaper, fireplaces, and plants. The rooms feel homey, but in an elevated, chic way. The lobby is gorgeous, and the Intelligentsia coffee bar in the morning turns over to a cozy cocktail bar in the evening (complete with great prices on bottles of Veuve). It's dog friendly, and the staff is always welcoming and helpful. I also love how close it is to the high line, and the west side waterfront - great for running on the river, or walking the high line at night. Lastly, there's no gym in premises, but that means access to the Equinox a couple of blocks away (way better than a tiny hotel gym in my book).

title: The Wonderful High Line Hotel - Great Boutique Hotel in Chelsea (NYC) !
text: Wonderful Hotel !  This is my second time to the High Line Hotel.  The firs time I was there with my family for a vacation in NYC.  This last time I was in NYC for less than 24hrs for business.  Both times, coming to the High Line Hotel, felt like staying at a friend's (very nice) apartment, with all the amenities I'd expect from a high-end boutique hotel.  The building and grounds are amazing, very hip decor, wonderful garden cafe and in a great neighborhood.  I typically stay at large chain hotels - not anymore when I visit Manhattan.  I'm a big fan of the High Line !

title: Finally a NY hotel I love
text: I had always heard High Line was great. I've been keeping an eye on prices and finally got a great deal. Loved every minute of it. Big, gracious rooms. Lovely outside space. Good bar/coffee downstairs. Perfect neighborhood. Would love to stay every time I'm in NY.

title: A little bit of home
text: This hotel was great! I stayed here for 2 nights while moving houses and it felt super homey. The service was good, the food was good, the little cafe down the bottom was charming. I will say that the room was a little small but it was well appointed so I didn't really notice. Would definitely stay here again.

title: Good atmosphere and great neighbourhood
text:
We had a very pleasant one week stay at the hotel. The hotel is very charming and the people there are very helpful and nice. For our purposes the location was great with easy access to some interesting places and sights. We have a dog and liking them is definitely an advantage at this pet friendly hotel. There are many coming in an out but it is still calm and clean.
