The rooms were not that great. We had a suite and a deluxe room and I would say the latter was the better room. We stayed in room no. 5 which has its charm but leaves a bit to be desired in terms of bathroom, storage space and the lay-out in general. 

I recommend the hotel and would also go back but the rooms would need an upgrade for the 5 star rating.

title: "Buyer beware" You can get a terrible room.
text:
At first approach to the building you may think to yourself this is not such a pretty hotel from the outside. It is directly across from a parking lot, and the outside looks kind of "usual," but when you step through the gates your entire view changes. There is a wonderful courtyard with benches and places to sit and relax. The check in area is strange. You walk in the door and there is a person standing there with a computer right next to the bar, and that is the check in. It feels weird but the staff is very nice and you will be on your way rather quickly. The room was large and my bed was very comfortable.  There was a very good HVAC system, and the bathroom was very nice as well, with great water pressure in the shower. The towels were upscale, which I particularly enjoy. Room was decorated in an antique way and very nice. I also have to mention there were plenty of outlets. 

So why the bad review? There are a few rooms that are on the first floor, directly across from the bar and because I checked in late, I was unlucky enough to get one of these rooms. They tried to bill it as an upgrade, but this was far from the truth. The room is absolutely terrible because you can hear absolutely everything from the person checking in guests, to the bar tender clanking glasses while he fills them or cleans them. Now this went on till about 11:30pm when it closed, but that bar turned into a coffee bar in the morning that they started setting up at 6am, so the noise started all over again. So basically you can only sleep between those hours. They try to compensate by placing a large air purifier in the room to create a white noise mask, which actually works slightly. They really should not sell these rooms because they make it impossible for e to recommend this hotel to anyone.

title: Hip vibe
text: high ceiling, large room. great location if you're going to the Javits center it's one straight road direct. Love the old architecture! It was the last place I spent with a dear friend and he is photographed here using a retro phone.

title: Already booked it again--
text: Stayed here while helping my daughter move in to her new place a block away.  What a great introduction to the neighborhood--and a relaxing room to decompress in.  Wonderful building, decor, and staff--bringing husband and son/girlfriend back for a visit this Fall.

title: A beautiful gem in Chelsea!
text: An authentic experience from every angle.  Friendly helpful staff..... amazing antique décor..... comfortable bed...... immaculate..... felt like home.  We have travelled the world and don't typically write reviews as we believe travel experiences are unique to the individual.  But this place left us feeling so happy we couldn't resist telling you all about it.  The courtyard is attractive and it was a nice quiet reprieve from the typical NY hustle.

title: Hold on -- am I this cool?
text:
While the kids were at sleep-away camp we escaped to NYC with another couple for the weekend.  Having never been in Chelsea, we weren't sure what we'd find.  The weekend was great, and the High Line Hotel played a central role.  

Location: perfection across the street from the High Line and Cookshop (eat there morning, noon, and night).  Walk the High Line a mile south and you are in the Meatpacking District or the East Village.  

Service: impressive.  I read about the High LIne Hotel's non traditional check-in and was worried.  True, there isn't any "front desk" but there were always staff people in the lobby area eager to help.  We arrived early, the staff bought us coffee and later delivered our bags straight to our room.  

Location and service are standard expectations.  The hotel itself is what sets it apart.  Lovingly restored, the hotel has the modern necessities - high-thread count sheets, docking station, flatscreen, central air - but it also has period furniture, a rotary phone, well-worn oriental rugs, and many other details that remind you are staying a place older than yourself.  I hope you are supposed to take a few High Line Hotel pencils with you b/c I certainly did.  The public spaces are always a buzz with activity that make you feel like you've been invited to a great party.  Careful, it is easy enough to relax in courtyard with a coffee and let the afternoon slip into happy hour...  you have to motivate yourself to leave this urban oasis.

title: Favorite Hotel in NYC
text:
I've stayed here a couple times now (for business and personal visits) and each time it feels like coming home.  The warm, cozy, vintage environment of the hotel and the quiet oasis of the grounds is priceless at the end of a long, hectic, stressful day in New York.  Plus the super friendly staff and access to one of the best gyms in the city make it really feel like you're treating yourself.

I'd also add that the location is great for just about anywhere from Midtown to Battery Park--I like it for easy access to meetings in Midtown by day and meeting up with friends and bars and restaurants in Chelsea and the Village.

title: Grand on the Outside and Intimate, Charming and Eccentric Inside
text: Our first real connection with The High Line Hotel was calling while en route to find out about parking.  The staff person was friendly, informative and helpful.  That was only the beginning! The staff bent over backwards to meet our every need during our all-too-short stay.  My husband and I have not been NYC enthusiasts...until now....we've found a HAVEN from which to explore the nearby The High Line and Hudson River Park or the Guggenheim and Met, a good Shinola ride away!  You can look forward to returning to your room - the old fashioned phone works, the closet is large and the room is spacious.  There are details that delight - the sharpened pencils, the smell of coffee brewing early in the morning from Intelligentsia downstairs and the old books piled on the mantle!  We're going back as soon as we can.

title: Nearly Perfect!
text:
There are other hotels in NYC that are more modern, more glamorous, with angles of glass and brass, and lots of flash. This isn't that. The High Line Hotel is a charming, historic, eccentric, warm and relaxing respite from the rush of the street. It's close to so much of what we love, the High Line, Chelsea Market, walkable to the West Village, if you're game, and surrounded by some of the best food and drink in the city. 
Our room was on the 5th floor, facing 10th Avenue, and the traffic wasn't too bothersome, but the floors below us, might experience a little more noise. Next time, we'll ask for a room on the courtyard in the back. But, as NYC rooms go, it was a nice size, and the closet was large enough to unpack a month's worth of clothes, which is unheard of, in the city. The bathroom was also nicely appointed, but a little small, for sharing. 
And, for coffee in the morning, throw on your jeans, and run downstairs to Intelligentsia. It's worth getting out of bed for. Great lattes, pastries, it's a lovely way to start the day; and, the secret must be out around the neighborhood, because people walking their dogs stop by to grab their cups, on their way out in the morning. 
It's a really fun place, with great staff that live to help you, and know your name and needs. We can't wait to go back. Enough said.

title: Unique, charming, spacious, witty, comfortable, surprising, SPOTLESS....
text: This place delighted me every 5 minutes.  The bird pics on the hallway walls, the lovely little lobby, the antiques and vintage items all placed so well....and so SPOTLESS!   The pencils, the embosser, the old antique rug, the HEAVY working phone...... Everything was old (in a good way) except the things that mattered (like bedding and showers).  The room was surprisingly spacious.  (Rm 24)   I wanted to buy the owl on the mantle!   Neat little mini bar in the room, big towels, heavy velvet drapes ----   good restuarant with outdoor seating, cute dogs walking around, I mean, really, you are a DB if you don't like this place.  Bikes to borrow and a nice area to walk around - easy to find parking on the side streets.  I have stayed a lot of places and this place felt like it welcomed me and that I belonged to it.... I didn't want to leave.  I swear, I looked for a speck of dirt or hair and couldn't find any!   What a gem - I hope it thrives but not so much that I can never get a room there.  ;-)    Also, I felt the guests were very nice and polite - there was no loud crazy noise, and people were polite in the coffee line - and the dogs were fun!

title: The  best way to experience The High Line area is by staying at The High Line Hotel.  enjoyed every detail staying here
text:
There is  nothing better to me  than waking up to a great cup of coffee at a coffee bar   with the right kind of music playing and go out the back door to a peaceful courtyard in the middle of this gorgeous building to enjoy it.  I Then went for a  walk just 1/2 block and to climb up to The High Line and enjoy that part of Manhattan down to the Whitney.
Wow Wow.. loved every moment and recommend the experience to all my fellow travelers. Perfection!

title: Excellent
text: Accueil sympathique, bonne atmosphère, personnel attentif, très bonne qualité.  Je recommande les vélos pour un tour dans le quartier et bien-sûr la marche sur la Highline. Que du bon pour cet établissement.

title: NYC at it's finest
text: HLH is a super charming boutique hotel. Location is great, across from the High Line park. Nice coffee/cocktail bar in the lobby and outside patio. Great decorations and art, nice hardwood and tile floors. Room was city small, but bed was extremely comfortable, and room was well stocked with amenities and excellent mini bar treats. Staff was over the top friendly and helpful. Will definitely stay again.

title: Clean and spacious
text: Spent a Friday and Saturday night here in a double queen room on the 2nd floor that was clean and spacious.  Beds are very comfortable.  Bathroom was clean and good size.  Would have been 5 stars but hotel does not have a restaurant (the said they have food outside on the weekends if the weather is nice but we didn't see this).  There were people sitting outside having cocktails but didn't see food.  There are plenty of good restaurants in the immediate area.  No parking at the hotel either but there is a Fast Park across the street which we made a reservation for and was perfect since we didn't plan on driving in the city.  House keeping comes late in the afternoon so when we came back on Saturday afternoon around 3:30 we had to wait for about 30 minutes while they finished up in the room.  Overall good place to stay if you're interested in being in this area of the city.

title: Urban Oasis...
text:
OK, I'm a sucker for older re-purposed heritage buildings, so when my hotel search showed an 1800s red sandstone / brick residential building, in a cool neighborhood (Chelsea) I was all in. And after a few days of Corporate New York, we were ready to decompress.
We only stayed one night due to flight bookings, but what a fantastic experience! After an hour of Manhattan traffic, to be greeted by name, we were truly welcomed.  All the amenities great boutique hotels offer were present in spades - great staff, comfy bedding, big thick towels, awesome coffee bar (Intelligensia, frequented by locals as well as guests).
The High Line Hotel will certainly see us again!

title: Great experience!
text: My husband and I along with a large majority of our friends and family stayed at the High Line Hotel for our sons wedding in the city.  The staff could not have been more accommodating.  The rooms were clean, the beds were comfortable and the service was great.  Also, the hotel is conveniently located to great restaurants, Chelsea Market and the High Line.  The garden restaurant at the hotel is a beautiful place to conveniently grab a bite to eat or a drink.  We would definitely go back to the High Line Hotel.

title: Awesome Hotel Experience
text: I had the opportunity to stay at this hotel for two nights while my family and I stayed there for my sister's wedding from 7/8-7/10. From the moment we entered the hotel premises, we were greeted and welcomed. The doormen to the concierge to the check-in, everyone was very professional, friendly and attentive. The hotel is not a high story hotel and has 5 floors, but that fact is what makes this hotel in the midst of NYC very appealing in that it is not overcrowded and congested. Everything from the coffee place in the lobby to the rooms itself were very inviting.  This hotel from top to bottom has an avant garde trendy aesthetic appearance. I was impressed by this hotel overall and the employees working there, and would definitely recommend it!

title: Awesome experience
text: Great hotel, awesome folks and location.  One of my best hotel stays in NYC.  The High Line Hotel is comfortable, cozy and warm.  Beats the hotel chains in every category.  I would definitely recommend this hotel.

title: love the highline
text: i have been using the high line hotel for 3 years now while traveling from LA. Danny and the staff have been very accommodating even when arriving early morning from a red eye. i will continue to use the high line hotel as my first choice in NYC.

title: Love this Hotel
text:
My boyfriend and I stay here every time we come to NYC. The hotel is beautiful & the rooms are comfortable and clean.   

Danny, one of the concierges, was incredibly accommodating and helpful. We had just arrived from LA off a redeye and got to the hotel at 6am - way too early to check in but Danny said he would see what he could do to get a room ready for us ASAP.  He recommended a few places to kill some early morning time and called us as soon as a room was available for us, which wasn't too long after our arrival.  He was great during our entire stay.

title: A Gem in Chelsea
text: A most UN-Manhattan hotel in charming Chelsea, this hotel feels like it belongs in London or Oxford. Retro furnishings (the rotary dial telephones are a wonderful touch) give the place a funky at home feel, and everything about the service is highly personal and friendly. I loved staying here in this wonderful New York enclave right across from the High Line and just blocks from the New Whitney. I'll definitely be back.

title: An Oasis in Chelsea - More like a wonderful inn than a large hotel
text:
My wife and I (and teen daughter, at times) have stayed at the High Line several times now and I consider it one of the best hotel values in the city.  Our rooms have ranged from smaller (but never too small) to grand, with plenty of space for the three of us;  and the service is always great.  Daniel at the front desk treats us as old friends who stay there every week (we don't!); Alvin, one of the ready and able doormen, grabs our bags or sets us up with our complimentary bikes, always with a smile and a wink. At the end of this stay it was pouring - bucket loads.  One of the other doormen put my suitcase in the cab's trunk and when I handed him back the hotel's signature sturdy High Line umbrella, he said, " Its really coming down, why don't you take it with you".  I said, "But I'm not coming back". He said, "it's OK; you stay here don't you?"  It's the kind of small thing that makes you want to come back.

This is a quiet hotel - the lobby is not filled with 20-something hipsters or loud music. The lobby is small but a nice to take a break, have a coffee or tea.  There are also two nice outdoor seating areas, one of them shaded by tall trees.  Everything about this hotel is solid, and everyone is kind.  It's also pet and kid friendly.

Only thing lacking, to my knowledge, is room service but with Intelligensia Coffee in the lobby, excellent coffee is at hand (I'm guessing you might be able to call down and place an order).  The food is also great at the on-site dinner restaurant.  No breakfast or lunch, but Cookshop and the Empire Diner (newly spiffed up) are a half block or less in either direction.  Or you can go to Le Grainne Cafe, my favorite little funky French corner restaurant a block away on 9th. It's less than half a block to the glorious Highline, and a block to the Hudson River bike path (do it!).  Five stars!!!

title: Family trip into NYC
text:
Spent 3 nights with family. Rooms were comfortable and attractive.
Staff was friendly and helpful. Coffee bar served great coffee. Loved that it is a dog friendly place. Lots to do in the area. Some really good restaurants and reasonably priced. Great location. Across the street from the High Line. Would definitely stay there again. Highly recommend.

title: Amazing hotel
text: We let the hotel know that it was our anniversary, and were upgraded to an amazing room with champagne.  Beautiful, unique furnishings, steps from the high line, lovely staff.  One of our favorite places.

title: What a hidden gem
text: I have stayed at this amazing historic property several times now.  Each time i come back the staff is more attentive than the last.  I had the pleasure to stay here for my friends wedding most recently.  WOW!!! The space was enchanting and the food was 'out of this world' good!!

title: Stunningly preserved architecture
text: From the moment you step out of your cab you are warmly greeted by staff to welcome you to the hotel and get you checked in effortlessly.  And those warm greetings don't stop until you say your farewell.  Everyone is available to make your stay perfect.  The rooms are expertly restored with beautiful hardwood floors, large ceiling moldings, black and white tile in the bathrooms, and period carpets and furnishings.  If you can swing the High Line Suite, it's worth it!  And make sure you set aside some time to enjoy one of their expertly hand crafted cocktails out back before heading up to your room for the night.

title: Quiet and comfortable...
text: Here a lot on business. I usually stay up the street. Never again. High Line was very comfortable -- and very easy. Helpful front staff. Turndown service. Good scotch at bar. Bummed no valet service, but parking lot right across the street.

title: Cool to check out
text: I was looking at neat hotels in NY and had to check out this place. Its super close to the high Line, Obviously, which is nice if you would like to check that out. Its also close to Chelsea Market, if you were interested in going there. The hotel is just beautiful to see and walk around in. Since I wasn't staying there, i just went into the lobby where they have a cafe. You can sit down in a pretty little courtyard out back or right in the lobby if there is room.

title: Undiscovered Diamond
text: Love this place. In the middle of everything. Scratches my inner Harry Potter when I stay here. Considering staying in a soulless chain hotel? Forget about it. Book a room in the High Line Hotel and feel the history of lower Manhattan surround you.

title: Best hotel in NYC
text: This is a wonderful hotel perfectly located in Chelsea. The hotel is very quiet and the staff made an excellent impression during our stay. The hotel is very personal with nice rooms with a personal touch

title: Favorite Hotel in NYC
text: This is our new favorite hotel in NYC.  The location is wonderful, close to the Highline, galleries and great restaurants.  The outside dinning area is wonderful, especially during the warmer months of the year.  The staff is great and the coffee bar fantastic.  Our room is perfect size, and a breath of fresh air from the corporate hotels around the city.  I will always pick the Highline Hotel as my hotel of choice when visiting NYC

title: Hidden gem of NYC
text: Massive kudos to everyone at the High Line Hotel who made our stay so lovely. We stayed there for 4 nights and absolutely adored it! Everyone was so welcoming and friendly, and helpful beyond words! We will definitely return!

title: Welcoming and Charming
text: I've had the opportunity to stay at this hotel twice now, and it has quickly become my favorite place to stay while visiting friends and family in NY. Beautiful, historic building with comfortable rooms, friendly staff, and an exceptional coffee shop in the lobby. Will certainly be back soon.

title: Fabuloso!
text: Esto es un review del restaurante que esta afuera del hotel, es bello, con vista al highline. Llegamos a eso de las 6 de la tarde, nos sentamos afuera, y pedimos tragos y hamburgesa y patatas, la comida riquisima y el ambiente lo maximo verdaderamente.

title: Lovely Hotel & A Great Staff!
text: I really appreciate the warm, welcoming "climate" of The High Line.  Staff is excellent, friendly and professional!  I have stayed here before and plan to return.  I have family in the immediate neighborhood, so it's a perfect fit.

title: The perfect venue for a weekend getaway
text:
For business trips, I often find myself in Midtown "name" hotels that are uptight and cater to ego.  For a personal weekend trip with my wife, I just wanted to be comfortable in a quaint yet convenient neighborhood, and a room that feels more "homey".   The High Line Hotel was perfect.  Chelsea is the perfect neighborhood to stay in with plenty of restaurants, shopping and activity.   Add in the proximity of the High Line, which in my opinion is one of the City's great passive amenities, and the hotel offers an extremely unique set of options.
The building itself is well worth seeing.   The exterior stonework and details provide the feeling of a castle, while the woodwork and interior furnishings are warm and inviting.  I'm admittedly a fan of architectural history and enjoy seeing that in the midst of urban modernity.   If you share that interest, this building is worth seeing regardless of where you stay.
Just as the building is unique, the grounds are equally interesting.   Make a point of going into the exterior space in back, taking the stairs up to the courtyard that looks out at the Seminary's space, sit on the grass or the steps and look up at the trees, check out the stained glass windows, and you'll find yourself in a garden that pulls you into a different world.   We sat out there and enjoyed a coffee in the morning, and then a pre-dinner glass of wine.  I highly recommend doing the same.
Finally, the staff did everything they could to contribute to our feeling at home.   The High Line is not a glitzy, stuffy hotel with extra services for "status" members.   It's a quaint yet trendy boutique hotel, and the staff treat you in the same manner as every other guest.   The lobby is your living room, the grounds are your garden, and the staff are your concierges.   There was always someone in the lobby to answer questions, make suggestions or provide assistance.   All of the staff were friendly and accommodating, and made us feel like we'd been friends for awhile.   Again, this is very unique to NY in my experience...
Without question, we'll stay here again.   The only hesitation I have in recommending it, is trying to keep it a little bit of a personal secret for my own benefit.   I'm afraid that's no longer possible regardless...  Stay here if you want a perfect personal experience in NY without the glitz and glammer, and you'll be very happy!

title: Beautiful garden, great coffee, small room and cant trust house keeping
text:
We stayed at this hotel 2 nights. We checked in late at night and were given room 57.5 (which was interesting). Checkin was smooth. I am not sure about the .5 but maybe because it was small in size? Anyhow - it was a very small room but neat and tidy. We liked it. I read that there are bigger rooms too but I guess that depends on how you made your reservation. We used Hotel Tonight.
The cafe in the lobby is great (except it is a bit pricey - $4 for a regular coffee)? The best part of the hotel is the garden where you can sit, relax, work etc.
We were happy with our stay till the time we checked out. We forgot our iphone charger in the room. We called them the next day and the lady who answered the phone said she couldn't find it in lost and found and will check with the house keeping and get back. I told her that we were leaving NY the same day so would appreciate a reply sooner - so we can come pick up the charger. I never got a call back.
I called them again before leaving NY - no one answered so I left a detailed message and again requested them to call back. Again no answer.

It is unfortunate when guests forget some things at the hotel and hotel can't find those things. Worst is when the hotel staff assure you that they will get back and they don't. If you go back to this hotel - please take care of your belongings.
Will not go back.

title: NYC is the city that never sleeps - but when it does it would go here!
text:
So many hotels in NY and so few of them really get it. I must admit to bias that the NY I love is in Chelsea or the Meatpacking district - you can keep Times Square or 5th Avenue. This is proper NY. 

And the High Line Hotel is a proper hotel. The rooms are very Soho House if you are familiar with the brand. Well thought out, eclectic with neat touches in the furniture and styling. Everything from the floor rugs to the books has been carefully chosen and there's even a manual paper embosser in each room that will stamp one of the original symbols from the hotels previous days as a religious college and seminary. 

The coffee shop in the small lobby converts into a bar at night and don't worry if you need more than a pastry at breakfast, the Cookshop right next door runs one of the healthiest and most original breakfast menus in the whole of Manhattan. 

The High Line just gets it right without trying too hard. Fluffy towels - the most amazingly comfortable bed - some statement in the land of amazing hotel beds (why are the Americans the only people who understand how important mattresses are when you spend a third of your life lying on one??) - and laid back helpful staff contribute to making this my new favourite hotel in NYC. So let's just keep this to ourselves shall we?

title: Impeccably maintained historic building in a great location
text:
The High Line Hotel exceeded my expectations for a quick overnight stay in Manhattan.  The location is fantastic - across the street from the High Line itself and very close to Chelsea Piers and Chelsea Market.  The trendy meatpacking district is nearby - and the property is only a 15 minute walk from the heart of midtown.

My room was decent size for a NYC hotel - and had tons of snacks and drinks ready for consumption!  Also the TV was much better than 90% of hotels - lots of channels and all in HD.  Internet access was free and easy as well; I was able to get some work done without the evening wifi slowdown at many hotels.

Finally the hotel has a small but lively cafe in the lobby.  Many people from the neighborhood brought their dogs to get coffee; it makes the property much more homey than a stiff big box hotel.

title: Miserable hotel
text: Look for better hotels in NY for this price. The room was tiny, with old interior, not very clean (spots everywhere), and it smelled. There was no place for bags, the light was faint, the bathroom small. We did not feel comfortable.

title: The High Line Oasis
text: The location first. The High Line Hotel is in the wonderful area of Chelsea Lower Manhattan. Such a relaxed comfortable neighbourhood area. You need this tranquillity from the NY midtown bustle. Only a short bus/subway/taxi to all other areas. Although Philippa & walked everywhere. We chatted with so many friendly locals. Either in the hotel or the local cafe's/bar's/restaurant's. The hotel itself.......Where do I start.....From the time we stepped in to the time we skipped out  everything was perfect perfect perfect. There is no main reception area no bar during the day no restaurant as such.....So what. I have heard so many negative comments regarding the lack of the fore mentioned.  There is a booking in area in the lounge/reception area. The staff, all the staff are so kind & courteous. You are looked after the whole time you are at the THLH. Thank you to all the staff. We were booked in so quickly & our luggage whisked upto out room in minutes.  It was a busy time when we arrived as well. We booked a King deluxe room. Everything about it was perfect. The huge bed with the luxury bedding & pillows was very very comfortable. The room was large with huge windows with blackout curtains.  We were lucky our room was on the corner of the building meaning we had two views.  There is minibar with a variety of drinks & snacks.  A safe, an ironing board iron & hairdryer. The toiletries are of a local quility brand. The aircon was fine. The little antiquities around the room made it that more interesting. Bathrobe & slippers on arrival. Towels changed daily & bedding changed when requested. During the season there is an evening restaurant. All served on the front patio/garden area. We ate there one eveing. The food was fine. We only ate light as we were off to the theatre & were eating afterwards.  The coffee bar in the mornings was a treat.  We also ate locally. The Empire Diner. The Cookshop, Chelsea Market.  All were very good. When we return to NY.  There is only one place we shall be staying & that will be THLH.

title: High Line Hotel is a Gem
text: We stayed at the High Line Hotel on a recent trip to visit the Morgan Museum.  We definitely plan to return!  The hotel is located in a former Episcopal seminary, is warmly pet-friendly, located just across the street from a good spot for breakfast/brunch and only a block or so from some very dinner spots. Parking is just across the street. We also appreciated the hotel's location next to an entrance to the High Line walkway (former railroad line turned into a lovely urban park). The comfort and convenience of the High Line Hotel made our visit to the city pleasant and relaxed.  Highly recommended.

title: Great Location; Quiet Room; Too Much Stuff for Sale in the Room
text:
The good stuff about the High Line: it is in a great location - close to the High Line, the Chelsea Market, the Whitney Museum and the Rubin Museum. Our bed was comfortable. The room - on the 4th floor - was very quiet by New York Standards. The public spaces in the hotel supported a happy mingling of locals (and their dogs) and hotel guests. The back yard patio was secluded and quiet; the front yard patio was open and busy all the time (when it wasn't raining). The wifi was strong and free with the price of the room
The less good stuff about the High Line: Our 200 sq. ft. room had no closet and only two small drawers to put our clothes - and nowhere to put our luggage. The room seemed poorly appointed for one person, let alone 2.  Every available surface was covered with pricey snack food and booze. I would rather have had a bit more room for my own stuff. 
The stair up to the (ancient, tiny) elevator from the lobby was narrow, steep and ridiculously poorly lit. 
The high Line has a lot of character. If you spend a lot of time in your hotel when you travel to NYC, I imagine you'll think it's awesome.

title: Great Hotel!!!
text: I really loved the feel of this hotel...close to the Hi line and vet comfy beds!!!  I slept so well after enjoying the NYC nightlife!!!  Great snacks...and other treats in the mini bar!! The hotel bar/coffee shop is also quite nice...great place to relax and hang out!!

title: Great Place to stay in Chelsea
text: We love The High Line Hotel. Having stayed there three times now, it is officially our go-to place for a great place to stay in New York City. But it's not for everyone. If you want a standard hotel experience, with all the standard amenities, and standard furniture in all the standard places, you may want to look elsewhere. But if you are looking for a unique, on-of-a-kind experience, give it a try. I would describe it as the anti-hotel hotel. It doesn't look like a hotel and there is no front desk. The entrance area (I don't want to call it a lobby) has a coffee shop with the best coffee you will find anywhere. Since a lot of neighborhood residents come in for coffee, it's great for people watching.  Hotel guests and neighborhood residents intersect in a way that seems unforced and very authentic. Proceeding to your room, it feels more like you are going to your own private space in your friend's apartment building rather than going to a typical hotel room. Floors are hardwood, stained black, with hand-knotted antique carpets scattered around. The furnishings are unique and arranged in an idiosyncratic way that makes the room feel very personal. It's not the typical hotel room  formula arrangement that you expect to see at any hotel anywhere in the world. For instance, the room we stayed in this time did not have a closet. A freestanding, ample-sized clothing rack was provided instead.  I suspect some people would find this off-putting, but it's the sort of thing we have in the guest rooms of our own old house, where some rooms simply don't have closets. The bed is wonderfully comfortable and always a pleasure to retreat to after a long  day tromping the city streets. The shower is great, with lots of pressure. We were short on hot water one late morning, but it's easy to forgive in light of all the many positives, and I would say that just contributes to a feeling of authenticity. The room has lots of quality snack choices and an assortment of drinks. You don't need to leave the room if you don’t want to. Lastly, if you are looking for a low-key place to stay and enjoy the city, you can't beat the location. It's in a real neighborhood with real restaurants and shopping close by. The High Line is right out your front door. There's a subway stop close by, and the hotel is easy to get to by car if you are taking taxis or ride-share. Interestingly, we found that most drivers are unfamiliar with the hotel, which we think only adds to the charm. So if you are looking for an off-beat place, give The High Line Hotel a try. We can't wait to go back.

title: Well-appointed hotel in trendy Chelsea
text: We spent a great Mother's Day weekend at the High Line.  We had 2 rooms, one on the 1st floor and another on the 2nd floor.  The rooms were enormous.  The room with 2 queen beds (room 20), had a massive bathroom and large, comfortable living space.  Our other room (L8) had a single king and a nice seating area.  The neighborhood is very quiet, steps from the Highline and Chelsea Market.  We usually stay on the east side, but wanted a change of pace.  I think we'll be staying at the High Line for our next trip to NYC.

title: Style over substance
text:
Checked in last week to this hotel having booked several months before but was disappointed by my selection and wished I'd chosen one of the others in the neighbourhood that we reviewed. I travel to NYC frequently and have stayed in many hotels (big brands / New York classics / boutique etc) but this one is definitely style over substance!

The 1st impression is great... building is beautiful, neighbourhood is fab and greeting was good. Once you go inside though it does go downhill.  We arrived at 6.30pm - the entrance area was really busy and the reception is not a reception - its a computer in a cupboard on one side of the area. You immediately feel in the way of people there drinking (and probably not staying) - not a good experience when you are paying a high price for a room and they are paying $5 for a coffee!

We got shown to our room (27 & a half) which was tiny! A lovely comfy bed, a metal clothes rail and a big cupboard in the corner that contained safe, iron, fridge but no draws or areas to store clothes. And on the other wall was a table that again was covered with books and other "trinkets" that were of no use but rendered the table useless. We arrived with 2 large suitcases as NY was a part of our trip and not only was there no room to unpack anything but there was no room to put our suitcases down either without moving the rail across the door.  The only part of the room that had any space was the bathroom!

Having arrived after a long journey we wanted a drink straightaway,(there is no room service) so we went down to the communal area / reception area where there is a bar, but was told we couldn't get a coffee as its was after 6pm!  We then sat down (expecting the barman to come & take an order) but that didn't happen either - even though there were several hotel staff just standing around talking. It was only the following day that we realized that the bar and coffee area are probably franchises of some sorts and run separately to one another and to the hotel too (and both are really expensive and offer a limited choice!).

The only positive experience was after we complained the following morning, they then moved us to a room where we could unpack and move around (No.21).

I won't be back for sure.  In a city with so much choice (and good choices too!) this one was lacking in many areas

title: Very hip hotel - spoiled only by yappy dog late at night
text:
I booked the hotel through Hoteltonight.com (recommended!) and was overall very pleased with it. We were in Room 47 and a half (if anybody can enlighten me on why the half, please do!) and although it was small, it was very nicely decorated. 

Only complaint was that there was a dog yapping at midnight. We'd only just got back to the room so it didn't bother me, but if I'd been asleep already it would have been annoying, as it was definitely loud enough to wake me. Not really sure I like the idea of dogs in hotel rooms anyway, even if they don't yap.

title: New York elegance
text: Lovely comfortable room with a huge, cosy bed to rest your weary bones. Our room had a tiny bathroom with only enough room for one person at a time, which is normal in NY apparently. The rooms have an eclectic mix of antique pieces making them very individual and a large choice of drinks and snacks but no tea-making facility. There is also no restaurant to speak of so you have to eat out. They do have a very popular coffee lounge though, used by guests, but also by locals, some of which occupy valuable seating areas and subject their business forums to anyone within earshot, so it's only possible to relax in your room rather than a lounge. Our room was kept very clean, but was quite often not tidied until after 4pm, which made relaxing after a busy day, tricky.  Would definitely stay again though. Staff were very friendly and polite. Love the fact the hotel allows pooches in the foyer.

title: A Unique Hotel Experience
text: We've stayed at the High Line Hotel three times, most recently last weekend and loved it every time.  The High Line is different from any other hotel we've stayed in in New York. The location is somewhat afield from usual Manhattan locations, but is perfect for exploring the High Line, Chelsea and other hip westside neighborhoods.  A former Episcopal Seminary guesthouse, the hotel decor features art deco antiques, pre-tech appliances like dial phones and manual typewriters, and other eclectic items.  The staff is young, friendly and very helpful.  We particularly like the vibe from the cozy lobby, which always seems full of interesting people of various degrees of hipness, as well as their dogs.  The rooms also feature eclectic décor but also have very comfortable beds and linens, a flat-screen HD TV, and excellent wifi.

title: odor
text:
Love this hotel overall but the antiques and old rugs in rooms have a very odd (i suspect mildewcide) smell. It bothered both myself and my colleague's throats/lungs.

Also, the lobby gets overrun by locals and their dogs (non-guests) coming to get coffee at Intelligentsia(a coffee bar in the lobby). For almost $500 a night this seems rather intrusive.

Even though I love the vibe of the old place I'll stay elsewhere next time due to room odor. It's just not healthy.

title: Good, but not the right hotel for everybody
text: My partner and I stayed here in one room this weekend, and my parents were in another room.  Overall, I'm happy to have stayed here, but not sure that I would stay here again.  We stayed in this hotel as it was 100% convenient to where we wanted to be in - Chelsea, just blocks from my brother's apartment.  the Location was great, and there are a number of great restaurants nearby - handy since there's no full - service restaurant on the premises.  Also, the hotel is right near the high line ( hence the name), so it's great for exploring.  I liked the hotel, but I'll be the first to say it's not for everybody.  It's an old, historic building.  With a lovely court yard and a great patio out front with seating.  Everybody tells me its great for drinks outside at night in the summer.  Due to the size of the building, each room is unique, and some are very small, some are a bit bigger.  Clearly, this is NYC and that's to be expected.  Our room was small - it had a comfortable king size bed.  I liked it, but my partner - and my parents in their room - commented that it was a tad too soft for their tastes.  Linens, though, were extremely soft and comfortable.  Towels in the bathroom were excellent.  I also liked the toiletires - CO Bigelow - high quality.  furniture throughout the hotel is mismatched, on purpose.  People will either like that or not.  Delightfully quirky.  Our room, being small, might have been only truly for one person, as there was only one bedside table, which made it inconvenient for whoever was on that side of the bed.  Also, I noticed that plugs/ power outlets througout my room were sparse - which was difficult for charging phones/ electronics.  IN addition, it was tough for ironing - we had to plug the iron into the outlet in our bathroom.  My parents room, slightly larger, had two bedside tables.  It also had an intersting couch.  Good to have a couch, but honestly, there was no practical way to sit in it other than laying back entirely.  The hotel also had some moderate wear and tear in places - the rug in the elevator in our section of the building was completely stained/ scruffed, and there were nicks/ tears in certain areas in our room (in the wall paper behind the bed, chipped paint, etc).   Also, this definitely isnt (in my opinion) a hotel if you're a business traveler - desks are small, there arent business services, and there arent enough plugs.  THAT SAID, we loved the vibe in the lobby - great coffee from intelligentsia.  There definitely is a quaint and quirky charm to the whole premises.  And we loved the mix of locals with their dogs and guests in the coffee area (bar at night) and in the patio/ courtyard.  Overall, this is a great hotel if you want to be in Chelsea, if you want a bit of quirkiness, and are into exploring the neighborhood for food options (of which there are plentiful and excellent options, including Cookshop next door).

title: Excellent hotel
text:
Great location, a few blocks from Chelsea market, and from Greenwitch village
Within view of the highline for an evening walk, and a block from the Hudson river walkway/bike path for a morning run, or a bike ride.
Nice room, quiet location. Friendly, and helpful staff.

title: Nice hotel, nice people but terrible housekeeping department
text: We stayed at the Highline Hotel the weekend of April 6-9th. Great location.  The rooms were  very large, especially for NYC, nice, interestingly decorated.  There is a small bar in the lobby that doubles as a coffee bar during the day and a bar with alcohol at night.  The people working at the bar were really nice and very service oriented.  There is a pretty garden outside the front door with tables and chairs for nice weather.  It's obviously a popular hangout spot for the neighborhood.  Our problem was with the housekeeping.  The afternoon of our second day there, we returned to our room around 4pm only to find our room hadn't been made up while we were out all day.  We called and someone came up and quickly cleaned up and brought fresh towels.  Amazingly, the same thing happened the next day as well!  We asked that they come take care of the room when we left again at 5 pm, but when we got back to the room after 11 pm, they had done turndown service but had left us with no towels at all!  I called downstairs and the person on duty said he had no key to the closet where the towels were kept.  We finally were brought towels in the morning.  When we left, I reported all of this again to the person who checked us out.  She was apologetic and said she'd report this to the manager and that we'd hear from him, but we never did.  Clearly, the Highline Hotel has a problem in their Housekeeping Department.

title: Historic, luxurious, understated hotel
text:
The Highline Hotel, as you will have read, was converted from part of an Episcopal Seminary that dates back to the late 1800s. (The other part of the building still functions as a seminary). Located in West Chelsea, on 10th Ave between 20th and 21st, the hotel is in a terrific part of the neighborhood. This is not a touristy area, but rather a lively family neighborhood full of young professionals and families. The restaurants nearby are excellent and laid-back. You'll notice the neighborhood in the morning when the superb lobby coffee shop (Intelligentsia) develops a line full of locals and their dogs out for morning coffee. Yes, the hotel is dog-friendly--there is even a bowl of dog treats by the entrance.
     The rooms are really converted from the old seminary rooms, so they have a lot of personality. Our room, a deluxe King, was quite large and had a fireplace and two closets. The bathroom still had the original floor tile. The beds are new and modern but much of the furniture comes from local flea markets and antique shops. It does feel quite a bit like staying in a wealthy friend's country 'cottage.' But the amenities you are about are great--sheets are luxurious, the AC works well, good water pressure, nice shampoos, etc.
     The hotel also has a lovely courtyard with tables where you can have a quiet coffee under the trees. It seems as if quite a few locals come in to do some work out of their apartments. This does not feel like New York--it feels secluded and relaxing. They also lend out a fleet of Shinola bikes if you'd like, and they provide a good local bike map.
     About the only complaint you could have is that there is no on-site restaurant. Intelligentsia provides coffees and pastries for breakfast but for something more substantial, you have to walk a half-block down 10th Ave to a local restaurant (which is also very good!).
     Uber cars are plentiful in the neighborhood. We would definitely go back.

title: Original and comfortable
text: This was the second time I stayed here. The hotel itself is so well-appointed, I love the furniture and decor in the rooms- it feels like being at a friend's house rather than a hotel. Great little bar on the first floor is good for coffee in the morning and good wine at night. Proximity to the High Line and Chelsea Market is great.

title: Great Historic Hotel
text: Cool old building with interesting architecture, large patio, and great coffee shop. The staff is very helpful and friendly, rooms are restored, comfortable and spotless. The lobby is typically busy from Intelligentsia and all different breeds of dogs are usually present. Rooms can be a little small but, the location and appointments make it worth it. The Cook Shop restaurant next door is also great, as is the access to Equinox gym. Second time here and would definitely do so again.

title: Es un lugar genial, amigable y excelente ubicación para New Yorkers
text:
El hotel tiene una arquitectura única, la decoración vintage es agradable, cómoda y la cama excelente para descansar. Los tapetes dan una sensación de casa. El escritorio tipo pupitre es una excelente pieza con un sello para grabar papel que le da un toque nostálgico. El café es excelente y los vecinos van con sus perros que reciben premios del concierge del hotel.
Ha sido mi mejor estancia en NY.

title: Great Fun
text: Loved the hotel - wonderful staff and an upgrade to a deluxe King which was wonderful.  Amazing that you don't hear the street noise.  The lobby gets crazy busy with coffee bar but never too much to get in and out.  There are a lot of dogs in the lobby in the morning and I could have done without but I'm not a pet hater - and most were well behaved.  So close to the highland and a great location.

title: Unique gem in NYC
text: My wife and I stayed for 3 nights and enjoyed it very much.  We plan on staying again later this year; probably this fall.  The room was very clean, charming and the staff were very courteous and helpful.

title: Not a serious hotel
text:
This is not a serious hotel.  
They charge 400 a night but There is no room meal service.  
The coffee shop caters to outsiders. 
I was locked out off my room because their key system was broken and forced to sleep in random room until 7 am.  The staff did not have keys to rooms and the battery in door was not working.   
I missed morning meeting.  
There is no gym.  You need to walk 400m to equinox.

title: The money worth it !
text: This hotel is just amazing, the money just worth it. Very well furnished and everything in the room is just so fun and classic. The bed is very comfy, you will definitely have a good sleep there. There're also many other fun things in the room for you to discover.

title: Flawless!
text: This was a memorable experience. The hotel is intimate, luxurious but not flashy. The hotel captures a historical/vintage vibe without overdoing it.  Daniel, the concierge, was very helpful. In addition to its perfect location, a plus to the hotel is the restaurant across the street (Cookshop) -- great food and service as well. I would like to go back to the High Line Hotel in summer to enjoy the courtyard. I recommend this hotel without hesitation.

title: Stepped back in time in a welcoming, warm, bohemian hotel...
text:
If you are looking for a traditional bustling New York Hotel with the pretentiousness and indifference that sometimes accompanies this, this is not the hotel for you.  If you would enjoy staying in an historic setting with gas lamps outside and a welcoming staff inside, then make reservations here.  A stones throw from the High Line, galleries, Chelsea Market and numerous restaurants, it's a great central location for visiting this end of Manhattan.

The single small check-in area, that appeared to irritate another reviewer, was actually very efficient, charming and functional, and did not impede our check-in at all.  Our host at that desk, Dan, was very warm and knowledgeable about the history of the hotel, and offered to show us around the next day when he had more time.  Parts of this seminary and grounds are still in use, we were told, which adds to the charm and historical significance of the site. 

While the hotel does not have its own restaurant, a coffee bar off the lobby, was very popular, and again added to the hotel's ambience.  We found an incredible restaurant for dinner on Saturday night (The Red Cat) on a block or two away.  Right next to the hotel is the Cook Shop, which we did not try, but seems to have great on-line reviews.  

Our room and bed was very comfortable, and decorated with comfortable period furniture.  The rotary phones in the room which immediately connected with the hotel staff, were a nice touch as well.  Make sure you see the refectory, if possible.  My wife and I would come back here in a heartbeat.

title: Shabby hotel with character facing the Highline
text: This is a very strange hotel. Upon arrival you are greeted by a receptionist staring at a computer, housed in a hole in the wall that is the sum total of  'reception'. I really did feel sorry for them not being allowed to sit down all day. We were shown to a well appointed large room on the 3rd floor overlooking a quiet courtyard. A big plus is that the windows opened easily but there is no air conditioning only very noisy heating. The bed was a bit on the soft side but comfortable. Very little storage space as the room is full of vintage furniture without drawers. The bathroom is old fashioned and lacked adequate lighting or a make up mirror. There are no services to speak of so it is bit like staying in a rented room rather than a hotel. The small lobby houses a public coffee bar with free wifi so any seating is constantly taken up by locals with their dogs who stay for hours. This is extremely annoying and it is like staying in a branch of Starbucks. There is no dining room but the hotel is very near restaurants, diners and Chelsea Market and a 24 hour drugstore. Bus stops right outside but subway (23rd street) is a 15 minute walk. No manager to be seen but Daniel in reception was extremely helpful. Try the excellent lunch at Del Posto - 5 minutes walk.

title: Beautiful boutique hotel full of character.
text: The High Line is a beautiful period property. The check in was informal but extremely courteous and warm. The lift is very dark and smells odd. Feels a little haunted house like. My room was well appointed. Beautiful vintage furnishings. Sheets and bedding were perfect. Fresh, soft and extremely comfortable like the mattress. Excellent pillows and duvet. The bathroom is too dimly lit for my preference with only a light above the mirror. The shower was ok in terms of heat but the shower head was hanging out slightly of the wall. Not great aesthetically. Pressure was fine but not incredible. All the lamps were pretty and had to be switched off separately. Charming if not slightly inconvenient with no overhead lighting. No coffee, tea or complimentary amenity in room. Extensive mini bar though since they do not have food or room service in the hotel. Perfect if you love boutique hotels and want to feel transported back to another time in New York.

title: Unique hotel in Chelsea
text: My husband and I have "staycationed" at The High Line Hotel twice for birthday celebrations (we live in Brooklyn) and love staying at this one-of-a-kind hotel in the city.  The rooms are beautiful with antique (or at least antique-style), eclectic but classy furniture.  They're also decked out with wonderful CO Bigelow products in the bathroom, location-relevant books, and a great mini-bar.  The beds are high, big, and comfortable.  There's an Intelligentsia coffee kiosk in the lobby for coffee & snacks that doubles as a bar.  Stay in an inside room if you can - it's so quiet, you can't believe you're in the city.  Also, you're only one block from the High Line park! Great location and a wonderful, romantic hotel.

title: Had a lovely stay
text: I only stayed for 1 night!!  It was a lovely stay and everything was clean and neat. The reception was really good and efficient!!  The location is also really great!!  I stayed in a standard room and was sufficient for 1 person, could get a tiny bit small if you are more than 1 person.  I would just want to mention 1 issue.  Their is only a central heating system, not sure if their is a central cooling system as well.  It was really cold outside but it was way to hot inside the room!!  I could hardly breath!!  I was told by reception that I cannot control my own heat in the room, so I need to open a window!!  Which I did, the only problem with that was then it became really noisy!!  Not sure what the rooms would be like if it is really hot?  Say in summer, because if their is no aircon it might get really hot?

title: Funky meets location
text: Tiny lobby full of guests with dogs, people studying and on their computers, and a flow between the shared coffee shop/bar. Former seminar offers tiny but well outfitted rooms. You can invision the former students hunched over their desk, being warmed by the fireplace (now not functional) while reading by the light flowing in from the big windows. Water pressure in the shower is amazing - wish I had that at home. During warmer months there is also alfresco dining available. Convienantly located by restaurants, museums, art galleries galore, and just across the street from High Line access.

title: Beautiful Historic Hotel in Great Neighborhood!
text: My sister and I stayed here for a fun NYC overnight.  The hotel is in a great Chelsea neighborhood, very close to the High Line, Chelsea Market, tons of shops and eateries.  It is a remodeled historic building, with high ceilings,  tiled bathrooms, thick walls, and high, large windows.  There is a lovely front patio and cozy indoor seating area near the coffee bar.  We arrived a few hours before check in, and not only were we granted early check in, but our room was upgraded!  Comfy beds, free WiFi, clean room, and noon checkout were all things which endeared the hotel to us.  This is our new New York hotel from now on!

title: Unconventionally Unique
text: What an amazing suite it was! It was the EXACT room I had admired while studying up on this outstanding hotel--The pink leather club chair was so inviting, and before leaving this morning, I tried my hand at the lovely antique embosser... The coffee bar/ très unique lobby was special and delicious! From the moment we arrived, to checkout, the experience was so superlative! The gentleman who carried our luggage to our suite, explained everything to us. Less than 24 hours spent at The High Line Hotel and we cannot WAIT to return . . .

title: wonderful experience
text: Hotel is lovely, a hidden gem. Great location to High Line, New Whitney Art Museum, Chelsea Market.  Great restaurants within walking distance. A nice safe area to explore on foot. Staff were lovely, remembered my name. Intelligentsia Coffee bar had great pastry and excellent coffee. Staff were knowledgeable and friendly. I was able to purchase whole bean coffee to go. Bartender made great crafted cocktails. My room was spacious and clean. Nice large windows and view of courtyard.  highly recommend this former seminary, for a stay. it is a cloistered haven.

title: Like a quaint European hotel
text: Huge rooms, fabulous location, charming lobby and bar, super fluffy beds. It was like I was transported to a quaint European hotel. Just a few blocks from the famous Chelsea Market and steps away from the highline. Fabulous!

title: Lovely stay
text: Wonderful old building with a ton of charm. Service was good and rooms comfortable and quiet. We stayed in a huge wonderful room which served us well for the five nights we spent there. If you love dogs, they're all over the place. We found ourselves tripping and dodging them every time we entered or exited. Steps away is the High Line, which allowed us a direct walk to the trade show at Javits we were attending. Additionally, the Chelsea area is charming and full of fun culinary surprises. Stay here if you like old architecture and charm. Be sure to pack plenty of dog biscuits for the welcoming committee.

title: Best Hot Chocolate Ever!
text:
Had an hour to kill Sunday before brunch and stumbled into this charming hotel.  
The coffee war was amazing - very intimate setting, staff could not have been nicer.  The hot chocolate came in a huge mug, and a deep, rich dark chocolate flavor.   They even made a foam tulip for me that lasted till the last drop.  A great place to be on your own or with company.

title: Great Location, Cool Hotel
text: This hotel is in a great location, near the highline, Chelsea, Greenwich, West Village.  Easy to walk many places, and they have great bikes for use also.  We took advantage of Equinox, their health club, which was easy and very convenient.  Although we found the room to be small, it was very well insulated, no noise, and it had everything we needed.  Bed was extremely comfortable.  Best selection I've ever seen in a minibar.  Staff was all very friendly, nice to have the coffee bar downstairs, and lots of nice outdoor space.

title: Amazingly chic and off the beaten path.
text: We LOVE this hotel and would highly recommend it!! It's not crowded with tourists and has a very insider feel. The rooms are decorated with antiques and cool floral wallpaper with really comfortable beds and great service. They have Intellegentsia coffee downstairs and has a very neighborhood feel. Right across the street from Highline, galleries, cookshop, it's a great quiet location.

title: The worst hotel I've ever stayed
text:
I’ve spent nearly two weeks in New York and stayed in the High Line Hotel at 180 Fifth Avenue.  My impression of the hotel, no matter the room itself or the services, are the worst in my experience in travelling around the world.

Below are my personal experience with the hotel to share with you:-

1.	Can u believe that a hotel with a daily rate of around US$450+ does not have a proper reception at the so-called lobby? Actually, there is no lobby in the hotel.

2.	When you go into the hotel, you will see a coffee bar and few tables that are always full of ppl.  On one side of the bar, you will see a staff standing in front of a computer and that’s the so-called reception.  Apart from check in and check out, the staff at the computer will never say ‘hi’ or greet you.  It seems that clients living in the hotel are transparent to them but the ‘reception staff’ just enjoy greeting those in the coffee bar.  Indeed, I feel like going and staying in a motel during the whole period.

3.	The above in fact do not bother me more than its services.  Since the day I stayed there, the bedside lamp and one of the light bulbs in the bathroom were not working.  One week after I stayed there, they were still out of order and only did I leave a complaint note to them did they fix them.  Unbelievable!

4.	For refilling the fridge or snack bar, No and Never did they do it.

5.	Two of their staff were helpful, namely Romeo and Daniel.  But, the problems were even though their attitudes were helpful and kind but the messages which I left for them to convey to their manager or the reply they subsequently gave me were very misunderstood or not-well communicated.  I really feel very disappointed at the communication amongst the staff of the hotel.  Seems like the hierarchy is having problem and the chain of command of leadership are completely in lack of.

6.	At the last day when I left the hotel, I checked out in the early morning and departed for the JFK airport and when in the Uber on the way, I suddenly learned that the flight was delayed and so I returned to the hotel.  I was told by a staff that if I stayed after 1:30 pm, I needed to pay a half-day rate for which I agreed (but I was later told by the hotel manager that there was no thing called half-day rate. Indeed, for the overstay for few hours, I was charged US$485).  I told him to proceed and to inform the manager and for which he said he would.  But, when I stayed in the room from 10:00 to 11:00 am and hang a “Do Not Disturb” sign at the door, 3 different staff locked at my door for different purposes.  All of them said they thought I had checked out.  For the first one, it’s ok and I assumed that the message of my staying in the room had not been well conveyed to the others. But, for the subsequent two disturbances, how could the hotel be accounted for that?

7.	What’s more ridiculous was when I went out later and returned to the hotel room to pick up my stuff for departure to the airport, when checking out again, the staff gave me a parcel which I had been waiting for few days.  I asked her why she didn’t give me that earlier (for other parcels I received, they would place it in my room) so that I can pack it into my luggages.  She replied me as I had put a “Do Not Disturb” sign at the room and therefore she didn’t do it.  Oh, I really have nothing to say about that.  They could keep disturbing me when I  hanged a “Do Not Disturb” sign but why this time could not?

8.	One advice for you is when you checked out at the hotel, you better check carefully the invoice.  For my morning check out on 11 Feb, nothing mentioned about my laundry expenses or even ‘fine of US$250’ per day for ‘smoking in the room’.  When checked out in the afternoon again, the invoice had suddenly appeared these two items but not the room rate for that extra-day.  I told the manager that if there’s a fine for ‘smoking in the room’, firstly, there must be warning to alert the clients and secondly, there must be some kind of evidence but not from the smell or my clothes or any other unsubstantiated matters.  Besides, if such a fine is to be levied, should the hotel forewarn the client first?  I indeed smoke and may have the smell with my clothes but when in the hotel, I didn’t smoke in the room but rather I had gone downstairs to the street to smoke.  If using the smell in the room to fine me of US$250 per day, they should tell me earlier rather than having the bill of US$250 per day x 13 days stated there at the time so sudden when check-out.  Up till now, the hotel invoices were still chaotic and I still need to spend effort to clarify with them.  How horrible this is?

9.	Another encounter was with the room-keeper.  One day when I went out at around noon and hang the door sign of “make up the room”, when I returned to the room at around 5 pm, I found the room had not been done yet and so I called the ‘reception’ to make arrangement.  Then, a room-keeper came and said that when she came earlier that afternoon, I had the sign of “do not disturb” hanging there and therefore she didn’t do it.  As well, by that time so late, she was not going to do it.  But, as I didn’t want to argue with her on the “door sign”, I just told her to do it and she replied me “you want to do it now”? OMG, should I repeat my request which being a hotel client is totally entitled to.

All in all, if you plan to stay in that hotel, think twice before you act. 

Don’t be misled that the heritage means vintage.  Rather, it means obsolete and out-of-order only – not to mention that the water drained away slowly in the bath tub when you have a shower.  

Also, don’t mix this High Line Hotel up with the Standard High Line Hotel which I had stayed before.  For the latter one, I am happy with its services and hardwares.

title: Fantastic location, home away from a home.
text:
My family went back East to visit my sister this past summer - I was in town visiting from Vietnam - and we decided to stay at The High Line Hotel. Fantastic location. Beautiful gardens, a nice outdoor bar for well poured summer cocktails in the heart of Chelsea. A quick stroll down to the Chelsea market and well, pretty much a stone's throw from a wide variety of good eats, galleries, bars and markets. 

The rooms were very nice - almost like a friends home in the Pacific Northwest. I knew there was a reason I hadn't shaved my beard! It looked classic - it felt classic - it smelled classic. There is a nice coffee shop in the communal/"check-in" area that makes delicious iced coffee and offers small bits as well I believe. 

The rooms are comfy. The staff is very friendly. The vibes are warm. The location is grand. Overall, highly recommend staying here for a few nights in the city.

title: Cozy & Cool
text: This very cool in Chelsea is conveniently located close to the Highline and the West Side hwy. It's in an old abbey and beautifully restored. There's no real restaurant in the winter, but they do have a coffee bar that becomes a bar at 6 pm. I'm not a huge fan of the "no front desk, paperless" system, but check in was relatively painless as there was only one person to handle everything. Prepare to stand in line if you arrive at a busy time! The hotel is beautiful though and we loved our very cozy room 25. Super comfy bed and linens. We had everything we needed!

title: Great location, cool space
text: My wife picked this hotel for a birthday getaway. It is a very cool space. The room was clean and a decent size by NY standards. The hotel is situated near many restaurants and is very close to the Highline (obviously) as well as Chelsea Markets and the Meat packing District. Courteous, helpful staff and good coffee!

title: An amazing Birthday weekend spent here!
text: We spent our birthday here this past weekend and had an amazing stay! This hotel is in the heart of Chelsea and near all the best bars, restaurants, and clubs. The hotel is a beautiful boutique hotel that from the second you walk in you can feel the passion that was put into the design and feel of this hotel which brings it to life. The staff is beyond friendly, they go above and beyond to make you feel at home. You are greeted by the amazing staff from the minute you step out of the cab to your check in and from every encounter in between. The rooms are beautiful with one of a kind touches and the beds are the MOST comfortable I have ever slept in. The coffee shop in the lobby is delicious, I would 100% recommend stopping by if you are in the Meat packing area. You will not go wrong if you choose to stay at this amazing hotel for your next stay in New York City!!

title: Unique, Exciting, Great Location. Rooms are Luxurious, Bar and Courtyard a big plus.
text: It was a wonderful experience. The rooms were just lovely and plush with the right amount of amenities. The staff were friendly and helpful. The bar is a real treat. Unfortunately, I won't be staying there again. My friends and I go to the city, and I thought I had found a real gem to book rooms again and again. The issue is this: I left my black hat and gloves in Room 22 when I departed on 12/22. I called immediately to see if they had been found. I spoke to the person in Lost & Found. He said they were on his list as having been found. He took my name, address and credit card number so he could mail them to me. To date,1/23, I've still not received them. In between 12/22 and now, I had to call the hotel several times to no avail. My second call got me transferred to the Manager,Valerie who said she would look into it and call me back. She never did. I called again and spoke to Alvin who was very helpful. He spoke to the person in Lost and Found who told him my hat and gloves were still on the list as being found. They would be sent to me, yet again, after he spoke to Valerie about charging the mailing cost to the hotel since I told him that Valerie offered this to me the only time I spoke to her. I was given no explanation as to why the items weren't sent to me after the first time I called. No hat and gloves yet. I called again on 1/12 or 1/13, I was transferred to Valerie's voicemail. I left her a message. As of today, 1/23, no call from Valerie and no hat and gloves. What am I supposed to think? Clearly, two people told me the items were found and they would be sent to me. So, were they really not found (weird), have they been misplaced or did they walk out the door of the hotel. I'm frustrated and angry. This is very poor customer service. The Manager, or someone else, should have at least called me to discuss this. Helen Oless

title: Looking forward to our next visit!
text: My wife and I were married at The High Line Hotel (“The High Line”) on January 16, 2016 and returned on January 16, 2017 to celebrate our anniversary. The High Line distinguishes itself from other boutique hotels in the City as it offers a unique experience of contemporary and timeless. Our wedding reception was held in the majestic Hoffman Hall (The Refectory) which dazzled our guests with its turn-of-the-century Collegiate Gothic architecture. Our stay was equally pleasurable with luxurious finishes in the rooms and a world-class coffee bar (Intelligentisia). When the coffee bar serves its last espresso, it is transformed into one of the City’s best kept secrets; ‘The Bar.’ Complete with a quiet, intimate, low-key patio in the back where you can spend hours (and we have) just enjoying the beautiful décor and a finely crafted cocktail. What could make the experience just a little better? Yes, the staff is attentive and accommodating but The High Line is a dog friendly hotel. For my wife and me, our wedding (and future visits) would not have been complete without our eight year old Chiweenie.

title: time-travel with benefits
text: The High Line Hotel offers the best of the past incorporated into the best of the present.  Of course the future is all around you, too, in the architecture and multitude of galleries.  Service is uniformly attentive without being obsequious, the coffee shop, which allows dogs (dressed for winter during our stay) is a bustling mecca of conversation.  The rooms are "period" without being cutesy.  In short, a delight!

title: Cosy hotel
text:
Cosy hotel on the 10th avenue. Room at the back, deluxe king size room, garden view, nice bathroom with shower, good water pressure. No reception but enough staff to help you in case you need something. 

Will stay here again.

title: One of a kind, personal service!
text:
As a guest who stayed with here as part of a group in January, I'm happy to write this review to let all potential guests know of the OUTSTANDING service we received from Alvin. 
 
While the entire team was exceptionally gracious throughout our stay, on the morning of check out, Alvin went above and beyond to take care of our group. 
 
After noticing that we were all requesting to store our luggage until our afternoon departure from JFK, Alvin proactively offered to coordinate a SUV for our group that would start at the hotel so that he could load all of our bags without needing us to be there. This was huge for us, as we had nearly a full day of meetings planned. He then sent the car to our office where we were picked up with ease, our bags having already been loaded. 
 
Prior to meeting Alvin, I was worried about how we would get from our meeting back to the hotel to get our bags in time to get a car to JFK. But Alvin handled this all seamlessly for us, even offering his personal cell phone number in case we encountered any changes in plans. He promptly confirmed all of the services and everything ran exceedingly smoothly. The driver he sent was equally as helpful, which was appreciated. 
 
Alvin is a gem - in all of our days of travel we rarely run into someone as proactive, thoughtful and caring as him. 
 
Thank you for a great stay!

title: Great experience!!
text: I will stay here again and again. I didn't not take advantage of the coffee bar downstairs.  The stay includes access to a gym for working out.   Great restaurants nearby.  Chelsea market is amazing for shopping and food.  A must go to.

title: The perfect getaway for New Years Eve in a charming part of the city
text: We decided to stay at the High Line Hotel for our New Years Eve due to its charm, proximity to great restaurants in Chelsea, and cozy atmosphere for the holidays. We are blown away by the decor, atmosphere, and experience as a whole! We stayed in room 13 and had a beautiful view of the 25 foot Christmas tree in the front courtyard, as well as patio hanging lights at night. The room had a charm of its own, with a fireplace, unique collection of books, antique desk and charming fixtures and furniture, with the modern amenities of a luxury hotel. The charm of Chelsea and warmth of Intelligentsia fresh-brewed coffee in the morning makes it a guaranteed spot for us to return during a future holiday. I strongly recommend it for couples looking for a getaway. You won't be disappointed with the High Line Hotel!

title: Charming with a Neighborhood Feel
text: This hotel was perfect for a Christmas week trip with my teen daughter. We had a cozy, comfortable room on the fifth floor appointed with antiques and interesting architectural elements. The hotel was beautifully decorated for Christmas with a lovely tree out front and festive music playing in the lobby. There was always a hustle and bustle of neighbors, many with their dogs, in the lobby for coffee during the day and cocktails in the evening. The concierge was very helpful with reservations and recommendations. The price was reasonable for New York, and we walked to dinner and lunch. The Chelsea Market is just two blocks away. For those wanting a close subway station, it's a bit of a hike, but we didn't mind walking. I've stayed in Times Square and near Rockefeller Center before, which is fun, but also very crowded and touristy. This hotel has a slower pace and more of a neighborhood feel. We really enjoyed our stay and would return.

title: Cosy with atmosphere but nonfunctional
text: This hotel looks traditional  romantic and cosy with rooms fit for a photo shoot on tumbler or instagram.  We stayed here with a group of family members who chose this hotel .  Our group  was 3 adults 1 teen and 1 baby 14months.  We were housed on the top floor together for 5 nights which was very good in a quiet area .    The rooms were very "wow" on arrival and very clean. Beds comfortable with a feather soft topper but personally I prefer a firm pillow not mushy feather pillows.   But I can't praise much more.   The heating was too warm / stuffy and even though it was winter we had the window open most days and nights and heating off.    The room had too many impracticle ornaments which just got In the way especially with a young toddler both rooms totally impractical with Sharpe corners and ornaments  .  The  mini bar was so overstocked with alcohol and junk food even a lovers kit which my teen daughter thought hilarious.   The fridge was so full we had to remove cans to fit in a tub of  yoghurt.    There was no wardrobe in our room  but a clothes rack which was ok and 2  small drawers  and nowhere to store luggage.  The bathroom was nice looking and clean however the lighting was useless and seemed to have 2 globes above mirror which grew brighter the longer the light was turned on but this took all day and night and if the room maid turned the light off then start the process again.  We resorted to using the torch on my mobile phone to get a bit of decent lighting to apply makeup etc.   This hotel has no breakfast room but does have a coffee /bar for guests and non guests which I found crowded in the small space and unfriendly with people watching you  .  A family member   commented that the coffee was too strong but I did not use.   The location of the hotel is in Chelsea close to the highline, markets and a supermarket.  The nearest subway is 23rd street on 8th ave  which is a good 10 minute walk which becomes tedious when out sightseeing everyday.  The nearby restuarants are very good especially the Park.  I wouldn't have chosen this hotel based on previous  not so good reviews   which for me were confirmed and for the location but as a family member chose, I went  along with the choice.  I would recommend the hotel for a romantic couple weekend getaway but not for family or more than a short stay.

title: Their lobby
text:
The High Line has a warm inviting lobby where you can get cappuccino or my favorite their hot chocolate as well as a snack. 
In good weather you can sit outside. A great meeting place. It is a very well-kept and well-managed hotel.

title: The High Line Hotel Made My Holiday!
text: Last minute visit to NYC pre-holidays became a real treat with a complimentary upgrade from HLH to an amazing suite!
