Getting dressed to go down to a (fair) coffee shop is not ideal in the morning.  The beds are very comfortable, but expect quite a bit of noise from the street (the snowplows were LOUD.  I don't mind this in NYC, but a big chain is your answer if you want soundproofing).  The location is extremely lovely, quite near the high line itself.  But the food options are slim, especially for breakfast (due to the lease they have, unfortunately, that's out of the control of the hotel.  I did have pizza delivered one night without a problem).  Finally, the water quality is fairly poor--I addressed this with the hotel staff shortly after I discovered it and they were going to investigate.  With attention to more details and working around some of the glitches, this could be a fabulous place.

title: Excellent
text:
Seconde fois que je viens à cet hotel (à chaque fois 4/5 nuits) , et toujours une expérience parfaite :
- chambre très confortable : décoration pointue qui me plait beaucoup, excellente insonorisation, lit très grand et très agréable (avec même un surmatelas très moelleux), beaucoup de pression dans la douche, produits de toilettes supers
- hotel très cosie : le café le matin et le soir est un must pour l'ambiance et le goût, la décoration de l'extérieur très chaleureuse, le wifi est rapide et ne nécessite pas de connexion à un portail
- personnel charmant et efficace : pour réserver un taxi, faire visiter des chambres, servir le café, faire le check in et le check out...
- situation idéale : en plein Chelsea, tout près du Meat Packing et du Village

I'll come back here next time!

title: A uniquely peaceful way to experience Chelsea & NYC
text: We stayed for a 40th birthday with toddler in tow. It was by far our favorite NYC stay. Intelligentsia coffee bar on the ground floor is great, hotel staff and customer service is super. The look, feel and atmosphere of the hotel is so unique that though it is clearly a splurge, it was worth it. Hotel is just steps away from the High Line and Chelsea Market.

title: The hotel was unique with a all the right amenities.
text: The Hotel was a treat. I hadn't heard about the park in the sky, high line which the hotel is named so accurately. It was a great stay with good space and ambience. I'd recommend the hotel to friends and family. There is a great restaurant across the street called the cook shop.

title: Like being at home, but better
text: Unlike many Manhattan hotels, this one is properly friendly, low key, relaxed and welcoming. The staff genuinely make you feel at home. The rooms are beautiful, quiet, cosy and spacious (I've stayed here often, always true) and the lobby is busy with great coffee and dog visitors. I spend half my year in New York and the High Line is always my first choice.

title: Anniversary Trip
text: EXCELLENT hotel.  The decor is fantastic, the employees are super friendly and helpful.  This hotel is unlike any hotel I have ever stayed in.  Our room was quite small but it was so nicely done and comfortable that we didn't even notice the size!  The coffee bar in the lobby is quite good and very popular!  Location is incredible!  The high line is right across the street, many cool shops and places to eat.  A few blocks down is the Chelsea Market.  Such a cool part of the city.  We absolutely loved it and would definitely stay there again.  As we were checking out, they walk you through the bill to make sure everything is correct.  I haven't found that to be the norm and thought that final touch was very nice.  HIGHLY recommend The High Line Hotel!!!!!

title: Nice, cosy and quiet
text:
During a business trip I stayed here for 5 nights. It is a great hotel, beautiful from the outside as well as from the inside. Nice room, with a very old feel, but with modern day comfort: a large, very soft bed, and a Bluetooth loudspeaker to hook your smart phone or computer to, amongst the many amenities (free Wi-Fi! No password!). My room was facing the courtyard (and terrace), which was really very quiet, probably because of the winter cold, but the streets surrounding the hotel weren't too busy either.
The only downside to the High Line Hotel is the lack of a restaurant. There is a coffee counter, very posh and stylish, with all the right coffees for hipsters and such, but not the place for me to eat my breakfast, continental or not. There is no room service either. Breakfast, lunch and dinner should be had somewhere else, which is okay if you wanted to explore the city anyway.
I didn't hear my neighbors, but maybe there weren't any. So, apart from the jetlag, I could sleep well.

title: great visit
text: A number of family and friends got together in Chelsea for a celebration. We stayed at the High Line for its convenience. What we found was a very cool hotel that had architectural history as well as everything we needed. The staff was continuously helpful. The lobby coffee bar a welcome spot.

title: Exceeded our expectations!
text: My boyfriend and I enjoyed a delightful stay just after New Year’s Eve at the High Line Hotel.  The lack of reception desk didn't divert us from a thoughtful and prompt check in process.  We were shown to the elevator to get to our room, which was on the top floor overlooking the gardens.  The room was quite a bit more spacious than I had anticipated, and all the amenities were so well thought out.  The décor was perfectly suited to the room space, and we loved the door fixtures and black trim!  Did not even look for a thermostat, the room was at perfect temperature all night, no fan noise or anything!  We had coffee in the lounge downstairs, and enjoyed walking to the High Line in the morning, had it been warmer we would have taken advantage of the road bikes for guest use.  Our next stay in New York will most definitely be here!

title: Pretty Good Choice
text: This hotel is a converted seminary. And it's been converted nicely. The rooms are spacious (by New York standards) and comfortable. The room's climate control worked well. The bed was large and soft, with superior linen and comforter. Fridge worked well, but there was no ice bucket in the room. In truth, I have only two negatives: 1) a five block walk to the nearest subway station, and 2) the faucet in the bathroom. This is one of those that operates via a sensor. Put your hand under and get some water ... sometimes cold, sometimes warm, sometimes scalding! No control. The only other places I've seen these are in restrooms at airports. Why here? Is water use an issue? I hated this faucet. Finally, I must say that the staff were VERY helpful and friendly.

title: Very comfortable "pension" type hotel.
text:
All that you could want in a small cosy hotel. When in New York again it will be a first choice. 
Well located near all attractions. Shopping just round the corner on 5th Avenue. 
A little piece of heaven.

title: Exceptionally charming and hospitable
text:
From the minute we pulled up to this historic building and were greeted by a helpful young man who greeted us and took our bags, to the friendly reception staff who checked us in quickly, we were impressed by the professionalism and genuine desire to please of every member of the hotels's staff. Our room was super comfortable with real period charm that could not be reproduced by a chain and every modern covenience. We had a plush king size bed with high quality linens, a real desk, comfortable armchairs and lovely velvet curtains that kept out morning light. A beautiful armoire provided plenty of storage and even had an ironing board and two umbrellas which luckily we didn't need. This thoughtfulness and concern for guests is clear in very aspect of the hotel. Our bathroom was beautiful with oversized luxurious towels and plenty of amenities. We had no problems with water. Free wifi was super fast.
We loved the garden and outdoor space and because the weather was relatively mild we were able to enjoy our coffee on the rear terrace in December.
The hotel is well situated with so many wonderful restaurants nearby, including Cookshop across the street and Empire Diner two blocks away, that we didn't feel the need for anything beyond the terrific lobby coffee bar.
The Highline entrance across the street make sit a wonderful way to experience this unique part of the city.
Highly recommended.

title: A second chance for The High Line
text: I recently reviewed the High Line and my original review stated that my stay was not a good experience.  I received a call from the general manager, Mr. Daeppen wanting to hear my concerns about the hotel and during my stay.  I feel mr. Daeppen listened to all the issues we had during our stay and that he will make positive changes to ensure the guests have a positive experience and do not encounter the issues we had.  In certain circumstances, I truly believe a person/place should have the opportunity to correct their mistakes and to give people a second chance.  I will be giving the High Line a second chance and visiting the hotel again in 2015.

title: Great staff, Great Location, Great room, HORRIBLE water issues!!!
text: The hotel staff was delightful, the location great, and the bedding wonderful.  But.....  Someone thought it would be clever to use automatic faucets so you could not adjust the water temperature.  Depending on the wafter usage in the hotel it ran from ice cold to steaming hot and some times warm.  The staff was very nice and allowed us to change rooms, but this did not help!  We still had water temperature issues.  This is a deal breaker.  Basic comfort features are a must, and it does not matter how cute the rooms are or how great the staff is if you cant get a drink of water or start the sower without burning yourself.  For the price we paid, we should be able to adjust the water temperature.

title: Lots of character near the High Line
text:
My wife an I stayed at the High Line hotel while we were going to an opening at one of Chelsea's many art galleries.  My wife is a gardener, and was wanting to see the elevated High Line gardens. One of the entrances to the High Line is just across the street, so it was a very convenient location for us.  

The hotel has a great deal of charm.  It is a converted dormitory from the seminary that is still next door.  That gives the rooms tons of character, with all the old architectural features. We had a deluxe room on the back of the hotel, which was overlooking a grassy courtyard between the hotel and seminary.  That helped us avoid the sound of traffic you would get on the front.  

There isn't a reception desk in the lobby.  There is instead a nice coffee place.  You are checked in by a staff member with an ipad.

There are plenty of cool places to eat in the area.  

In short, if you are looking to see the High Line, or the galleries of Chelsea then this is a fun, funky place to stay.  We'll be back.

title: Great Staff
text:
Really nice rooms and a fantastic staff.They bent over backwards to accomidate us.Great area,and the walk on the High Line is cool.My only complaints are ,our room for some reason had a automatic faucet in the sink, which was weird.If you showered then brushed your teeth, you were using hot water.My other complaint was the lobby noise,  we were on the first floor, and it was really noisy late at night and in the morning, so book a higher room.The room was spacious and the bed was fantastic.All in all a great place to stay for the $$$

dano

title: Classy
text:
We stayed at the High Line Hotel at the end of October 2014. The hotel is clean, the staff is great and it's full of history. The only downside for us was the noise. Since it is an old hotel, the windows are not well isolated so we could hear the noise from the street plus it was cold. 
Beautiful but expensive!

title: Comfortable, yet exciting. Would love to stay there again!
text:
This hotel is in a fantastic part of NYC, near Chelsea, the High Line and the West Village. The rooms are beautiful, cozy and very aesthetically pleasing. All of the staff were incredibly friendly, as were the other travelers. The type of people that this hotel attracts will make you want to spend hours sitting in the lobby chatting everyone up!

The coffee shop is outstanding; definitely the most freshly brewed cup of coffee I have had in a while. I love the look of the entire hotel. Very boutique and not like any hotel I had ever seen.

The view from the room was of the hustling and bustling street, however it was extremely quiet at night and very easy to fall asleep. The shower was very nice, as was the bathroom. I loved the look and feel of the room and was dying to stay longer. Free wifi and free domestic and international calls- always a bonus. 

The small hotel experience makes the stay very unique and quaint; the service is always quick due to the small number of people staying there.
Everything was better than expected and I am looking forward to staying there again!

title: Great location, gorgeous building, lovely rooms
text: Now if only we could add efficiency. We arrived at 2pm,  granted slightly before check in, and were told rooms would be ready in 20 minutes. Fine, we went to have lunch. Returned an hour later to hear, rooms would be ready in twenty minutes. Left again to go shopping. Returned at 5pm and yes, told the rooms would be ready in twenty minutes. It's now after 6pm,this is a one night stay and special treat for our daughters for the holidays and we're now piled into one available room to get ready for our dinner. The attitude about the whole deal is indifferent and 'what's the big deal' . We were given a brunch voucher, sadly we won't be able to use it.

title: Nice but lacks amenities
text: Great building, very nice interesting rooms.  Convenient location for Chelsea and west village. Easy access to the high line park and Hudson River views .  Two problems the hotel as yet yo resolve - no food service except and overpriced yuppy coffee stand and very quirky, slow and clumsy check in process.  In particular the slow checking system is really bad in a city that prides itself on speed and efficiency.  The lack of a good restaurant is annoying but we hope this will improve in the future .  There really  is no lobby, just a space with a few benches, a chair and standup overpriced not very good coffee.  There are other choices in the neighborhood.

title: Change from Chains
text: Wanting a different experience we decided to enjoy our annual Christmas shopping trip away from the main stays.  We were not disappointed.  Christmas music greeted us in the outside courtyard, adorned with a glorious 15 foot lighted tree. Entering the front door there is a busy coffee bar with lots of people and their dogs relaxing. The check in station is a small alcove to your right. Our rooms were not ready, so we checked our bags and set out to walk the High Line, one of Manhattan’s newest attractions, an elevated train track turned into an aerial walking park.  It is a great way to get to Chelsea Market and enjoy a wide range of food choices and gift shops.  It seems Chelsea is the new Soho with over 300 galleries and new apartments popping up all around.  Returning at 4:30 still no room.  We were told it was because we had requested a courtyard view on 5th floor (to avoid street noise).  We finally got to our room at 5:15.  Room 57 is about 12’ by 12 in size’, with dark original hard wood floors covered by a made to look old oriental rug, king bed billowing with a fluffy comforter,  lots of pillows, an old writing desk, rotary telephone and small cabinet with two draws, hidden refrigerator and safe.  A basket of snacks and a wide range of adult beverages for purchase are also in the room.  There was no closet, however a rolling hanging rack was provided.  The bathroom was small but adequate and very clean.  Plenty of towels, toiletries, hairdryer, robe and slippers were in place. Internet is complimentary and we found the connection to be great. There was a 42 inch flat screen TV. Interestingly, no clock or radio. Old books bedside and an odd terrarium enhance the feel you have stepped back in time. Lighting is very dim however. You need to call downstairs for ice to be delivered. The staff is friendly and helpful, particularly Paul.  We enjoyed the neighborhood feel, the small hotel experience (less than 60 rooms) and the really comfortable bed.  I asked Paul and was told rooms 3, 4 and 5 are larger.  We will definitely stay again. My only complaint is the coffee bar's bakery items are NOT good and cocktail service is only a few hours in the afternoon.  I suggest breakfast and cocktails down the street 1 block.

title: No food no bar no cool
text:
What a massive management misfortune. To offer a pseudo wine bar with nothing to eat is short sighted. I wouldn't have stayed here if I knew this. No food? Really? Amazing and stupid.
Not cool not hip not coming back.

title: Great for professionals pre-kids
text:
The High Line Hotel would be fun if you have the right attitude.  I think this hotel is ideal for professionals in their 20s and 30s who don't have kids.  The beds are super comfortable.  The decor in rooms is fun, well done with a touch of retro (like the pencil sharpener with a full cup of High Line pencils).  

However, if you have kids and are looking for a romantic get away weekend, the High Line is not for you.  We had two different suites that both overlooked the back of the building.  It was quiet outside but both suites echoed the noise of the hallway, elevator and stairs.  (Our first suite which was right above the coffee staircase even vibrated with the boiler/heater.)

The management and staff are eager to help and provide high quality service.  (The manager moved our room and left a bottle of wine and a reduction in price from our first night.)  The maintanceman brought us two complimentary cafe lattes when the fire alarm went off in the room next to us at 7am because the fire detector and alarm is too close to the bathroom and those taking a hot shower.)  The personnel have the right service oriented attitude.

The entire general atmosphere from the lobby, to the coffee bar, staff, room and ambiance was: young, modern and hip.  Staying here, I realized in my forties that I guess I am none of these even if I thought I might be.

title: Wanted to love, ended up with Like
text:
Such a cool building. Gorgeous old episcopal school from the 19th century. Awesome landscaping. I was awestruck. 

Until I stayed there.

The rooms are small, with no closet, which I can deal with. They are clean and the beds are great.

However, the lack of public space and services is staggering. There is a tiny! Lobby with a few seats - more of a large mudroom. And that is it. And the only service is intelligentsia coffee. Morning, noon, night.  Pastries and overpriced, off-tasting coffee.

How about some food. Or a newspaper. Or just a place to hang out?

The deal is that if the room has nowhere to sit, the lobby has to supply some relief.  They have the room, but they are monetizing it as conference space.

I'll take a pass.

title: Very nice, but cold, New York City hotel
text:
My wife and I stayed in the hotel for a very brief getaway to New York City. We arrived late (around midnight) on a Thursday night and departed on Saturday morning. The hotel itself is a very nice renovation of an old religious building in the Chelsea neighborhood of New York City. The rooms were decent sized (for New York City) and reasonably well appointed. There was a very small, but comfortable, sitting area and a desk with a queen size bed that barely fit in the rest of the room. The bathroom was small, but up-to-date. The only complaint about the room was that the mattress was quite soft. It's more of a personal preference, but we would rather sleep on a firm mattress.

There is a very nice coffee bar in the lobby of the hotel, but very little space to hang around and enjoy it. Also, the lobby was quite cold in November because The doors on either side of the lobby opened to the outside (without any vestibule) creating a wind tunnel effect in the lobby.

The location is great – accessible to the Highline, the Chelsea market and lots of other places to see in the neighborhood. It is also quite accessible to the train. We drove down from Boston and there was a parking lot available across the street for $32 per day (not bad).

We had some friends stay at the hotel a couple months before we did and they complained about loud construction noise – this was not an issue for us at all, perhaps the construction project that bothered her friends had been completed.

The staff was very friendly and overall, our experience was quite positive with the hotel. We might not return soon, simply because there are so many other great places to see in the city.

title: Wonderful find and VERY dog friendly!
text:
This was my first stay at the High Line Hotel and I must say, it delivered fabulous in every aspect. The staff could not have been friendlier or more helpful. The room was well done, the bed very comfortable, and clean. 

My dog was treated like a princess, dog bones with lots of love. 

We will be back. Thank you for a great stay!

title: Great find...AND Dog Friendly!
text:
The gothic exterior of this erstwhile seminary boarding house belies the slick and chic updating within. 

We were greeted by the doorman who ushered us into a lobby that resembled a lounge for hipster extras waiting for their cue to take their places on a film set. Disorienting at first, until the incredible aroma of hand crafted coffee beverages hits you and you realize that the lobby doubles as a lounge for Intelligentsia Coffee, and these are local denizens enjoying the afternoon. 

Just before being sucked into the coffee scene, you're greeted by the "front desk", which is a small kiosk opposite the barista. That everything Daniel greeted us and proceeded to check us in and direct is to our rooms, while also assuring us that he would find us a table at one of the two hot spots in the neighborhood for dinner. 

We ascended to our room and found it to be a toasty, cozy place, decorated with a loyalty to its origins but with a flat panel tv and new bathroom. The phone was a replica of a 1940s rotary model - who uses these anyway other than to dual zero?!  As we settled in with our dogs - yes this is a pet friendly hotel - Daniel knocked to say we were all set for dinner. I half considered staying in though, popping the cork on the bottle of red wine and nibbling some of the snacks offered for purchase in the room, it was so inviting on a chilly night. 

You can't beat the location of this spot. Between the High Line and lots of great eating places and galleries, there is no shortage of things to do on an weekend whim, a a short walk from the hotel. The coffee, by the way, is quite good. No syrups or trendy drinks here - this is the real deal, seriously prepared coffee, served by serious people that raise the foaming and decorating of milk in your latte to an art form. 

This is a perfect place for an escape from suburbia, even for just a night. I still marvel at how Daniel could have been in so many places at once and serve as a one-man front desk and concierge, but he did so graciously and with enthusiasm.

title: Great for a boutique hotel - mostly because of the staff
text:
I really debated between giving this hotel 3 or 4 stars... wish I could give it 3 and a half. Also note that I think it's really decent for being a boutique hotel, but then I generally think boutique is code for "it's crappy but we'll call it boutique and charge more".  Also note that if you're a hipster, you'll probably think you've died and gone to heaven at this hotel.

So, on with the review. The biggest pro by FAR is the staff. They were nothing short of amazing... so kind and attentive, knew our room number and the details of our reservation. We were truly impressed, and very appreciative that they were so on top of everything. If this review were based on  staff alone, I would enthusiastically give it 5 stars.  Definitely keep in mind that my opinion of the staff does NOT include the staff at the Intelligentsia coffee bar located in the lobby. I'll reserve a later paragraph to tell you all about those special folks.

First impressions: The first impression of the room is that it was much nicer than we anticipated. The staff member mentioned to us that all of the rooms in the hotel are different. Ours was very nice... plenty of space, two large closets, huge bathroom, wood floors, felt very homey.

Noise: The room we got, room #10, is on the first floor and looks directly out the front of the hotel onto the street. We voiced a bit of concern to the staff about the potential noise, and they assured us that if there were any issues, they'd see about changing our room. And truly, everything seemed fine, we couldn't really hear any street noise, and we assumed the other trip advisor reviews we read were being a bit too picky. We went to bed that night and slept soundly - until 2:00 am when the garbage got collected. Scared the crap out of us! Loud banging noises, people yelling as the dumpsters got lifted up and emptied into the truck.. there was truly no attempt by the garbage people to even be a tiny bit quiet. We didn't say anything about it to the staff, but it happened every single night between 1:30am and 2:30am, and there was truly no way to sleep through that. By the end of our stay, the husband and I were sort of resigned to it, but I would seriously recommend getting a room that doesn't point toward the street.

Heat: We are pretty sure that the heat control in our room was nothing more than a placebo. You can control how fast the fan blows, but there did not seem to be any control whatsoever over whether hot or cold air was blowing. Keep in mind that it was unseasonably cold in NYC last week, impossible to go outside without scarf, gloves and big fluffy coat. Our room was so warm that by the third night, we ended up cracking a window to be able to get the room cool enough so that we could sleep (which made the 2am garbage truck even more of a nightmare). Again, we did not say anything to the staff because we figured there probably isn't much they can do if that's how the heat system is set up. Also worth noting, my husband's coworker staying in the same hotel mentioned that he had absolutely zero heat in his room and was freezing the whole time.

Bathroom: nice and big, tiled floors, has a bathtub. The water pressure is absolutely incredible. Gigantic wonderful towels. Just two nitpicky things here - there were wafts of strange smells in our bathroom. Almost like maybe the bathroom was cleaned with a dirty sponge or mop. Or possibly this is just how bathrooms in old buildings smell? The other thing is that there wasn't an extra roll of toilet paper, and we ended up running out. We didn't get cleaning service every single day, so perhaps this is our own fault, but I've never actually stayed in a hotel room that doesn't have at least one extra roll of TP available.

Bed: The bed was fine - not the worst hotel bed I've slept on and not the best. Felt like a spring mattress with a feather bed on top of it. Totally functional. We always travel with out own pillows because we never like hotel pillows, so no comment there.

Now, as for the staff at the Intelligentsia Coffee stand inside the lobby. Oh boy. They were awful. Keep in mind that the husband and I are total coffee snobs and were actually excited about staying in a place that offered Intelligentsia pour-overs. At home, we subscribe to freshly roasted beans and always make our own pour-overs, so we can appreciate a little snobbery in this area considering that it takes actual talent to pour a good cup. We know it takes 5 minutes to do a good pour over and weren't concerned about it being speedy. The problem is, the staff at the coffee bar have all of the attitude and snobbery and none of the talent that goes into making a stellar cup of coffee. After the second day with the same crappy cup of coffee, I gave up ordering pour-overs and opted for lattes instead which were much better. But the staff are astounding - they just come across as lazy lazy lazy. Reluctant to take an order, no real appreciation for their product, but tons of better-than-thou attitude, and the only interest they seemed to have in their job was chatting with co-workers. They truly make you feel like you are inconveniencing them for wanting a cup of coffee. Not cool.

So, those are the things that stand out in my mind. I'm assuming you all already know that the location is great, good neighborhood, easy access to all of Manhattan, etc, etc. 

After talking to other folks staying at the hotel, I think whether or not you are happy here will depend entirely on which room you get (not pointing at the street) and whether or not your heater works. The hotel staff are truly a joy though and I can't say enough positive things about them.

title: Charming and friendly service
text: I was upgraded to a larger room upon checkin.  The staff was transparent in telling me that although the room was larger, it was right off the lobby and I could be woken up in the morning by the smell of the coffee bar in the morning.  I decided to take the room anyway.  It was quite roomy, but like others said, the lighting is very dim even with all the lights turned on.  Because the heating unit was quite loud and there was a dehumidifier in the room (which in November was quite interesting - makes you wonder how humid the room is in the summer), there was enough "white noise" in the room that I couldn't hear much of the coffee grinder or people in the hallway.  The bed was extremely plush and comfortable.  I thought the setting was very charming overall, since it used to be a refectory/monastery.  But because of the lighting, I probably wouldn't stay here again.

title: Great value for NYC
text: The High Line is a fairly new Chelsea hotel built on the site of the former dormitory for the General Theological Seminary;  the developers retained the feel of the gothic structure and therefore, to me, it's just beautiful.  The price can be right too;  we paid $320 (all in) per night, although prices vary.  We're walkers, and so walking an hour to theater or other midtown venues is fine with us; anything to avoid staying midtown.   Intelligentsia runs a fantastic espresso bar with really, really nice baristas in the lobby, and there's plenty of indoor and outdoor seating (if you don't mind rubbing shoulders with a preponderance of small dogs).  The good news is that you too can bring your dog for a sleepover if you so desire.   Here are the downsides:  1) the lobby is downright cold because of the draft from the front doors.   2) The lighting in the room is too dim, especially in the bathroom. Unless you are about 18 years old and have excellent eyesight, I would not attempt to put make-up on in here.  3) The bathroom door gets in the way and if you want to dry your hair in front of the mirror, you will have a view of exactly half of your head.  4) This is most important to me: the bed is too, too soft.  Even my husband, who can sleep, upright, through Armageddon, complained this morning that his back was sore. 5) The coffee bar is only open from 5-9 pm at night;  I think it'd be nice to hang around for a drink after a show.  6) Only one ADA room and the outside courtyard (which beckons invitingly, were it warm outside) is not accessible.  But, I must reiterate, the price, location and ambiance make this hotel completely worthwhile for a return trip, in my estimation.  I would give it a 3 and 3/4 star if possible.

title: Stepping Back in Time at The High Line Hotel Chelsea NYC
text:
Room on Courtyard side fairly quite. Lighting in room dim, bathroom small and tight  but adequate. Bed comfortable. All Wood Floors with Oriental Rug. Elevator. Has an older classy Charm in décor. Many other rooms all different configurations. Step Back in Time Lovely Feel but not enough area for clothing and toiletries No Counter space or Dresser. One Closet with no suitcase butler. 
Double, Singles etc. with some sitting areas. 
 
NO RESTURANT on premises only coffee bar in entrance foyer. Would have justified the cost of room per night with a resturant and other amenities. 

High Line walkway outdoors with areas to sit.  Parking area Edison Park across street which stacks cars not a garage. Close to Chelsea Piers. Would not recommend for family with kids. VERY BUSY area.

title: West side gem
text:
We spent three nights in early November - not long enough!  This hotel is in a great neighbourhood, right across from the High Line.  We had a deluxe on the corner of 20th and 10th Avenue.  Next time I'll be sure to request a courtyard room as our room was pretty noisy, in spite of being on the 4th floor.  Lots of traffic day and night so we were glad we packed earplugs.  

The ground floor is by and large a coffee shop - Intelligentsia.  Make sure you're not rushed for coffee as it's definitely worth the wait.  Shame there isn't more seating as it does have an air of being a bit of a locals hangout - giving it a nice vibe, but it's short on space for hotel guests who want to sit out somewhere other than their room.   

Very comfortable beds - we slept like babies - with earplugs ;-)  
Nice Bigelow toiletries and linens.

There is no in-hotel dining but some great local options, like Cookshop across the street.  La Lunchonette (sadly closing in 2015) just to nama a couple of places.  23rd Street a couple of blocks up so public transportation is a breeze.

We'll definitely be back.

title: Charm but not comfort
text: We have stayed here several times as we have family to visit in the neighborhood.  Location great, ambiance nice, bell staff wonderful. The rooms are small and there is no counter space in the bathroom.  The dim lighting in the bedroom is unacceptable.  Since the only mirror is in the bathroom, I had to lay out toiletries and cosmetics on the desk and carry individual items into the bathroom to use.  The shower has multiple hold bars and a fold-down seat, but the small size of the bathroom would make it difficult for a wheelchair user.  We stay here when the price is right!

title: Love the High Line
text: Wonderful charming boutique hotel close to amazing restaurants and so many fun NY experiences (have to check out the High Line walk).  Huge rooms for New York City.  Cozy beds and such helpful staff.  Love!

title: Comfy, vintage property, but noisy on first floor
text:
First time staying here, and would do it again but wil request a higher floor.  The check in was strange as they don't have a reception area.  Instead, the 'doorman'/front desk reception staff greeted me upon arrival, and at my confused look explained he was the check in guy, using only an ipad.  he gave me the key and sent me on my way; I actually like hotels that don't escort you to your room (I don;t need someone to show me how to turn on a TV), but it did feel a little like a holiday inn in that sense.   The building is old and recently converted into a hotel; the style and decor are very cozy and comfy, elegant with a touch of a vintage.  My room was very comfy although the pillows were too thick, thus upsetting an otherwise good night's sleep.  

Another upsetting factor to my sleep was my proximity to the hotel's coffee shop, which occupies what would normally be the reception area.  And it was directly across from my room.  Thus, I heard the line of mostly non-hotel guests (and seemingly New York's coolest hipster set) queuing for their $5 coffees,   The smells and noises wafted into my room at an early hour both days, and woke me up.  That was not pleasant for me, and I would never stay in that area again.  There was also noise from the street in early mornings and late nights.  And more noise from guests returning to their rooms late night too....the walls seem very thin.

title: Great break with two teens
text:
Comfiest bed I have ever slept in EVER.
 
We stayed here for a week in Autumn half term, with my two daughters 11 & 13.
Its a great place to stay to explore the city, we loved the neighbourhood, the local diners, chelsea market and the high line. It makes a welcome change to the hectic corporate world of midtown staying in a residential area.
The STAFF are out of this world helpful and friendly and the room - a twin double - was ample for the four of our needs (they have very large bathrooms, massive closets, Irons, ironing boards yada yada) . So top marks, the only mild suggestion I have is more towel hooks please. The coffee shop is Tres cool also!! Bx

title: Awesome!
text: Staff was super nice and helpful.  Room was huge for NYC.  Great experience!  Needed a late night dinner suggestion after arriving at 9:30 and they steered me to a great nearby location.  Provided umbrellas due to rain, and made every accommodation.

title: Excellence beyond measure.....
text:
We recently celebrated my daughters wedding (Hass-Walters Wedding) in The Refectory at The High Line Hotel.  I also had a nine-day stay at The High Line Hotel as wedding plans proceeded, guests arrived, and the wedding event flawlessly took place in this beautiful hotel.
 
I would like to thank the following staff members who attended to every small detail, day in and day out, for nine days.  Each time I entered the lobby in the early morning, or late evening, the staff was waiting with a smile and an offer to help.  Very professional, but more, truly caring.
 
Michelle, Teresa and Alex (amazing).....Natasha K and Natasha R, Micheal, Daniel, Rahman, Gabriel, Brandon, John, Juan, Fazl and Tidi................I thank each of you for your personal help, friendship, and such a lovely stay.
 
Sherry Hass
Austin, TX

title: Amazing find in NYC
text: I booked a room for my parents when they were visiting as it's the closest hotel to my apartment. What an unusual hidden gem. My parents loved it. The charm level is sky high (and the prices are really decent for New York City) - an old red brick church building converted to a small hotel and each of the rooms are furnished with original antiques and old rugs. It is architecturally very stunning and unusual. The rooms are huge by New York City standards and the bathrooms are giant. My parents' room overlooked a garden with huge old trees. There is an outdoor restaurant under a canopy of trees and gas lanterns and with a fountain in the middle and it is so incredible! We didn't have dinner there but did have a glass of wildly expensive Champagne. The location for me was perfect as it was near our apartment but for tourists I don't know...depends what you are looking for. It is far from the subway (two long east-west blocks) and not near any "tourist attractions" (except the High Line which is right across the street and probably the best thing to see in New York City today). But it's in the middle of a trendy neighborhood with tons of great restaurants and art galleries, more of a "locals" experience in a fantastic New York neighborhood! Would definitely have my parents stay here again!

title: Diferente e confortável
text: Hotel boutique muito interessante. Não tem dois quartos iguais. Decoração muito bem feita e com móveis antigos. Você se sente habitando uma casa do início do século passado. No entrando é muito confortável e caro. Não é um hotel  comum. Não tem restaurante, mas como você está em NY, o último lugar onde cai querer jantar é no hotel.

title: I hope my memory fades quickly!
text:
Firstly, do not expect any Valet Parking, or anyone to be outside the hotel for that matter. I had to wait with the car while my wife searched around the entrance for somebody to help with our bags. There is no Front Desk by the way, and the employees do not wear any discerning clothes or name tags. They all look like guests wondering around paying no attention who comes and goes. Hint: look for the very young person wearing jeans and a sweater holding a walkie-talkie.  There is a computer terminal in a cabinet which is where you may find a person staring into. 

Needless to say we were told that we could not check-in until exactly 3:00pm, and we could just come back then because the “Housekeeping” was very busy. 

We were very disappointed with our weekend stay here. We reserved a "Deluxe" room, upgraded from their "Standard" room for the night. What we got was a tiny room not more than 250 SqFt with a large bed, desk and a completely useless love seat couch. It is impossible to sit comfortably on this thing because there is no back to it! The bathroom was extremely tiny. Only one person could occupy it at a time. Lighting was minimal and my wife had to use her iPhone light to see! There was no closet, only a Wardrobe cabinet that also was extremely small. 

This room was on the first floor facing 10th Ave, and the outdoor public restaurant/bar. It was very noisy. You could look right into our room from the outside. In addition the lights from the building were directed directly into the room. When I inquired about a change in rooms, I was told that none were available and in fact this was a “Deluxe” room, and every room was different.
I was also concerned with security at this hotel. The “lobby/coffee bar” area and bathrooms are open to the public. Anyone can come and go and in fact there was a long line waiting opposite the elevators for public bathroom use. The staircase next to the coffee/bar is completely accessible to the floor above, right opposite our room! ANYONE can come and go without question.
I’m not sure why this is so poorly run. Very amateurish. I get the “Boutique” or “Bed and Breakfast” thing, but at $500/nite this is not a “Bed & Breakfast” property. (No breakfast offered, BTW).

Overall, a very disappointing experience. There other GREAT choices nearby for you to consider.

title: comfortable bed and great coffee.
text: Small, cute, and friendly staff.  The bathroom was tiny,  but the room was a decent size by NY standards.  The bed was super comfortable - a huge plus in my opinion.  Intelligentsia is right in the lobby, and the outdoor space is a great place to read.

title: Luxury Excellence at its BEST!!!!
text:
Exquisite rooms that balance a luxury modern feel crossed with classic ol NYC Glamour all in what used to be a seminary!  

If you'd like a TRUE NYC experience I highly recommend The Highline Hotel in New York City's Chelsea neighborhood.  From the greeting at the curb to the room decor and the staffs amazing attitude I couldn't have asked for a better experience. 

....and you get complimentary access to the Chelsea Equinox.  Talk about value.

title: Limited; but good spot for weekend fun
text:
I spent two nights at this hotel with a friend for a weekend away in New York.  The location could not have been better for a fun weekend trip.  We were able to leave the hotel in the morning and not return until late in the evening and we never had to take a cab.  The room was spacious and modern and the bed was very comfortable.  Since we were only looking for (essentially) a place to sleep it was a good choice.

The hotel was limited in other areas as other travelers have noted.  There is construction going on across the street that prevents sleeping past 7 am on Saturday.  There is not a traditional bell staff, kitchen or business center, which makes it an inconvenient place at times.  I would not be able to achieve about 85% of what I need to do when traveling for work, which means I would not choose it over other perfectly good Midtown options (Palace, W, Le Meredien), but it was a great choice for two girlfriends having fun in NY.

title: Don't Stay Here
text: This is a former seminary masking as a hotel. Tripping over its hipster attitude but missing the point of a good place to sleep. The windows and doors seem to be the same the seminarians endured, so the noise from every car and truck form the street is heard as is every guest and maid in the hall. There is no room service and no breakfast. I've never seen a hotel with no breakfast. I was told to go to the corner restaurant or to the diner down the street. There's a franchise of an Intelligentsia coffee shop in the "lobby" but it took eight minutes to brew a cup of coffee. The "Reception" is a guy standing at a cupboard with a laptop.  Upon checkout, I asked if they could change a bill for the taxi and was told they don't carry cash. What a ridiculous excuse for a hotel.

title: Quaint but Not Quiet
text: If you want to be near the Meatpacking District, this quaint hotel offers a great location, an attractive and popular courtyard (in nice weather) and an interesting history.   But don't expect to sleep in peace.   Hotel room doors readily transmit hallway noises (doors shutting, people chatting, housekeeping staff knocking and working nearby).  And windows don't shield the vibrant sounds of the city -- sirens, construction equipment and trucks beeping to back up.   If you like a full-service hotel, this isn't it --  with a cramped entry, no lobby, no indoor bar, no room service, and no onsite breakfast (except a painfully slow coffee operation -- 9 minutes for my fresh brew).  Friendly doorman aren't enough to compensate.

title: Top-Notch Hotel, Wonderful Staff
text: My wife and I came to New York for a weekend wedding being held at The Highline, a fine boutique hotel in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan. What a wonderful experience! The moment our cab stopped in front of the hotel, the staff greeted us like family. I travel quite a bit for business and rarely receive the warm welcome we got from Daniel, Tidi, Fazl and the rest of the staff. They were not only helpful and polite (expected) but outgoing and playful (unexpected). It was like being greeted at a friend's house. The hotel is part of a former seminary and the architecture is gorgeous. The wedding was held in a beautiful room that looked like a scene out of a Harry Potter movie - in fact another room in the building was used in the movie. We enjoyed ourselves so much that we extended out stay another day. Every single time we met any of the hotel staff we were greeted by name, asked how they could make our stay better and just treated like old friends. As a small business owner, I know the challenges involved in getting, training and retaining good staff. The High Line has figured it out. The staff is excellent. The hotel itself is a gem, close to all kinds of interesting things to do and see. If you're looking for a unique experience for your next visit to New York, give this hotel a try. You won't be disappointed.

title: Great Stay at The Highline
text:
The Highline is a fine boutique hotel in the Chelsea area of NY. Walking distance to Chelsea Markets, restaurants & bars.
More importantly for us, the rooms are extremely comfortable, although a little small, the Staff were outstanding with service, attention to detail & willingness to help.
The Cafe in the foyer offers the best coffee I've ever had in many years of travelling to the USA.

title: An absolutely wonderful hotel
text: The High Line is the most wonderful hotel I can imagine. The rooms are beautifully decorated to maintain the old world comfort, wood-hewn feel of the seminary building. My room overlooking the courtyard was quiet, the bed was wonderfully comfortable, everything was well-kept up and clean--it was a beautiful oasis within NYC. The staff is wonderful, the coffee bar in the lobby is great, the location is great--next to the High Line, Chelsea art galleries, and close to subways. It is the only place I ever want to stay in NYC.

title: Unique Decor, HUGE Room
text:
We really enjoyed our stay at the High Line Hotel.  We arrived hours earlier than check-in and found that our room was already prepared. It was much larger then any standard New York Hotel room we have stayed in thus far.  The bell staff were all very helpful and friendly.  From helping us unload upon check-in, to assisting us with renting bikes they were quick and attentive. 

LOVED: the decor, the amount of space, the comfortable bed, the huge bathroom, the location.

Our only gripe would be the snobbery of the coffee shop (Intelligentsia) staff, although I suppose some people enjoy that type of treatment. 

Overall, a fantastic trip!

title: Old New York in the hippest location
text: Loved the old world charm of this hotel including the details of the furnishings (rotary dial phone!). The dormer windows of my fifth floor room reminded my of the cosy attic bedrooms of my grandparents house. The bed was the most comfy I've ever slept in. I hosted a small business gathering that evening in the outdoor courtyard--lovely (though it got a bit chilly as the night progressed). A hip young crowd (with dogs) lined up to get coffee and croissants downstairs in the morning. Only wish I'd had more time to wander around the neighborhood and see the High Line after which the hotel is named!

title: Бюджетный отель на пару дней
text: Отель без излишеств - минималистский ремонт, но в номере есть душ+туалет, в окне - кондиционер стоит блок, из которого поддувает - приходилось закрывать его покрывалом с кровати. Транспортная доступность - хорошая - немного пройтись до остановки автобуса, а на нем до станции сабвэя рукой подать. Можно прогуляться по Хай Лайну в сторону центра Манхэтэна. Долго жить напрягает, но несколько ночей переночевать не переплачивая за излишние опции - вполне реально.

title: Great hotel that can get greater still
text:
I have just spent a night at the High Line hotel. Overall I have enjoyed my time here but there are a couple things that management/staff could work on to make this place better still.
The good/great: 1. Location, where Chelsea meets Meatpacking with the gorgeous high line on your door step. 2. The interior  design of both the rooms and common areas: beautiful and cosy at the same time. 3. Room size: my standard room must have been around 300sqf, which is generous by NYC standards.
The room for improvement: 1. rooms facing 10th avenue aren't quiet despite double-glazing, and the building works opposite the hotel at present are adding to the traffic noise. 2. Staff (relatively young and hip) do their job, but somehow I felt they lacked warmth and could have made me feel more welcome, perhaps with little else than a smile.

title: Amazing staff, great location, liked the decor - a little loud
text: I really loved The High Line Hotel.  The staff was SO accommodating and pleasant.  The location can't be beat and my room was lovely.  My only complaint is that it was really loud.  I was on the second floor at the corner of 20th and 10th Ave.  I lived in NYC for many years and understand the sounds of the city, but this was too much.  My suggestion would be to request an interior room (if there are interior rooms) or something higher up.  Other than that, great place, would definitely stay again.

title: Wonderful stay - but get email confirmation to avoid discrepancies
text:
Just returned from a one night stay at the High Line.  Really enjoyed the hotel's ambience and retro vibe.  Hotel staff was very helpful and pleasant.  Rooms were a tad on the small side, though perhaps not by NYC standards.  The bathroom was tight and presented me with some difficulty when getting ready for the evening.  A girl needs a place for her toiletries!  Also, when my husband showered, there was absolutely NO hot water.  When we inquired about it on our way to dinner, we were told there had been an issue but that it had already been resolved.  So, I guess just bad luck in timing for him.    Bed was the most comfortable I've slept in EVER.  I also appreciated the well stocked mini bar at reasonable prices.  $2.00 for Twix bar and $5.00 for Fiji water.  Another nice touch wad bottle of wine in our room compliments of the hotel for our anniversary.   Wonderful location close to Higline and Chelsea Market.  
Now the cons (aside from the lack of hot water):  my husband had requested early check in which was not able to be granted.  Ok, I understand there is no guarantee.  When we did check in, I asked if we had a standard King (which we had booked) or a Deluxe King (was hoping for an upgrade since we were celebrating an anniversary).  I was told we had a "Superior King" which I thought might have been an upgrade but turns out was a regular Standard King.  Not sure why there was confusion on the terminology.  Again, the room was lovely, nonetheless.  However, upon check out we found that we were charged $399.  When we booked (several weeks ago) we were told the rate was $340, I believe.  I say I believe, because even after 2 phone calls to request one, we never received an email confirmation.  So, no way to prove discrepancy.  I am certain we did not originally book at $399 because we had a budget.  
Still, all in all, a wonderful stay.  Will be back again!

title: Charming surprise
text: My husband and I stayed at this charming hotel for a pre-cruise stay. We had never been to Chelsea and thoroughly enjoyed everything. We were greeted at the curb and escorted to our unique room where the manager had sent a bottle of wine, knowing it was my birthday. Every employee was friendly and helpful. The room was cool, quiet, clean and comfortable. The recommended carrot cake donut was to die for!!! We would definitely stay again. Thanks to all for a wonderful stay.

title: Great location, funky hotel, nice staff team...
text: We stayed in room 27 1/2...loved the quirk factor of that. Room was small but perfectly serviceable, albeit the bed was a tad soft. Hotel staff super friendly, nice to have the Intelligentsia coffee shop in the lobby. Chelsea's a super location to,operate from for a stay. good restaurants, nice walking, subway close, quiet at night. Loved it.

title: A good place to stay, but not without some minor problems.....
text:
We arrived at our hotel at 2:30pm and it was not ready.  Ok, check in is at 3pm, so we will go have a bite and they will call us when it's ready.  Didn't receive the call and when we got back to the hotel we were told our room was still not ready. We are informed that there is the exact same room on the same floor just down the hall and that it's ready.  I suggest that we be given a late checkout for not having the room ready on time.  She has to talk to her manager, but in the meantime we are given two tokens for free espresso at their coffee shop.  Happy to report they did give us a late checkout. 
Our room was quite nice with a very comfy bed.  The room is small, but adequate.  Very clean.  There was no bath mat and when I called down about this they said, to use a towel.  Ok, but what is strange is that on the day we checked out there was a bath mat.  Also, we were missing a pair of slippers that  is included with the two robes that hang behind the door.  
The staff was friendly and helpful.  Love the atmosphere at this hotel.  They now serve food and drinks on their front patio during the nice weather.  They also have a courtyard in the back to hang out.  You do have to be lucky to get a seat in the courtyard. If it's raining there is some seating in the lobby, but very limited. The elevator is very very slow, so a lot of times I would take the stairs to our room on the 5th floor. 
Location is OK, but there is a bit of a walk to the subway.  I love the idea of being a block away from the High Line and close to the Chelsea Market.  I had read other reviews about people being disappointed that there is not a restaurant in the hotel.  Trust me, there are so many good places to eat close by.  The Cook House across is very good and they serve breakfast, lunch, an dinner.  
Overall, our stay was good, but do expect a few little glitches.  We mainly chose this location for being close to the High Line.  Not sure if I would stay here again if I was going to spend more time in the theater district or interested in other main attractions.

title: IN LOVE
text: We stayed one night and can't wait to go back.  There is absolutely nothing but raves for this hotel.  Location can't be beat, excellent restaurants on every corner..we ate at Scarpetta and it was ridiculously excellent!  Our room though small was all we needed...the coffee shop & the coffee truck outside make an excellent cup..can't wait to go back..worth every penny and more!

title: High Line Hotel has ice!
text: Recently got back from a trip to NYC with my g/f Pam and stayed at the High Line. First, as many have said, the MOST comfortable bed I've ever slept in! Hotel or otherwise! Second, a few unique hotel which is what we were looking for. Lots of quirky items in the room and the hotel itself. Very charming. Third and most important with me.......The staff is excellent!!! Each of them have great attitudes, great sense of humour, and were always asking if I am "enjoying my stay" or if I "need anything, just ask".  I know it's a small thing but it's nice to be looked after when you travel. They did a fantastic job! On a side note, they must've gotten sick of us asking for ice everyday! Thanks again High Line! Looking forward to staying again in the future!

title: original et inoubliable
text:
hotel tres bien place , en plein chelsea , en face du high line .
on fait un voyage dans le temps , les chambres sont decorees avec beaucoup et d originalite  .literie parfaite , et lit immense .personel jeune et moderne

title: They sent back the underwear, thanks for that
text: It's a boutique hotel that has a sense of itself, in a good way. It's not one of those boutique hotels who don't understand that they are Band B's with an overinflated sense of marketing. The coffee bar makes good coffee, not Australian good, but not half bad. It''s a bit of a palaver with all the pouring into different hot bowls and stuff for the tea, but quite mesmeric if you're not in a hurry. The room was a nice cosy size, and attractively organised. There were really really good bottles of whisky, proper sizes, from the mini bar. More of a midi bar really. And, best of all, when my husband left all his underwear in a drawer, they mailed it back, without writing UNDERWEAR on the label. The bar out the front is a good place for social and business meetings, and the service is nice, friendly. The room was a bit overpriced, but that is presumably because it's in Chelsea. Anyway, I liked it.

title: Good but not great
text: Great boutique hotel in the Chelsea district. The location of this hotel was wonderful with plenty of restaurants and bars plus Chelsea market within a short walk. You can use the hotels complimentary bikes and explore the cycle way next to the hudson. Service was in the most part excellent especially from the door men who were very friendly and helpful. A few  issues though, firstly the air conditioning system is not good and our room never cooled down properly. Secondly the guest amenities were not refreshed each day, in fact they were never refreshed and the shampoo ran out. The snack tray also had out of date items.

title: Things go wrong, but they can get worse
text:
Flew up to NYC friday afternoon for a friend''s bday party and a mini anniversary celebration and decided to splurge on the high-line. It was a fast visit, check in at 4 and out at 830 am the next day. 

It's a hot and muggy 90 degrees out and right when we got to our room, we noticed the AC was not functioning. We expressed our concern and we were assured that an engineer would be up to address the problem. We asked to be moved to another room and were told that the engineer had to come up first. So we left our bags packed and went out to see the neighborhood. It is a great area of Manhattan to explore with excellent shopping.  We asked the staff to give us a cal and let us know status (so we can decide if we are going to stay there or not) 

We got back and were told that the engineer had been up and indeed the AC was not working but that they could not move us. They offered us a fan. My husband asked to speak to a manager and waited in the lobby for 20 minutes. At this point we need to get to our friend's party so we start to get ready while our room is basically broiling hot -- it faces the hudson. 

There is no bathmat and we cannot find a hair dryer but no one at the front desk will take our calls now and our multiple calls to inquire about a hair dryer or a fan all roll into a general hotel reservation line.  Still no fan and no manager. The manager shows up after 45 minutes since we first asked and the fan never showed up.  He has nothing new to add but that the engineer is working on the problem and doesn't seem to be aware that we wanted to change rooms the second we stepped into the 80 degree room. News to him. He promises to update us but makes no effort to ease the situation and tells us we cannot be moved bc they are "fully committed" ...still no fan. 

Having stayed in all manner of hotel, I found the level of service and attention here to be JV at best.  I don't think it was too much to ask for an option to change rooms or a  more information when our room was 80 degrees and uninhabitable.

We leave for the party at 7. When we return at midnight, the room seems to be cooler but by no means at the level we would have expected as the ac is marginally functioning. No fan. 

At check-out, all this information is new again to the check-out person who asked cheerfully about our stay at their ultra groovy hotel.  As I explain that our stay was pretty awful and why, she muses about hearing the the AC went down briefly. She offers to call the manager who "might" be able to offer us a credit. 

Since we are on our way to catch a plane and have no real confidence that the manager will show up in a timely fashion, I encouraged her to explain the situation to her manager and would look forward to a response from the hotel. I double checked if she had my email and phone number. 

 That was 8 hours ago and nothing but an email of our bill. Is it now my job to pursue a credit from the hotel? 

So yes the hotel is charming and cool. The room on the 4th floor had a view of the river. The bathroom, however, was TINY, very mad men era, and looked nothing like the picture on the website for a king deluxe room.  Since we had no bath mat, we had to put a towel down, when we took it up to dry it, it was smeared with rust brown gunk from the floor.  The bed was comfy and the sheets were fine. There was free WIFI and a safe and a fridge and a well-stocked mini bar--all the amenities one might expect. 

All in all, it's more like a private room at a youth hostel but with a $500 price tag (room rate was $429-- hurts to even think about it.)

title: Very nice not counting the fire alarm
text: Old church annex reborn as hip luxury midtown hotel. Nice and friendly staff but a very old building means no restaurant, no bar, no gym and no room service. Also a notoriously cranky fire alarm that goes off every other day or so. Wifi is super fast and stable and hassle free (no login). Good coffee and a nice outdoors bar in the front yard (summer only?). One block from the High Line Park.

title: Appearances aren't everything
text:
First the positives: this place doesn't follow the boring design formula beloved of the hotel chains; the interior reflects the previous history of the building and to say that the place has character would be an understatement.
It's location is another positive, particularly if you are not averse to walking; some good dining options very close by which compensates for the lack of an on-site restaurant.
Where things came badly unstuck for us on a recent four night stay was with the level of service. The absence of a reception desk made dealing with staff while standing in the foyer quite awkward - particularly as it never seemed quite clear as to who exactly was in charge of operations.  A person who is indentifiable as the manager would be a useful feature as we had little success dealing with a problem that arose.
On arrival we were assigned a room which could be best described as "compact", lacking any facility to hang clothes - possibly not a major issue if one was staying for a single night but four nights.....?   We were initially assured that, due to the hotel being fully booked on our first night, we could not be reassigned a larger room until the next day.  Upon checking the next morning, the story remained the same - hotel still fully booked, nothing could be done for us.  So there the matter rested and we remained in what was cheekily named Room 36 and a half for our full stay.
What proved to be the most frustrating aspect was the failure of somebody to present themselves as management and explain why the problem could not be dealt with.

title: BEWARE
text:
I specifically booked this hotel for a reunion. We flew in from various locations to meet. Hotel was booked 2 weeks in advance and eight minutes before check in our reservation was cancelled! Manager on location had zero people skills and offered no help or explanation. Upon returning home I called the General Manager and demanded an explanation. He promised to get back . Two emails were sent no reply and no phone call. Three weeks later still no answer!
Do yourself a favor stay somewhere else!!

title: Ottimo
text:
Abbiamo soggiornato in agosto bella camera ottimo servizio molto curato e quartiere bello fuori dall'hotel c'è un camioncino che fa un ottimo caffè intellighenzia volendo ti danno le bici, vicino all'highline molto bello per passeggiare o andare a correre .
Nelle vicinanze ci sono bar e ristoranti carini .

title: Amazing
text: We stayed at the Highline for one night on August 11th. From the moment we arrived we were blown away. Our room was upgraded to the Highline Suite because it was my birthday, and it was an awesome surprise. The hotel's history is amazing and the staff and excellent. The beds were excellent and the hotel soaps and lotions smell amazing.  Whether you sit in the cozy courtyard for wine at night or coffee in the morning-its always quiet and relaxing. The location is excellent as well. Steps away from excellent restaraunts and the highline itself. Chelsea Market is nearby and a must see. This was an amazing hotel from start to finish.

title: originalité
text:
à New york il y a le choix dans les hotels, les grands buildings et els autres, celui ci est certainement l'un des plus originaux, dans un ancien "monastère" dans un bloc de bâtiments restés à vocation religieux.
Si il n'y avait pas la high Line, on pourrait dite qu'il est excentré, mais avec la High Line, le Chelsea market et la promenade au bord de l'Hudson il est idéalement situé pour des initiés.
Très "branché" malgré ses origines, il a aussi de grandes terrasses devant et derrières, prisées par les habitants du quartier pour son café "original"
notre seul soucies à été l'emplacement de la chambre, en rez de chaussé, pas top pour la vue...

title: Great place
text: Great experience staying in this old, beautiful, renovated building.  Very convenient to many activities.  High Line across the street.  You can find everything you want within walking distance. Staff was out of this world. Look forward to staying here again. Steve. Atlanta.

title: nice boutique hotel
text: This is a very beautiful boutique hotel, very comfy bed, very clean. The room is spacious and beautifully decorated; not like other big name chain hotels, very unique. We stayed in many 4 star hotels in NYC, this one we love the most. The location is nice too, just cross street from High Line park. Highly recommend.

title: Not really any good
text:
This is uber trendy and in a great location. However, it is unusual to find a hotel without a restaurant even  for breakfast. If all the rooms were like my room they are tiny and I have never had a room without a cupboard in which to hang my clothes. Although there was no cupboard the whole place is stuffed with fairly second rate quasi antiques and distressed carpets. 
Not  worth it.

title: Disappointed :(
text:
Evening of July 4th through July 6th, very important days for us.  We arrived at the hotel, and everyone was absolutely amazing.  They greeted us with kindness and offered to assist us any way possible.  We stepped away to chelsea market was fascinating, and it was my first time.  Great experience.  As we came back from the market and arrived at the hotel to get ready to step out for dinner.  We noticed the air conditioner wasn't working very well.  So we called room service and had someone assist us right away.  They were not able to get it working so they moved us to another room right above ours.  Packed all of our things and headed to our new room immediately.  I looked like a crazy woman with my wedding dress shoes, etc.  At this point I was a bit furious since I was trying to keep a little bit of a tradition going and didn't want my husband to be to see my dress. Nonetheless we were in our new room now, took a deep breathe and moved on.  Felt great, we got ready, and went to a marvelous dinner with our friends, and loved ones.  

When we arrived back our room around 10p or so our room was still a bit warm-ish.  We asked for a fan, and unfortunately the hotel didn't have one.  We decided to leave things as they were and went to bed.  Laid in bed, and felt something poking us, weird right? so we got up, and lifted the sheet that was on top of the feather quilt toper that was on top of the mattress.  I didn't expect the bed to be made this way, didn't think anything crazy but was a little disappointed.  We decided to remove the feather topper, and and just leave the sheet on top of the mattress.  Started folding the feather topper when we came across a stain of blood which was very visible.  Such a disappointment. I know it happens, but gosh, not this, not the night before our wedding.  Come on now!!

July 5th morning, our wedding day, woke up really early and stepped out for breakfast.  We spoke to someone at the front desk regarding the room situation and the gal on staff advised that she would speak to her manager and have the manager call me as soon as they could.  Got back to the room to get ready for our big day, and the staff brought up things to us as we called it in.  No complaints.  Our day went smooth. And we went on with our special wedding day.  

As I write this, on Sunday, August 10th I realize that I still have not yet received a call from this so called manager.  It's the little things in life that make a difference.  Not sure if this person is busy, whatever it is/was, this was our wedding day.  Not a regular stay at a hotel, but a special day that people should sympathise with especially since it's such a sacred and special day.  I hear of stories all the time, and well I just thought that at least the hotel part would be at it's best with these little things, and the wedding part would be a little crazy because things happen.  We decided to stay here because I had a great experience when I attended our last Christmas party that was held here. If it wasn't because the staff, we would've checked out that same night!  

I have to say that I'm the easy person to please in life, it's the little things that make my day.  I was proud to say that I was not your typical bride at all, not a bridezilla, but am proud to tell you our side of the story.  Our special day!  

I hope the manager at this location gets it together.  Make sure your beds are made correctly and the air conditioner is working well.  As for the staff, they are all amazing and I'm glad you got that part right!  You're on the right path, work on everything else!

title: not quite great
text: great location, trendy, close to boutiques etc. I don't think the hotel has been open long and it shows. friendly staff, lovely room, no complaints there at all. problem is there isn't a proper bar and the catering on the patio outside appears to be run by a separate company. asking if I could put a drink on my room caused complete blank faces...nobody knew. so, you arrive back after the theatre say and you just fancy a nightcap...no chance.

title: Great staff, some glitches, neat location
text:
We had a very late night arrival for a one night's stay (booked on Hotel Tonight).  We chose this place particularly for its location near the High Line.  Another charm of this hotel is that it occupies part of the General Theological Seminary (built in the 1820's) and is a Federal Historic Landmark.  As a point of trivia, Clement Clark Moore wrote "'Twas the Night Before Christmas" here in his 17th century apple orchard!

Every single staff member was super helpful and seemed happy to be doing their job.  At check-in, we even got a great recommendation of where to get a bite to eat at midnight.   As you would expect for a property with this history, our room was reached by walking up a few steps into a tiny hallway to reach one of those old elevators where you open a hinged door to access the elevator once it slides open.  

Our room (facing the courtyard) was large for a NYC hotel, with a high pillow-top king bed and windows tucked into thick, almost 200 year old walls.   The bed was fairly comfortable - it had one of those big feather duvets on it as so many hotels now like to do.  I find that sleeping with the duvet on is too warm and without it is too cold.  The room was very clean, with the exception of a dirty smudge on one of the curtains, right where one would grab them to pull them back.  The window a/c did a decent job.  

The bathroom was also large and nicely appointed (other reviewers were right about the shower water getting really hot really fast, btw).  The towels were particularly thick and fluffy, but we had no wash cloths.  Our chief complaint was that the lighting in the bathroom was EXTREMELY dim - we looked around for a dimmer switch but only found a basic on/off switch.  Really, you could barely see in there - it was as if there was only a night light on, which made it very difficult to deal with contact lenses, for example.  I don't know if this is the usual lighting or if both bulbs were on their way out, but it should be addressed.  We arrived so late and by the time we got some midnight dinner and returned, we just didn't have the energy to pursue a lighting remedy with the staff.

One of the great features of this hotel is that they have a little coffee bar in the lobby featuring Intelligensia Coffee and baked goods from a variety of highly regarded NYC bakeries.  (There is also an Intelligensia truck in the front courtyard area.). So we got to sit in the little side courtyard with our dried cherry scones and beverages before launching on our day, which was a lovely moment.

title: Not happy
text:
I have never written a Trip Advisor review before but I am so angry as I sit in my hotel room that I feel compelled.  Today is my birthday and my husband and I were able to leave the kids for one night and one night only to enjoy some peace and quiet.  We arrived at the Highline Hotel at 3:00 PM and were told that our room was not ready.  After grabbing a coffee and going for an hour stroll we returned and were told that our room was still not ready.  By 5:00 PM I began to get annoyed and asked for any room.  At this point the woman at the front desk offered to upgrade us to a suite.  Happily, my husband and I followed her.  She opened the door to find the room already occupied and some pretty shocked guests on the other side.  We were then brought back to the lobby where we waited another hour for our "deluxe king" room to be ready.  

At 6:00 we were told that the manager had not communicated that our room (the one we waited for for 3 hours) was previously put on hold for a different guest yet to arrive.  When we asked to speak to "said manager" we were told he was "on break".  So, now we are in a "superior king" which is a down grade.  Happy birthday to me! 

On a positive - the hotel is adorable but I'm still miffed !

title: Do you want full attention? It is a right place!
text: Hospitality is the act of the recklessly generous heart. ... paying full attention and focus to what you want or need and the High Line hotel will flourish you during your stay. Of course, the quality of service is not guaranteed at top level. It may exceed or fall your expectations. But you could get a full attention from the High Line hotel's hospitality team if you would like. You will not get any full attention at average or standard hotel. The hotel has only 60 rooms!  Our arrival experience was unique! The High Line hotel is extraordinary because we felt valued and worthy. They host daily wine reception after 5pm. It was impeccable and relaxing. The wine reception gave us a little break to unwind and sing songs like a hidden retreat from hectic rushiest new york city's life. We loved the guest room and lobby's interior because their seminary's historic interior /style mentioned us about the eighteenth century and we flocked back into old centuries world. Do not forget to try their breakfast and specialty coffee drinks. The hotel location is perfect if you are an art and food gourmet lover.

title: Convention
text: I was here for the Cherry Bombe Jubliee in the end of March. It was a perfect location for the convention and I loved the fact that it was originally a monastery . The staff was helpful and polite as we navigated the grounds. The main hall was beautiful with its high ceilings and stain glass windows. Though I didn't stay in one of the rooms, they did look very nice from the website.

title: Loved this quirky hotel
text:
Really enjoyed this hotel, it's quite quirky and I think feels more like a high end guest house. 

It was at full occupancy when I stayed but yet was really peaceful and quiet with a lovely air of calm.  

There’s no reception desk as such, staff meet you with an iPad to check you in. When I was there at Easter, there was no restaurant but I believe they have since opened one. There’s a coffee shop on the ground floor with very elaborate coffee and tea making techniques and the most amazing hot chocolate!  

Stayed in a suite and the bed was possibly one of the most comfortable I’ve ever slept in.  The bathroom was huge (by NY standards), deep bath with overhead shower, lovely toiletries.  I really loved the fact that I could open the sash windows.

I wasn’t crazy about the seats in the seating area of the room – quirky, but not very comfortable!

I found the staff really helpful and friendly and the location was great.

I note some reviews here about the noise from 10th Avenue.  I faced the back of the hotel, overlooking a playground so it was really quiet. 

Would definitely recommend this hotel.

title: What a FANTASTIC Suprise.
text: I travel to New York quite frequently, but usually stay in Times Square.  I generally don’t write a review for my stays in Manhattan, since I usually stay at a Hilton property and reviewed them in the past.  I wanted to share my experience at the High Line Hotel because it was someplace new, I had not stayed before.  My company contacted me for an unexpected trip to the Chelsea area.  The High Line Hotel was available so I booked a two night stay.  I have never been to the Chelsea area so I didn't know what to expect.  From the moment I arrived to the time (unfortunately) had departed I felt as if I was at home.  The hotel was AMAZING, the Hotel Associates, friendly and went out of their way to assist.  I arrived early on a Wednesday and they graciously held my luggage until I returned late in the day.  Upon returning I enjoyed an evening cocktail at their champagne bar, I think it was called Champagne Charlie’s.
