They had a nice menu, but I did not have anything to eat, although I overheard several people complimenting the server on how good their meal was.  While checking in the General Manager, Pablo greeted me with a welcoming smile which added to the overall experience.  (You could tell he genuinely and enthusiastically wanted to make my experience a pleasant one)  The room was more than I expected for a boutique hotel.  Rooms were very clean and appointed nicely.  The only problem I experienced with the room is that my company had to check in on me the next morning, the beds were so, so comfortable that I didn’t want to get out of it.  The next two days were all work so I didn’t really get to experience much more of the hotel or the surrounding area, but next time I go to NY I will be going with my wife and friends, making sure we stay at the High Line Hotel.  The High Line is located across the street from the “High Line” from what I understand it is a walking path that sits about 4 or so stories above the street and runs for about a mile or so?  Also, parking is right across the street and the hotel is very convenient to many great restaurants.

title: Perfect blend of comfort and "hipster"
text: This is a perfect blend of beautifully design (may not fit everyone's taste), great hospitality and comfort.  The hotel is small in term of number of rooms which makes it a very unique experience and personable.  The hotel was converted from the seminary dormitories.  It has an old world charms with modern touches- amazing coffee bar at the lobby!  It's a block away from the High Line and in Chelsea and not far from Meat Packing District. The location is perfect. However, the10th Ave is quite busy.  The check is is fairly straight forward.  The check in staff made an offer for larger room if we wait which was a great suggestion.  The room 57 is quite large (comparing to other NYC hotels), the bed was very comfortable and it's on the back of the building so we didn't hear any traffic noise from the 10th Ave.  (thank you to the staff for making this offering!)  Though, there was no "closet" we were provided with open rack for our clothes and trunk by the bed. The bathroom is quite nice.  The waster pressure and the toiletries quality were quite good.  We had a wonderful time staying there and it's a perfect place to come back each night after a day excursion in the city.

title: Generally good, but needs to iron out a few issues
text:
We selected this hotel because the location was ideal for us and our plans for the weekend. 

On the good side, the beds were comfortable, the rooms we had were spacious, the staff was friendly and helpful, and the location is perfect for us. 

Now to the issues. We arrived on Friday afternoon and were placed in room 13, on the first floor facing the front.  Sound did not seem to be a problem, even though there was traffic on 10th Avenue and the restaurant was right outside our window.  What was clearly a problem was not discernible until we returned to the room after dark.  Even though the curtains are heavy and kept out the direct light, the lights bathing the front of the building are UP lights, and hence shown through the space between the top of the curtains and the wall, lighting up the whole ceiling.  They were so bright, it was almost daylight, and we were unable to sleep. 
The next morning we asked to change rooms and our request was readily granted - to another room on the other side of the lobby, again on the first floor, but this time facing the back.  The light was nowhere near as bad.  But, in this room we were able to hear the conversations going on in the lobby and we did not have cold water in the sink.  It would run cold for just a few seconds when we first turned the faucet on, but would then get hot, even after we let it run for many seconds.  We reported this and they had the maintenance person look at it, but it did not seem to be fixed.  
One other thing I found a bit frustrating was that the chairs and "love seats" in the rooms were, I felt, extremely uncomfortable.  So there was really no comfortable place to sit except the bed.

All of that being said, I would like to try this hotel again to give it another chance. We will be sure to ask for a room on a higher floor and facing the back.

title: Chelsea boutique hotel and easy access to High Line
text: Stay only one night but had a very nice experience.  Lovely room with antique furnishings (old rotary phone, school desk, crank pencil sharpener.)  Bed was comfortable and bathroom with old fashion black and white tiles.  We had a garden facing room - which was quiet even with the window opened.  Convenient for a walk on the High Line, Chelsea Market, and good restaurant selection.  Hotel has Intelligentsia coffee in the lobby and outdoor garden, great for those coffee snobs.   No restaurant or food service.

title: Sharp and small boutique hotel in Chelsea
text: We spent two nights here and were very pleased with this gem.  The building was originally part of a seminary, so it is made up of small rooms.  We had a lovely room that had windows that opened up to the yard of the seminary.  We had a big tree outside the window as well, which was lovely.  The bed was very comfortable, with a down topper.  The bathroom was not large, but suited us just fine.  I really appreciated the furniture, which was unconventional and not standard hotel fare.  The fully stocked mini bar with snacks was reasonably priced.  We knew that there was no food service, but the coffee bar was fine for our needs.  There are plenty of dining options all around this neighborhood.  It's a pet friendly hotel, so it was nice to see people relaxing outside, enjoying their  coffee with their dogs next to them.  The staff was warm and easy.  It was a treat to stay here.

title: Stylish hotel in Chelsea
text:
Stayed in the High Line Hotel for 8 nights in the middle of May - first time in this hotel but second time in Chelsea.  The hotel can best be described as "boutique" and I thought it rather lovely.  There isn't a lobby as such; the check in staff operate from a small desk via iPads within the Intelligentsia coffee bar - great coffee and tea was to be had here and indoor and outdoor seating was available.  

The rooms were quirky, individual and interesting:  mine was on the 5th floor and had two dormer windows; a largish bathroom with an excellent shower; a huge bed with a feather mattress topper and the best hotel pillows I have ever slept on; a fully stocked mini bar; air conditioning; and lovely old furniture.  The only downsides were that the room faced 10th Avenue which was very busy all the time (there was also construction going on across the road which was obviously not in the hotel's control) and there was no wardrobe.  However there was a small cupboard with a drawer and shelves and I used the coat hangers from the bathrobes so managed OK.  I had some problems with the light in my room but the staff were very helpful and sent the maintenance man up to sort things out.  Most of the guests seemed to be youngish which gave the hotel a "trendy" feel.

The location was great as an entrance to the High Line was located opposite across 10th Avenue.  10-12 minutes walk will get you to a subway entrance and there are loads of excellent restaurants on 9th and 10th Avenues.  The Chelsea Piers are a 10 minute walk away and using the High Line one can walk down to Greenwich Village and on to Soho.  The Chelsea area is leafy, clean and quieter than Midtown and seems to be family orientated which makes it a perfect area for strolling rather than rushing!

I loved the High Line Hotel and won't hesitate to stay there again when visiting New York.

title: Better boutique option than most others.
text: Hits the mark on the boutique hotel experience.  Excellent rooms. Large for NYC and clubby chic works well. Lacks depth of service given no on premise restaurant - although excellent coffee. Some hiccups with room availability didn't tarnish the experience. Location is a little out there but for galleries and the awesome High Line walkway it is ideal. Overall it's a winner.

title: Stylish and peaceful
text: Having read some of the reviews I was a little apprehensive about staying here but thankfully our experience was very good. The lobby and rooms are beautifully styled - quirky and cosy and very well equipped - and the bed was the best I've ever slept in. We had a deluxe King room on the 3rd floor, facing on to the courtyard. It was so peaceful - our only interruption were the birds singing outside the window! It's in a lovely location with the big draw obviously being the High LIne, just over the road and just a short walk from the MeatPacking District and the West Village. The little courtyard out back and the patio in front are great spots to enoy a coffee and watch the world go by. The staff were lovely - laidback, friendly and helpful. I'd definitely stay here again - and hope I'll be back before too long.

title: Chelsea's a fabulous part of NYC!
text: The High Line is within a few steps from the hotel entrance. Located in a good neighborhood, the High Line Hotel has a young clientele. We were in town for a family wedding and were definitely the oldest couple there.  Lots of local couples with small kids in strollers stopping for coffee on Saturday morning. Beautiful courtyard in the middle of this old monastery. The some of the furniture in the rooms looks like it was original but the beds are new and comfortable. Rooms are clean but do not have makeup mirrors and bathrooms are not well-lit. But the staff is young and terrific. I will stay here again.

title: Mixed Up, Last Minute Room Review
text: We booked a room here within 48 hours of travel due to a reduced rate on Expedia for $265. This rate gets you a basement or lobby level room with a king bed. The room was nice but someone left the window open and we were slapping at Mosquitos most of the night. Also the room is directly across from the coffee bar, so it can be loud. With that said, you get what you pay for. The other nit, which has nothing to do with the rate is the auto sensor on the bathroom sink. I'm all for water conservation, but this is just silly because it's shuts off too quick. With that we will try this hotel next time at the regular rate because we like the style and it's a great location.

title: Beautiful, luxurious and peaceful
text:
I had booked a room here through hotels.com for a quick staycation for my husband's 30th birthday (we're from northern New Jersey). It was a little on the expensive side, but actually not that much more than some much-less-nice places nearby.

The check-in process was quick and easy, and the girl at the desk gave us a Superior King room (described as "one of the best rooms in the hotel") even though we had registered for a Standard King. Points right off the bat! Our room was on the fifth floor, which meant we were under the eaves, and it was spacious, homey, beautifully and tastefully decorated with antiques and extremely clean. In fact, we joked that if it had even a small kitchen, we could have lived there forever! We had a view of the High Line park across the street.

The location was convenient - we were attending Sleep No More, which is nearby, and had dinner planned at a restaurant close by as well. It was a great chance to stay in an area of the city other than the usual touristy neighborhoods.

The room had so many small details that really added up to make it special. The decorative accents were clearly carefully chosen, and one of the coolest little things was that each room seemed to have a different embosser screwed into the desktop. It worked (I embossed a piece of their stationery just to try it out!) and once I saw it I realized that the patterns on the coasters and the pattern engraved in the door of our room also matched it. The rooms on either side had different designs on the door, so I assume they had different accents. A small thing, but the sign of a place that truly takes care to make every little detail special for its guests.

The bed was huge and extremely comfortable - like floating on air. We slept like babies! We didn't sample from the mini-bar, but it was incredibly well stocked, and I was tempted by the Haribo gummy bears (my faves!). 

My one tiny complaint is that the tub in the bathroom could have drained a little bit better - but the tub and whole bathroom were so clean that it really wasn't even gross the way it normally would be. 

Overall, we were just thrilled with our stay, and wished we could have stayed longer. We highly recommend for travelers including couples like us!

title: Customer Service Nightmare
text:
The former Desmond Tutu Center was my favorite place to stay for business travel to NY (beautiful building, great location) but I have never had such a frustrating customer service experience as with the new High Line Hotel (between overbooking and months of billing mistakes) and will probably never stay there again. 

After calling the billing department at least 15 times (they never respond to email), I finally had to take a dispute to my credit card company. Despite each employee being polite and always agreeing with me over months of interactions, the hotel has never followed through correctly and I have spent far too much time trying to troubleshoot their mistakes. 

Before my stay, I called to let the hotel know I would be checking in late due to a funeral. When I arrived exhausted at midnight, my pre-paid room had been overbooked and I had to stay in a tiny room without a closet. The front desk assured me I would be discounted for the downgrade but on the last day I was billed the original amount. 

I asked for an updated invoice as I checked out and paid all mini-bar charges separately on my personal credit card. The front desk had a line of people waiting and asked if they could re-bill me by email. The new invoice still overcharged for the room, plus added a duplicate mini-bar charge (charging me once on my work account and once on my personal card for the same amount).

What followed next was months of painful back-and-forth and six revised invoices, finally ending with credits for all incorrect charges but also adding a new mystery charge on my work account months after my stay. I contested that too but after no credit appeared for the new charge, I had to contest it with my credit card company. Had this been my personal card, I would have rather paid money I didn't owe than waste any more time but with a work account, I was not willing to file a new expense report to explain an unknown charge.

Based on my experience and looking at other reviews on TripAdvisor, High Line Hotel's terrible customer service and billing are not an isolated incident. If they could address this problem, it could still be a great hotel, but that seems like it would take a major shift in their operations and culture. CAVEAT EMPTOR.

title: Disappointing
text: This hotel has it's positives. The building is historically interesting and the renovation is well done. The rooms are lovely and spacious and the beds are delightfully comfortable. The location is interesting (more so for those who have been to Manhattan before); it's a funky area close to the High Line and Chelsea Market. The staff are friendly. However the hotel is disappointing on several levels; the young staff are friendly but a bit directionless. I was kept waiting over an hour for my room (post check in time) and heard a couple of people complain about things (quite validly I thought), only to be given the phone number of the manager!! There is no room service or restaurant at the hotel and the public space is very limited. The daily room servicing was a touch sloppy...dirty glasses not cleared away, towels not replaced, no supplements in bathroom like shower cap, cotton buds etc. However I wouldn't post a negative review based on these relatively trivial complaints. What really upset me was arriving home on my first night there to be greeted by loud music and bright lights streaming in to my room at 10.45 pm. There was a function in the courtyard. I rang to enquire how much longer it was to go on and was told it would be over at 11. When I called back an hour later to complain about the ongoing noise I was offered the email of the manager so I "could reach out with my concerns"! I suggested someone might reach out to me....and despite the nice young desk boy's efforts, needless to say that never happened. I was reassured the next evening by the same chap that there were no functions that evening....so if you value a bit of peace and quiet when you try to sleep, this, for a not insignificant tariff, is not the hotel for you,

title: A cool place downtown
text:
The High Line Hotel, like the Jane, the Bowery and the Refinery before it (all of which I’ve stayed in) is one of a crop of NYC hotels where charm of a city hotel from some indeterminate 19th or early 20th century past is recreated, restored or rescued, but with all the modern and hipster features built in.  The High Line, as the name implies, is directly across 10th avenue from its namesake, making a visit to that landmark, the Chelsea galleries or the meatpacking district all very convenient.

The hotel itself has been carved out of a massive Richardsonian Romanesque pile that must have served as a seminary back in its former life.  Now the twisting halls, cold metal stairs, tiny elevators and passages lead to a warren of rooms of differing sizes and features.  I was kindly upgraded by the NYU art student/aspiring model staff to a large room overlooking 10th avenue and the epinoumous city park.  The room was cozy and well equipped with a small sofa (a davenport as my grandmother would have called this one), a non-working but atmospheric fireplace, a small but functional desk with plenty of outlets, and a ridiculously well stocked bar and snack set up.  There was a small closet and the large and extraordinarily comfortable bed with a featherbed, deep sheets and very soft pillows.

As far as things I was less than happy with, I could point to the fact that the hotel basically has no lobby, per se.  For a place of this size they’ve converted a very small area to the lobby function and the check in is literally a wardrobe that the staff opens when guests arrive.  If it’s at all busy, it makes for something of a cluster in there.  In the room itself, I will note that I was assigned to an accessible room with some very odd bathroom features.  The sink was equipped with a sensor faucet which seems like a great idea at first except ask yourself, have you ever been able to vary the temperature of the water in a public bathroom equipped with sensor activated faucets?  The answer is no, as I realized at the High Line.  Thus, having no way to change between tooth-brushing cold and shaving-hot, I was forced to turn plumber commando and screw around with the valves in the wall to change the temp every time I needed to!  This combined with the total lack of counter space for my toiletries (a real pet peeve of mine) and an accessible shower that literally poured water all over the room with each use made the bathroom a real drag.  

In the end however, these issues were tolerable, particularly given that the bathroom issues are unique to the room in which I stayed.

title: Historic High Line has charm, atmosphere and great staff!
text: We loved the High Line Hotel. It has wonderful intimate and interesting spaces. It has recently been renovated so the updates are crisp and new and clean. We loved the comfort of our bedding and the temperature control of our room, as well as the quietness of the heating, and a/c unit. Our room seemed very private and exclusive and the bar and snack extras are beyond what I have ever been offered. The room liquor and beer offerings on the bureau are unique and special too. The furnishings are charming. The most significant plus (in addition to the room hospitality amenities) is the house staff. The front desk personnel starting with Daniel L. If any one person could be the reason for overlooking any shortcomings of the hotel it would be him. He is professional, knowledgeable, well mannered and kind. Needless to say, we were impressed with him and he was on duty all evenings of our stay. We were helped at check in considerably by Jonathan R. and Kevin M.- also standouts in the hospitality arena of this fine hotel. Our only complaint would be that some housekeeping details were consistently overlooked by that dept. but the staff quickly came to our aid in bringing things up to par.  The neighborhood has galleries, the High Line walkway, the Chelsea Market and all are wonderful to explore.

title: Great place to stay
text: This hotel was a joy to stay in. Everyone was incredible friendly and helpful, in particular, Andres and Cameron. The coffee shop downstairs is exactly what you need in the morning after a long night out. I would absolutely, 100% stay here again. Highly recommend it!

title: The Room is The Only Destination on This High Line
text: Great location, fabulous room, (just make sure you ask for a quiet one) and very comfortable bed! The staff were helpful throughout our whole stay! The transformation from school to hotel makes it real contender for a memorable and different experience. The challenge is the the lack of communal space and amenities that you would expect from a $500 a night hotel (which is the total cost, when you get you're bill due to all the taxes, so make sure you factor this into the price). There is no bar, restaurant, gym or communal areas what so ever, nor room service. No tea or coffee making facilities in the room and the small cafe is extremely expensive, just for coffee and a croissant, not much change from $20 a day. Overall this hotel, trades on its location, as you really have to go out for everything except to sleep.

title: Fantastic stay
text:
Was worried about staying here due to the reviews but couldn't have been more delighted. We arrived very late at night and was checked in within minutes. Room was full of quirky pieces and the bed was one of the most comfy I have slept in. Room also well stocked but wasn't needed as so many places within walking distance to eat and drink. The staff were all young, friendly and helpful and it was wonderful to come down of a morning and smell the coffee brewing and grab a cup out in the courtyard before heading out for the day. 

Loved the location, the decoration and the coffee. If you are looking for somewhere to stay away from the crowds yet handy to everywhere than I can't recommend this place enough. Thanks for showing us another side of NYC

title: Loved the Highline Hotel
text: My wife and I got away to NYC for three days and stayed at the Highline Hotel.  It was exactly what we were looking for.  the room was small, but very comfortable.  The bed was excellent.  In the lobby, they have an Intelligentsia coffee/tea bar pouring high quality brews, as well as wine and beer.  FYI, there is no room service, but there are fantastic places to eat literally across the street.  And you have access to a nice gym a block away.

title: EXPERIENCE A PIECE OF HISTORY IN THIS HIP BOUTIQUE HOTEL
text:
We just returned from a weekend stay at the High Line Hotel. Since we live in NJ, this weekend was more of a stay-cation, something we often do to experience different neighborhoods in NYC and to escape the day to day. This was our first stay in Chelsea and we loved not only the neighborhood, but the hotel itself. When they renovated this property, it was done in such a way that the 1800's theology school can still be felt in the building, yet  you are staying in a very hip, chic and interesting hotel.

We loved that the architecture of the building and it's furnishings  were true to the original  buildings purpose, with original doorways, stained glass, period furnishings, fireplaces and old school desks and hand presses in the rooms, as well as old rotary phones. The interior space provided a small lobby with no registration desk. Instead, there was an employee or two with a lap top monitoring check ins, security and guests needs from the lobby. Bell staff handled bags and opened doors. There was an outstanding coffee bar that takes up half the lobby space and was always busy. We loved the outside interior courtyard….great place to sit and read or grab a coffee. Bicycles were available for guests use upon request.

Our room, #20 faced the High Line and was spacious with two double beds, two closets and a large bathroom. Again, decorated in period furnishings and colors, the room captured both the needs of today while still echoing it's history. Beds were VERY comfortable with plush down mattress pads and comforters. 

One of the very best things about The High Line Hotel was it's location. Not only are you across the street from the High Line Park, but you are surrounded by GREAT local, neighborhood restaurants, Chelsea Piers, The Park along the Hudson to ride bikes, jog, roller blade or walk for miles and miles, Chelsea Market, and tons of outstanding art galleries. We loved Cookshop for brunch next door and Red Cat for dinner or brunch. Porteno Restaurant  down the block on 10th was OUTSTANDING for Argentinean food, we had a very memorable and delicious dinner there. It is small, so make reservations.

We had no issues with the staff, they were young but attentive and interested in meeting and exceeding our needs. Do not come to this hotel if you are expecting the Ritz Carlton or The St. Regis. Although The High Line Hotel is an upscale boutique hotel, and a property well worth staying in and returning to, it is because it is a historical gem with amenities and a great location in West Chelsea. It does not pretend to be any more than that. Go and enjoy the experience, it is unique, and fun, and hip and we will definitely return.

title: If you want *any* service, or even an actual room - stay away!
text: The highline hotel could be very special but is ruined by the dreadful service. Bottom line: if you pay for a room, from 3 p.m. till 12 p.m. the next day, and you can't have your room for a large proportion of the time,  and they charge you the full amount, that is theft. This might sound harsh, but we actually arrived at mid-day very tired and told "just a few more minutes", with vague allusions to pillowcases. It does seem there are systemic issues with organization at this hotel. This went on for several hours. We left and came back several times and wasted the first precious day of our short stay, trusting they were telling us the truth that we could, in a few minutes, check-in. I don't think we would have actually been given our room had we not, after an 8 hour (yes 8 hour) wait, refused to leave reception until they sorted it out.  Add to this a myriad of other perfect examples of how to alienate and upset your guests, and I give it 3 stars (contact me if you want details of further mishaps - too long and boring to go into here). After paying nearly $1800 for two nights (because they don't provide roll-outs for big delux double rooms), I was told on check out to please contact the general manager, he is very good at responding.  So the unconscionable: it's mean to leave bad reviews if the general manager had no idea this problem arose and is not given the opportunity to make amends. As such, I wrote to the general manager... twice, and after dead silence, asked his staff to forward my email, which they kindly did. The problems with service seem to extend to their email servers. Despite Mr. Migoya having ample time over the past 10 days to respond to others on tripadvisor making public announcements about the disaster that is this hotel, my discreet inquiries remain unheeded. I must therefore warn other tripadvisor members, if you rent a hotel room, and would like to actually get a hotel room, without having to cojole, argue and ruin the precious hours of your visit, don't stay here.

title: Some things were great some things were not..
text:
Would have been a 4 star if got the bill correct. Stayed for 5 nights in late March. Mum's pick - fantastic sized deluxe double queen - amazing mini bar and great beds, bedding fixtures etc. The vintage features are cool and we loved the vibe and feel of the renovation, the gorgeous Bigelow & Co products and most of the staff were lovely. The heating was hot but this offset the cold draft from the gap in the bathroom sash window, normal problems when living in a Victorian building in modern times and the end result was the perfect temperature with a fresh air feel. 
Problems are the lack of balance with the small lobby and the impact of the too cool for school coffee bar staff, locals and allies in the hotel staff - some of whom are just rude and unhelpful. I know there are rumours this is part of the experience of NYC - it isn't it is just bad service and a bad product- sort it out. 
I had booked through Mr and Mrs Smith and we did not receive our extra - bottle of Prosecco, I was given a warm bottle of less than great white wine and told Prosecco should never have been offered (it is still the extra offer on the Mr and Mrs Smith website). Our bill was not correct at check out- deposit not deducted, I had listened to previous warnings and taken my email print out of what was due and this was altered but I did not enjoy having to try to sort this out in the middle of what is a local's coffee bar or the attempted fob off's to try to overcharge me. I loved the hotel itself and the location just not the added hassle. We slept really well and the space and view off the Highline were great. Great shame the guest detail hasn't been worked out yet. No buildings work when we were visiting. We used the hotel car service to JFK - $90 including toll and tip at 20% blacked out SUV a great trip, worth it. Lovely porter staff day and night.

title: Delightful
text:
Our stay at the High Line Hotel in NYC was delightful.  Friendly staff greeted us, the rooms were extremely comfortable and not too "hotel-y".  It felt like our room was my own small NY apartment for the week.
The Intelligentsia coffee bar in the lobby always had such a pleasant wafts of amazing coffee's that I was tempted to linger on the comfy sofas eternally.  The complementary bikes are awesome!  Breakfast next door at Cook Shop cannot be beat.  
Walking the High Line, working out at Equinox (complementary) and ease of getting around the city make this a great place to stay.

title: Amazing stay
text:
We came to the city for one night and used the Hotels Tonight app to  book the room. The room we got was amazing, lots of room and the bed was very comfortable. We also loved that the curtains were heavy enough to block out most of the noise and the light from outside at night.
Particularly I would like to point out the amazing staff. The concierge when we checked in was Lyric. She was a peach, delightful and she seemed genuinely interested in our trip and happy for us. I will definitely be staying here next time I'm in the city.

title: A few brutal details ruined what could have been perfection
text: We rented a room last minute at the Highline for a staycation. I had heard amazing things about the renovations and thought it would be the perfect escape from the usual upscale hotels around Chelsea/Meatpacking. The building is beautiful even though it is still VERY much under construction. The main entrance and whole front garden is closed and covered in caution tape. My room was off the lobby, which for a few twentysomethings who stay out late was fine but the fact that within minutes of us returning to the room the coffee bar was opening or preparing for the day - the clinking and clanging from that right outside our door before the sun even rose was brutal. That was, however, a minor issue compared to the temperature of our room. It was stuffy and unbearably warm upon arrival. We turned the thermostat all the way to cold on the highest setting before going out for the night. When we returned back, our room keys did not work (it was a twenty minutes before the one staff member in the lobby was done dealing with another angry guest before we could even be let into our room.) When we finally got in, the room was 10 times hotter than it was before we left. We opened the windows, only half of which had screens, so we had to keep only those two open. We barely slept because of how unbelievably hot the room was and being on street level with open windows did not help that. To top it off, the friendly helpful welcome we got at checkin was gone at check out. Not only were we not helped with our bags through the side entrance (all that's open because of the construction,) but the TWO staffers at the door didn't even hold it open not say a goodbye... Very strange indeed. It's sad that we left with such a foul taste when the building and our room were so gorgeous.

title: Nice enough hotel, rude service
text: I feel compelled to write this to warn other families, I booked a room for 2 adults and 1 child. On arrival after flying in from the uk, now 00.30 am uk time so a bit tired and needing to get our 8 year old to bed.  The receptionist, which is basically you standing in the middle of the coffee shop talking to a member of staff with a screen, told us she was moving things around to give us a bigger room. Great I think, once in the room we are met with just 1 king size bed. I return to reception to be told that is what I booked, yes I say I appreciate the room type but this is what was offered to me when I put in our search criteria I was expecting a sofa bed/single bed to be added to the room. She said I should have requested a rollaway bed for a further $75 on top of the $400 already paid. I don't think so I reply, initially she said this is the room you have booked, I state the fact and show my booking confirm clearly stating 2 adults, 1 child, she'd does say this has happened before, the website should really tell the booker, but it doesn't I say, I need a bed for my daughter. She calls another member, dithers around, we decide to get a drink she finally tells me a rollaway is being set up now, we gave it a further 5 mins, it's now 1.30 am we return to the room to no bed, no-one putting up a bed. I return again, now very frustrated to be told I have to be patient!! The cheek of it I say you told me now 10 mins ago the bed was being put up. I return again and eventually a bed arrives,, it's now 2 am before I can finally get my daughter to bed. Throughout the whole episode I was made to feel like it was my fault, certainly very poor customer service, with the conversation being held for all to hear. The hotel is in a great location but I don't think I'll return to be treated so rudely.

title: Great hotel, Shocking service
text:
The hotel itself is great. Very well renovated with some really classy touches. The rooms are pretty small, but from what I hear that's typical of NYC. The service on the other hand is absolutely appalling!

One or two of the staff were very moody and elitist, as though any basic question was beneath them - although I do have to point out that this was the minority as some were quite the opposite. It's just the bad experiences seem to really sour the whole experience. Part of the package is access to a local gym. I was assured by hotel staff that I just needed to let them know my name as they would call ahead, although when I arrived at the gym nobody there seemed to know that there was even a deal in place. I did manage to get in, but only after calling the hotel and getting them to have a conversation. These are minor problems though and we still would have been happy enough in the grand scheme of things until we were checking out.

When arranging a cab back to JFK I was stupid enough to fall for a fairly hard sell into paying considerably more for a private hotel car. Worth travelling back in style we thought, but as it turns out the car was filthy, the boot was already full of random rubbish meaning getting our cases in was a challenge and there were a number of deep cracks all the way across the windscreen! This was genuinely far worse than any yellow cab we'd taken. We were really surprised about this as the hotel itself, is clean and classy, so why would they want to associate themselves with this?

Worse still was the after service. I left an expensive pair of headphones in the room so emailed them from the UK asking if they had them. They were kind enough to call back and confirm this was the case so I arranged for a friend in NYC to collect them. I confirmed his name and details over email, but when he arrived he was told they had already been collected. I have no major objection to this as it must have been a mistake by somebody on reception and I understand these things happen (my fault for leaving them in the first place!) - although there is a slight question mark over why somebody else would come in and ask for them when nobody other than me, my wife, my friend and the hotel knew they were there. My big problem is the absolute zero contact from the High Line Hotel since this happened. I naturally emailed them to query the fact they had given them to somebody other than the person I'd specifically named, but had no reply. A couple of days later I repeated this, but again, nothing. As was the case on two or three other occasions. The headphones aren't the issue here, it's the fact that they refuse to even acknowledge the issue with a reply. Even if it wasn't what I wanted to hear, a reply of any form would have at least showed they have at least some concept of customer service. A very disappointing end to what had been a great trip.

Next time we're in NYC we'll stay at The Jane.

title: Road to Wellville Meets Sir John Sloane's Museum - Enjoy it!
text: The style of architecture I would describe as "Road to Wellville/Take the Waters meets Sir John Sloane's Museum." I had a pair of horns in my room, and you can spot other attic treasures scattered throughout. Floors are B&W tile, with iron beams and all the finer details found in big piles of bricks, this one a former seminary. But the rooms manage to wed old and new, with lovely aged carpets and vintage furnishings living happily beside period wallpaper and contemporary luxury linens. The bed is worth getting stranded in NYC for. I almost gave it 4 stars because my room was a bit street-noisy, but I was fine w earplugs. The lobby scene will appeal to anyone happy living under the tyranny of liveliness (I could skip it) -- coffee-drinkers in line for the loo was a bit off-putting but who am I to judge? If you are hip, you will feel at home here. If you fantasize about old European hotels, you will also like this. It's out with the old, and in with the new, and back in with the old. A singular hotel in a world where it is hard to be apart from the pack. Great bell staff -- one reminded me of a character from an Ishiguro novel.

title: You have to experience this hotel to believe it!
text: This is truly my absolute favorite hotel in NYC.  The rooms are so commodious that you truly feel as if you are returning to your own apartment.  I love the fact that the lobby is very casual:  really just a well masked station shared with a comfy lounge and Intelligentsia Coffee.  The attention to detail is spectacular; everyone who works here is very happy; and the view of the little park outside is so calming.  PLus it's in Chelsea with all the galleries and great restaurants and The High Line.  I would live here if I could!

title: Great stay
text: My husband and I just returned from a 6 night stay at The High Line Hotel and loved it. The decor is great and our room was smaller, in the eaves, but comfortable and we had everything we needed. I loved the touches of vintage phone, old writing desk and retro styling. The room was well kitted out with snacks and drinks and the coffee from the 'intelligentsia' coffee company in the lounge/reception was delicious. It's not your standard hotel, with no reception desk/room service etc, but we found the staff extremely friendly and helpful, easy to identify & our room was clean & well stocked. There are lots of places to eat both left and right out of the hotel and only a few blocks downtown is the Chelsea food market, so we didn't mind not being able to eat there.

title: Bad form
text: We booked this hotel over a month in advance. We left our bags there early and went for a walk on the high line. Twenty minutes later we received a call that 'an executive decision had been made' and we were booted out of the hotel because they 'had a group that decided to stay another week' and so they didn't have any more room for us.

title: Fun and funky
text: I stayed in this hotel recently for a business trip and enjoyed it. The quirky decor was utterly charming, the staff was helpful and friendly and the bed outrageously comfortable. The room wasn't spacious exactly but it felt like I was staying in someone's home, complete with (non-working) fireplace and random hardcover books scattered about. The only drawback was no room service - I was told to just Yelp around and have something delivered. But all things considered I'd certainly stay here on business again. Not sure it's a place for kids though.

title: Quirky but Comfortable
text: The High Line Hotel is in a renovated building that was formerly part of the Episcopal Seminary. It is definitely not your run of the mill boutique hotel. The rooms are small but comfortable with excellent beds and outfitted with a variety of old furniture and books and an elaborately supplied minibar, the bathrooms are tiny but modern, the halls are narrow and twisty, only one small and rather slow elevator, and there is no restaurant. The staff are extremely helpful and the coffee bar, operated by Coffee Intelligentsia, is quite good. One can't help but feel a little sorry for the receptionist who has to stand up all day at a very small laptop podium. The location is excellent - easy access to the High Line, a short walk to the subway at 18th and 7th, and many good Chelsea restaurants nearby. Particularly recommend Cookshop for breakfast, which is literally across the street. This is not for everyone but for the frequent visitor who is looking for an interesting and quiet place to stay a bit off the beaten path, I think it is nearly perfect.

title: Incredible location, great staff!
text: Only half a block from the High Line stairs, the hiking experience was awesome for my wife and I, with fantastic views all over the place. Cookshop restaurant right across a quiet street was our culinary highlight of the trip. We're from the Ann Arbor Mi. area, and the staff here had a laid back attitude we loved. Kudos to the following staff in particular: David at the morning coffee bar who was our rock of Gibraltar along with Irving at the door. You guys rock! Special mention to Alvin, Alexandra and Cameron. Joe Walker, Desk Manager, I asked about you repeatedly but never saw you. I know you comment on most reviews, but in this case, please take a DEEP breath, and don't comment on this positive review. (I know you can do it!) My wife and I are both very light sleepers, and our fifth floor room facing the courtyard was quiet as per the reviews. We were never awakened by noise. We would definitely stay here again.Tips: visit the roof, great views! We only learned about the third floor space that looks like Hogwarts on our last morning, so we didn't see it- guided permission only. Visit Chelsea Brewing within walking distance, a great IPA! Chelsea Market is only 3 or 4 blocks down the street. Pier 62 near the brewery has the AIANY boat tour around Manhattan. Incredible!

title: Better than its present ranking.
text:
My wife and I stayed here for 3 nites in March 2014.  We stayed in a Deluxe King.  The size of the room was excellent for the price we paid (thru booking.com) - at least for NYC.  We actually stayed in two different rooms after having an issue in the first room.  We moved from room 11 to room 19.  Room 11 was bigger but noisier.  Both rooms faced the front of the hotel on 10th Ave., which we liked.  The best thing about this place, that is hard to put into words, is its charm.  It's a very chic and trendy place in a good way.  It's also in a pretty fantastic location away from the tourist hordes.  The main down side is the same thing that gives the place charm.  The building is very old, so you can't expect everything to be in perfect condition.  For instance, the shower didn't drain properly.  When we moved rooms (that wasn't the issue) I thought the shower in the next room would be fine.  No such luck.  

I do have a couple of suggestions for mgmt.  The elevator was small and dark, better lighting would help.  Also my wife said the wall sockets in both rooms were loose, i.e., her plugs were falling out.  Also, with somewhat limited counter space in the bathroom it would be helpful to permanently remove the knickknacks on the counters.   

Like the hotel itself, the location might seem a bit questionable, until you get there and walk the neighborhood.  We used city buses to get around.  The bus stop is a half block away out the front door in either direction.  The no. 11 bus comes every 10-15 minutes and takes you right up 10th Ave. towards Midtown.  You can take the same no. 11 back down 9th Ave. to get back to the hotel.  But you'll need exact change ($2.75) or a metro card, which you can purchase at a subway station.  We had a really good breakfast at Le Grainne Cafe, a French diner, about 2 blocks away.  There's also a 24 hr. CVS one block away if you head out the front door to the right.  And at least 4 restaurants deliver to the hotel.  I have no doubt this place will be rising in the TA rankings.  The pros definitely outweigh the cons.  I can see why this place was ranked much higher a few years ago under previous management before it had to close due to Hurricane Sandy.  If you go, don't forget to check out the courtyard out back.  It's beautiful.  We will return.

title: Perfect
text: Fifth visit yesterday 3/21: this time booked on Expedia, and arrived within an hour.  Expedia hadn't yet synched when I got there ... but rather than look all confused, and questioning the validity of the booking (like most hotels do), the host apologized, explained that she had to call Expedia to obtain the reference number, offered me a seat, and a coffee.  Coffee was perfect; host was back in minutes; was smart and friendly - and offered me a double queen room (which was SUPER spacious). Impeccably handled experience.

title: Happiness at the High Line
text:
A beautiful room with spectacular customer service! A friend booked this hotel for us, so I had no idea what I was getting myself into nor any expectations going into it. 

We arrived late, 10pm, and were greeted by a reception of warmth from the staff, ready to check us in. The young woman, Sammi, was very helpful and informative. Our room was amazing(!); spacious with an air of vintage chic in every detail. It felt like we took a step back into time with reclaimed woods, furniture and books. The addition of terrariums featuring succulents and plants, was refreshing and fun. After getting settled in, it was time to hit the town! Sammi was very helpful in making recommendations for a bar that served food late at night and was in walking distance, so off we went. 

This exceptional service from Sammi continued all weekend. She was always there to send us off into the city with helpful tips and suggestions on how to make the most of our time in NYC. As we returned at night, she was there with equal enthusiasm and warmth to greet us after a long day. We know it is her job to be friendly to guests, however, Sammi went above and beyond to make us feel like we weren't just a hotel guest, but a friend.

Aside from the exceptional service, the hotel was a fun place to be. As a non-New Yorker, I found it to be interesting, chic and comfortable. Set in Chelsea, The High Line Hotel is the perfect mix of classic and modern. There is a coffee shop in place of a lobby bar; serving coffee all day and wine in the evenings. Never void of interesting, the lobby is filled with vintage sofas that are a revolving door of locals in trendy clothing and exotic conversation. The hotel evokes the way Chelsea should feel in the here and now..

title: Hi from the High Line Hotel
text: Nice hotel but not much of a lobby which is very small. Lobby does have a wonderful little coffee bar that makes great lattes. My family and I stayed here during Christmas holiday 2013. The rooms were nice with comfortable beds.

title: Bad experience
text: I had great expectations but was unfortunately very disappointed. The hotel is very charming but the staff are rude and offhanded (expect one guy, Alvin, he was great). The room was so hot we needed to sleep with opened window on ground floor! We also didn’t get the room we had booked and paid for during the first night. In our new room the lamps didn’t work and the bathroom door was jammed. I would definitely recommend people to view other options before booking this hotel.

title: A bit better than last time.
text:
My first review of the High Line Hotel from last spring no longer seems available, but when I first went when it had just opened (spring 2013) it was quite rough then: construction dust, a great deal of noise, wires uncovered, no shades or curtains on bathroom windows facing busy streets, telephone didn't work. I am happy to report that is has improved since then, though it still isn't quite as good as its prices are indicating. I would actually like to give it 3.5 stars but it is not an option here. 

Problems: I had a very, very small room this time (usually the rooms are larger), and it was very hot (even though cold outside) and the temperature controls did not seem to do much. I really needed an early check-in but could not be accommodated--even though they said they could do so-- and I ended up waiting awhile, not really knowing how long it would be. (That delay cost me an appointment.)  The hot room: I opened the window and had it open to get through the night, which was okay because I was high up but would not have felt safe lower to the ground. I found the staff quite friendly and helpful, which is what bumps up my score. Their friendliness eased some of the annoyances, which would have been more annoying if delivered with rudeness.  

The rooms and lobby are handsome and have some visual charm.  The rooms need a bit more to make them comfortable: a soft chair to sit in, a luggage rack to put one's suitcase on. And for some reason,the carpet in my room and also the lobby smelled like burnt rubber, which I could just tolerate but was noticeable and a little weird.  They should look into that...something wrong with the vacuum cleaner?

title: Great location but needs attention to details
text: The checkin was appalling as they couldn't find our reservation and I had written an email to confirm.  Our rooms were near the great Coffee Bar but was noisy with screaming kids in the morning, so do not book these rooms.  The key cards had to be reprogrammed three times.  No turndown service or towels the second night.  Bathroom needs brighter lights, shelves and hooks.  One bedside needs a reading lamp.  Overhead lights didn't work.  Luxurious linens and mattress.  Great decor/design in perfect location.

title: Great location, some nice amenities, some basics missing
text:
Stayed one night.  Location is great in hot high line area next to restaurants and across from high line park.  10th avenue is a busy road but my room was on other street so no noise issues but could be on street side.  Building is gorgeous, gas lanterns out front, nice courtyard with tables and chairs - it's winter so not being used but I am sure in spring the coffee truck there and courtyard will be a lively spot.  The lobby and common areas are nice but here is where the hotel is showing its still a soft open.  No bar or restaurant just fancy coffee bar.  No comfortable area to sit and lounge - basically lobby is foyer.  I didn't wander too much but my sense was all this is to come with construction.  Check in was efficient if a bid odd - guy just using a laptop on a table in lobby - again feels like just opened

Room was on top floor.  Very spacious for New York, but here there is some stuff missing.  Like what?  Well how about a closet- no closet, and by the way no chest of drawers either.  Furniture is quirky 1920s vintage desks and chairs, I liked it but may not be for everyone.  Bathroom is tiny which is typical New York but not typical for hotel of this level is tiny precast tub with shower curtain.   Obviously this quirkiness is from having to use the old building and working with what they had - it was fine but if my wife and I were there for a week and had nowhere - literally- to put clothes I wouldn't be happy.  There is no restaurant, at least yet, so no room service.  There is minibar that is shockingly underpriced -- candy for 2 dollars, beer for 5 or 6 dollars. By NYC standards that's cheap - nice selection to, craft beer, nice snacks, small batch bourbon - maybe trying to make up for lack of restaurant 

I booked through jetsetter and paid 200 or so - compared to others in NYC that's fair price.  When completed the place can command more.  Overall very cool place if you don't mind the quirks and realize its not completed yet.  Would definintely stay again

title: Old world charm
text:
Stayed here for a weekend with a friend and felt like I was in Europe except the room was huge! 
Very hip place with bicycle rental, great coffee shop with yummy pastries, and beautiful architecture.  Rooms have a comfy bed with great linens, quirky furniture, and the best part was the big windows that actually opened to the outside.  The Highline is nearby for an evening stroll.
Lots of shopping and great restaurants in the neighborhood.  Not too expensive either.
I travel to NYC a couple of times a year and this will now be my go to hotel.

title: Serenely delightful
text: We needed to make a quick trip to NYC for a birthday party for a friend who lives in Chelsea.  I am a former student at the seminary and my husband as always wanted to live on the Close.  The High Line Hotel was the perfect choice.   We were delighted from moment one with the service of the staff, the beautiful room and the feeling of serenity that enveloped us.   We have booked for a week in late April when we return to celebrate our wedding anniversary.   congratulations from two very very fussy former New Yorkers.  See you in Aoril

title: Making you feel right at home
text: Our stay at the High Line Hotel was neither business nor pleasure. My girlfriend and I had to evacuate our apartment due to mold! You can image how frustrated we were, but  when we arrived at the hotel Joe at the front desk sympathized with our situation and went the extra mile to make us feel right at home. Joe and the rest of his staff were very friendly and accommodating to all of our needs, including laundry and meals. The staff always had great recommendations on where to eat and were happy to get on the phone and call a wash and fold place to pick up our laundry. The hotel itself is beautiful, lots of character and ambiance! You feel like your not really in Manhattan but somewhere in Europe. The location is perfect, right next to High Line Park and Chelsea Market and steps away from posh nightlife spots.. A hidden gem in the hotel is the coffee shop. Be sure to stop and get a mocha latte! I cant thank Joe and his staff enough for making a terrible situation so much better.

title: Cosy, with character
text:
This is the type of hotel that you miss. It has the charm of an old building, the interiors feel welcoming and it's lobby, without a front desk is instead a haven for premium coffee junkies.
The rooms are converted from the days when this was a theological seminary, but ever so slightly. Dark woods, fireplaces and black and white tiled bathrooms. Lots of ambience!
Really good beds and quite, this was a good sleep.
The location, a couple of blocks north of Chelsea Market, right in the midst of galleries and any number of good restaurants, was perfect in many ways. And of course, High Line Park is just across the street.
The lobby doubles as a coffee bar and offers really good coffees too. And a bagel.
But I would have liked a small bar too. Just to hang out. 
It's possible they offer something outside when the weather is slightly warmer. I thought I saw something out front, but at near freezing temperatures outside, there was no option available within the building.
Still, a great hotel experience.

title: Excellent new find
text: My colleague booked our rooms, so I'm sorry I cannot comment on price or value. But otherwise, this place is a hidden gem (for now) in a relatively quiet area of NYC. Charming and unique-there is no front desk and the staff is casually dressed, actually making it hard to figure out who worked there versus who was a guest-the decor is really wonderful, from the exposed steel beams in the lobby to the old-timey phone and desk in my room. Plushy bathrobes and slippers provided, making this feel more like a European hotel than a US one. Room was huge, bathroom a little tight but manageable and terrific CO Bigelow toiletries. Towels huge and fluffy, and staff was friendly and accommodating from check in to hailing us a cab for the airport upon checkout, taking our bags and into the cab before we knew it. If location is an issue, midtown might be better, but since our business was in the area, it was perfect. Would certainly return.

title: Gracious hospitality, the extra mile
text:
The High Line Hotel is a delight if you love old buildings, which I do.  And so do those who refurbished this space from a dormitory for the Episcopal Seminary to a relaxed hotel in Chelsea.  The room was furnished with, among other things, somewhat worn oriental rugs, an old fashioned school desk (of a prior seminarian, one presumes), a cast-metal rotary telephone, and a large container of newly sharpened pencils on the desk.  The bed was deliciously modern and comfy, the bathroom fully equipped, and the flat-screen TV just fine.

The service was informal in manner but excellent in delivery, between help with bags, a recommendation for parking, directions locally.  

The "extra mile" came the following morning, when my elderly husband began feeling weak and dizzy.  Though we had checked out and gone to a local restaurant for breakfast, they let us back into our room (now made up by housekeeping) for him to lay down.  An hour later, when I had retrieved the car, they stood watch at the car to fend off ticketing, loaded the bags, and saw us on our way.  Thank you, caring staff!

title: Escape the hustle
text: It feels like returning "home" after a day whizzing around NYC versus going back to your "hotel". I'm a coffee lover so the Intellegensia cafe in the psuedo-lobby is a major plus. My room was very comfortable (overlooked the courtyard, not 10th Ave). The staff are extremely helpful and friendly. I had a chance to speak with Alvin and Mia - both commendable hosts. I forgot my mac power adapter (so annoying) and they found it for me and held it for 10 days. Mia even remembered our conversation a week after I reported it missing. Having the High Line at your doorstep is amazing, if you are into that kind of thing (which I am). The hotel is a converted convent and the hotel has 66 rooms but not much else. No restaurant but an amazing one across the street. No gym but you get access to Equinox three blocks away! Overall I think this hotel was a great value.

title: Lots of potential as yet unrealized
text: As a former seminary, with access to a lovely courtyard in Chelsea, this site has a lot of potential that feels unrealized.  We stayed here over New Years and, while the staff, especially Casey, the bellman, and Joseph Walker, the front office manager, are very nice, building a hotel around a coffee bar doesn't seem like enough.  Yes, Intelligentsia serves a great cup of joe, but the people who serve it are definitely in their own orbit, and one has the feeling of almost intruding as a hotel guest.  In general, the decor seems slapdash and a bit dismal, even gloomy.  Perhaps in the future, someone will chose to make the rooms more pleasant, with more storage, lighting, and seating, which certainly their size could accommodate.  Keepers: nice towels and sheets, and, yes, the coffee.

title: A wonderful escape
text:
I spent a wonderful night at this beautiful gem of a hotel right in the heart of Chelsea overlooking the High Line Park and the Hudson River.   I cannot say enough about how kind and welcoming the staff were and how beautifully they took care of me. The staff was young and bright and so wonderfully professional and positive!  Made everything EASY!

The Hotel itself is a former Church Seminary and it has been beautifully renovated and transformed into this gorgeous boutique hotel.  My room was clean and bright with wonderful details and everything you could need to feel welcomed and comfortable.  The bed was luxurious, the sheets bright clean and soft, the towels were also large(!) and fluffy!  They have kept the charm of the old spaces while giving it all a modern edge.  My room had an old fireplace, comfortable seating, a desk, two closets, a flat screen TV and a vintage rotary phone, plus fluffy bathrobes and umbrella's (just in case!).  The bathroom was spacious, with vintage tile and light fixtures all in keeping with the old NY esthetic.  I loved it.  
A few other details I loved:  Outdoor gardens with tables and chairs, in the front of the Hotel and in the back; the Lobby also doubles as an Intelligentsia coffee shop full of plush chairs and corners to sit in; they also have a fleet of bicycles you can USE (not rent!) at any time during your stay.  They also have a partnership with the Equinox Gym a a block away so you can use those facilities at any time during your stay.  
The only thing they don't have is an in house restaurant but there are so many wonderful places literally within one block of the Hotel you hardly notice.
I am definitely going to stay there the next time I am in the city!

title: Too little... much too little...
text:
This hotel feels and looks like an unfinished piece of art.
From the broken leather sofa in the reception, to the lack of true service or quality equipment such as a sound system in the room... the baths too shallow to enjoy... it was truly not worth the money spent!

Truly one of my biggest deception in New-York City. 

One piece of advice, if you have a great idea... follow-it through completely! Being a luxury hotel, means you cover at the very least all of the basics.

title: Trendy but a bit lacking
text: We booked this hotel for a romantic weekend getaway but left a bit disappointed. The hotel is definitely hip and the decor is very cool however our room was very small, had extremely low room lighting and lacked a closet or even a space to hang clothes.  We also had multiple issues with the room keys which would work once and then lock us out, despite my keeping the key separate from other electronics.  The room was also noisy and we could easily hear our neighbors and especially folks above us.  There are also limited parking options (no valet) although we got lucky and parked on the street.  On the plus side, the location is nice, away from the bustle of uptown, the staff were attentive and the coffee bar was convenient.

title: A STEP BACK IN TIME
text:
While some might consider the High Line Hotel the latest home to the hipster set, our experience of the property made for an experience that felt decidedly of another era! And, in the context of NY's hustle and bustle, it was a real treat to be in NY, seemingly in another time. 

Don't get me wrong, the hipsters abound what with the Intelligencia coffee outpost as magnet - housed in a period vending truck in the pleasant courtyard. And, the waxed mustaches, vested and tied staff bringing the hipster aesthetic vividly to life. 

However, the setting in and among the seminary,  the decor replete with unique "antique" pieces and old books and the overall quiet (we'll see for how long) of Chelsea truly made for an unlike any other in Manhattan. 

We were there in very early days of the hotel, so all of the pre-opening challenges will go unmentioned, not to mention those elements that were not ready i.e. dining, but if you are keen to experience New York in a quiet, otherworldly, way, a stone's through from the galleries, High Line and fabulous neighborhoody boîtes, not to mention having a great cup of coffee immediately to hand, this is the place for you!!!

title: A gem
text:
Wonderfully quirky from the lobby to the writers nook in my room. Came for a business party in the Refectory - a perfect space to host any party for up to 400 or so - and after a great time melted into the super comfortable bed.

CO Bigelow bath products and outstanding coffee in the lobby. Add easy access to Chelsea Market, the Meatpacking District and the High Line, and the High Line Hotel is worth a return visit.

title: I'll be back!
text: I usually stay at Hotel Americano while I'm in New York, but there were no rooms available on a recent trip, so I opted instead for The High Line and I have no regrets. The staff were some of the best I've encountered during my travels anywhere (a special shout-out to Alvin and Cameron!). The rooms are huge by New York standards and have an unparalleled charm. I also love the lack of tradition: no check-in desk, no concierge, just the most attentive and friendly staff, ready, willing and able to assist guests. I'll definitely be back.

title: Distinguished
text:
Just back and loved it. 

Rooms exactly as photographed and described. Very different to anything we had seen before in NYC, in a positive way.

Location super for exploring NYC but having a base away from the busier parts of town. 

Great selection of bars,  restaurants, shops and every imaginable amenity within a short walk.

Would definitely stay again, if we ever get the chance to  go back. 

Unlike other reviews, no  adverse noise issues experienced.

title: Not your average NY hideaway
text: What a great find in the heart of the city. Generous space, warmth and classic design. Intelligentsia coffee on site. Oh and the amazing bed! Alvin took care of us and was always right there to lend a hand with our luggage or help hail a cab. We'll be back.

title: Incredible Stay
text: We had the most amazing stay at this lovely hotel!  It was only one night but it felt like a mini vacation.  First of all, the staff couldn't have been more gracious and welcoming.  It was like being welcomed into someone's home.  The lobby is so warm and friendly and the lack of a traditional front desk only added to the feeling that you are not in a big chain hotel.  The room was spectacular.  Ours was a corner room with windows facing both the street and the lovely garden.  The bed was amazing and an additional bonus of a late check out made for a luxurious Sunday morning.  We felt so far away from the busy meatpacking district yet it was right outside our door.  Noise?  Not an issue at all.  the hotel is set back from the street just enough to eliminate street sounds.  Oh, and brunch at Cookshop down the street is an absolute must!  We will hopefully return to this great find over and over again.

title: Great rooms but need to work on noise level
text:
My wife, dog and I stayed here for a night when our apartment was being painted. We thought the style and design of the room was very nice.  The bed was also very comfortable. The motion sensors on the sink were a bit odd (trying to get my toothbrush to be in the exact spot of the sensor to brush my teeth was annoying), but otherwise we loved the room layout. 

The big disappointment was the proximity of our room (#6) to the cafe and resulting noise. All night we heard staff moving things around and making noise (assuming guests were not pushing carts of things past after midnight). Not to blame the staff - it is likely the layout that is the issue. I suggested they may want to ask late night staff to wear quieter shoes, and they agreed this might be a good idea.

Staff was friendly, room was nice, but at $460 after tax, I expect a quiet night's rest.  I want to give the hotel four stars, but because sleep quality is probably the most important aspect, I have to give it only three.

If you're staying on a higher floor, perhaps the four or five stars are warranted.  I give Value four stars if you are bringing a small dog (no extra charge), but if not then it is only average value (three stars).

title: Not Quite
text:
The highline doesn't seem ready for prime time.  

Since it's a tad on the pricey side, we were expecting more than just a hotel trying to be cool.  All the little things just kept adding up and we ended up staying three notes and then moving to another hotel for the remaining four mites of our trip.  I've never done that before.

The little things are the bell guys watching us unload bags at the curb at 1am and not coming out to help, getting one room key as my wife and I checked in (no, they didn't ask how many keys we needed), super noisy room (the main reason we moved hotels - we do need to be able to sleep at a hotel), housekeeping that didn't clean our glasses, set our towels on the floor they didn't vacuum, no additional toiletries in three days, and the kicker of the Chapstick on the floor when we checked in, also, the coffee bar in the lobby doesn't connect to the hotel system, so charging something to the room is not an option.  My favorite was coming back from dinner on Saturday nite all dressed up and being asked if we were checking in.  Yeah, with no luggage we were checking in.

It's new, so no big deal on no towel bars or hooks and the typical trendy mood lighting in the room and no closet light.  Generally, just not a really well functioning room.  Cool neighborhood though.

title: Not really a quality place, unfortunately
text:
First, the positives: The service was kind and friendly; one front desk worker went through great lengths to find a European converter for me (although truthfully they should have had one readily accessible in the first place). The design is atmospheric and quite pleasant. Super plush beds, although I know that's not everyone's cup of tea.

The standard queen sized room is advertised as 250 - 350 square feet. The first room they put me in was no more than 160 square feet, including the bathroom. (It was room 37 1/2, go figure.)
Not enough room to swing a cat, as the Brits say.  There wasn't even any hanging space, come to think of it.  After I protested, they put me in another room, which was no more than 180 square feet (and with pitched ceilings, so not ideal for tall people). To add insult to injury, they couldn't extend my stay for another evening because they were fully booked, so I had to lug all of my bags down to SoHo.  (Not entirely their fault, I know, although some hotels would find another way.) 

I specifically chose this hotel (instead of the hotel my colleagues were staying at) because of the advertised room size. I had several large bags because I was stopping over in New York before my move to Hong Kong, so you can imagine that I really needed that space. 

All-in-all, this is not a full service hotel. Which is often fine in some cases, but when the rooms are microscopic, then you sort of like a bit of extra to compensate. It's really more of a too-cool-for-school coffee shop with some dorm rooms attached. And what's amazing is that it's always fully booked! Guess they should start paying some royalties to NYC for their use of the "High Line" trademark!

title: Home away from home
text: We have stayed at the High Line twice in the past three months and both times our visits have been extraordinary.   The King suite was wonderful, the staff were sweet and very helpful and the atmosphere has been classy without being pretentious.   In the mornings we worked and enjoyed our cappuccinos from the lobby.   We also used the bicycles to ride for hours on our Saturday.

title: We loved it, but maybe not for everyone.
text:
This isn't a typical hotel.  You're choosing to stay in a very old building that used to be dormitories for the surrounding church.  The hotel made the decision not to tear this pretty amazing building down (or more likely, I guess, it is protected as a historic building), but that inevitably leaves some oddities. So, while I really enjoyed it, I cannot say this would satisfy everyone.  I'm including about everything I can think of to help people make decisions here, but basically if you want brand new, the Standard is just down the street.

First, the heating issue people have mentioned.  We visited mid-October.  Our room was quite warm when we checked in (74 or so), and the temp decreased slowly and steadily while we were there, to about 68 by night three.  Had we wanted to, the large windows in our room opened, so we could have cooled the room that way.  But we were comfortable.

So two weird things, neither of which really impacted our stay or would make me not stay there again, I just found them odd. And I know this is a soft opening, but our room didn't have a clock in it.  I just thought it was odd to open a hotel with no alarm clocks (I did look at the website and they say docks are "coming soon").  Also, the garbage can in our room was never emptied, not sure why.

We were almost sidewalk level, and had almost no noise, the soundproofing was excellent.  No horns, no traffic noise, no talking from pedestrians outside.  I heard people in the hallway outside, which is tiled (like a dorm would be!) rather than carpeted, maybe once or twice.  But not loud, nothing that would interrupt a stay, and I did see that there was at least one family near our room.

The room was ENORMOUS.  And not by NYC standards, by any standards.  Linens and towels were super high quality.  The Intelligentsia is great, I love having the option of getting really good coffee before heading out for the day.  The location is also great, close to trains to midtown and Tribeca, easily walkable to Meatpacking, West Village, Soho, etc, and a block to the High Line.  It was a bit chilly to take advantage of the outdoor seating space, but I would definitely come back in warmer weather just for that option.  It's really just a very unique experience, and we enjoyed it.

title: Good potential, but still working out the kinks
text:
This is a challenging hotel to rate on a 1-5 scale. There are some elements that hold great potential, and others that seem curious or even odd. We did enjoy our stay, and you have to give them credit for trying something new. Ultimately though, it feels more like a guest-house than a hotel. The services and amenities you might expect at this price point, are notably absent.  

Although previous reviews seem to indicate a discounted "soft-opening" back in July and August, there is still on-going work on the front and back courtyards. The whole endeavor still feels like a work-in-progress. Despite that, prices have risen into the same lofty realm as the Standard (a much more polished full-service hotel - also on the High Line).  

The best feature is the location – across the street from a High Line entrance. Our suite (#3) was quite large with two closets, a desk and a sitting area. The bed was supremely comfortable and the bathroom was well-appointed. Our room was very quiet due to its view of the lovely, but incomplete, back courtyard.

It's a unique concept, and a unique aesthetic. An 1800s Seminary building has been remodeled to feel like a cross between the prohibition-era vibe you're seeing all-over and someone's 1050s college apartment building. It shows admirable restraint that there aren't faux-vintage filament light bulbs everywhere. The furniture has a quirky mis-matched thrift-store feel to it, but on closer inspection, it's much too pristine to actually be vintage. The black floors, fireplace and grey mouldings are a nice touch, but I assume that our room's Home Depot exposed-bulb ceiling fixtures were just temporary. It truly is a mixed bag.

Would I recommend this property? I guess I'd give it a qualified "not yet"...at least not at this full-fare price. If you can wait until they finish the decor and grounds, this might be a good change of pace.

title: Great stay, great staff
text:
I stayed with my girlfriend in September on a trip where I was about to propose. Thanks to the wonderful front desk staff I was able to get a great room and check in a bit early. The hotel still seems to be in the opening stages as they still don't have breakfast, room service or newspapers but the front desk manager (I think his name was Andre) was very helpful. I told him we had just gotten engaged and we wanted breakfast in bed the next morning and we wanted a paper to commemorate the occasion and he took care of it! 

When we returned at the end of the day the New York Times was waiting for us in our room and I had an email with a menu for breakfast. He had let the next days manager, Joe, know about our breakfast and he was at our door right on time. It was perfect! Everyone was so nice, from the housekeepers to the bellman. My girlfriend and I had an amazing stay and would love to come back on our next visit. 

Our room was spacious and the bed was AMAZING. There was a bit of noise from construction across the street but we were always up early to enjoy the day. The neighborhood is convenient and close to many restaurants and art galleries. It

title: Pet Owners - Think before you book
text:
This hotel has some great qualities.  Our stay was soured by three important factors: hospitality, a continuous and unsolved temperature problem in our room, and smoking on a non-smoking floor. Our daughter has lived in the city for 3+ years and we have stayed in many NYC hotels; manhattan to brooklyn.  My husband and I travel consistently and regularly for business and feel very strongly about choosing hotels based on the quality of the hospitality and not just amenities.  It's simply such a crucial part to an enjoyable stay.  This past weekend we chose the Highline Hotel because of it's proximity to the West Village and that we wanted to bring our small dog with us for the weekend before traveling upstate, and the hotel is prominently advertised as a dog-friendly hotel, something we researched throughly.  On the surface, it seemed to be an important part of their business plan to cater to pet owners and to make human and canine guest alike feel at home.  The daily front desk and lobby staff is wonderful, incredibly warm and accommodating, and when I asked at check-in if I could take my dog outside to the gravel yard to walk her, I was told this was no problem.  She is a suburban dog who isn't familiar with a lot of concrete and throughout the next 2 days whenever she needed to go out to relieve herself I walked her in the front yard of the hotel and spoke to hotel staff and guests who never expressed a single comment about her being in the bushes outside.  On our last evening after dark, my daughters and I walked the dog outside on our way to dinner and noticed a large crowd in the lobby, coach buses out front and what was clearly a large amount of security and staff managing an important event that was taking place at the hotel.
