When I took the dog outside and proceeded to walk her in the yard as I had consistently for 2 days prior, I was approached suddenly by not one but two aggressive staff members who announced that I wasn't allowed to walk my dog in front of the hotel, but I was welcome to on the city sidewalk outside the gates.  When I explained that they were prominently a dog-friendly hotel and that I had specifically asked and been told that this was an appropriate place to walk her, I was met with blank stares and sharp responses that it mattered because the general manager was present and insisted upon it.  I understand that NYC hotels walk the thin line of being both hotels and local event space, but the good ones manage to do both with the utmost hospitality. Even if the message that I couldn't walk my dog there for that evening was a fair one, the way that it was expressed was hostile and entirely unacceptable.  As a responsible pet owner I asked the questions I was supposed to ask before walking my dog, and was later admonished by a mismanaged hotel because they had an event that required that they keep up appearances.  I will never be comfortable in a hotel that puts its local event business over its guests, and in a city like New York with the best of the best at your fingertips, why should anyone settle for less than simple hospitality?

It's worth nothing that this issue occurred after the heat in my room (in mid October in 60-50 degree weather) would not turn off all night leaving us drenched in sweat all 3 nights, an issue which we repeatedly mentioned and was told could not be helped because of the way that the heating in the building functions.  Fair enough, not every problem can be fixed with miracles but there was absolutely no gesture of compensation or any response other than "....well... sorry!"  I let it go because what could I do, until the incident with the dog and the night we spent with a constant smell of smoke on a non-smoking floor. As a brand new hotel, The Highline would do well to get it's management in order and train on both consistency and a standard of guest service.  It's the largest and most well-equipped room I've stayed at in the city, but I left with a regrettably bad taste in my mouth and won't stay here again.

title: Wonderful, memorable stay. Great service
text: This was the best experience I've every had in New York. The hotel was wonderful, quiet, quaint, charming. The neighborhood had amazing food and lovely art exhibits. Service was outstanding. Michael and Fazhl were the best and made sure that I had everything I needed. I left my coat in my room after I checked out, and the minute I returned they had it waiting for me. So friendly, and wonderful. Also, the coffee and the people watching were fabulous. I would definitely stay here again.

title: Must they really be so friendly!
text: I feel mean writing it but I am British and I value privacy and even anonymity when staying in hotels. So to have such friendly attention is too much for me. I don't need someone to take my case the 5m to my room. I've stayed in hotels before and I can usually work out which room is the bathroom. A minibar is not a shock to me. As I come and go, I prefer to just walk in without discussing my day. Seriously, the set up leaves reception staff standing around in the tiny lobby without a desk so they are forced to interact. Room was huge and bed very high and comfortable. Fascinating building and great location. My moan is more about the States than this particular hotel, so don't take it too seriously.

title: My cup of tea
text: I adored my little room, with the gable window and armoire (instead of a closet). However, since it was a bit quirky, I could see how this hotel would not be the right fit for everyone. I found the layout and vibe charming, like a boutique hotel in a European city. But if you're the type of traveler who's happier at a Sheraton Four Points, this is not the spot for you. The bed was very comfy, and the bathroom was well-lit and roomy, with a good shower and very nice towels (that's important!). Yes, they are super hip, but the staff was very friendly -- not too cool for school. The Intelligentsia coffee from both the inside coffee bar & outside coffee truck (in the lovely front garden), was terrific. As someone who frequently stays overnight in the city for work, I can see this becoming my go-to crash pad.

title: awful..not a hotel but a coffee shop with rooms
text:
The Developers missed a great opportunity to develop a special hotel. The building which houses the hotel is awesome. That pretty much where it stops. It was previously a seminary and feels very much like it still is. The bed is the only other thing worth mentioning, it is comfortable. The batrooms are minute, and I do not accept a shower curtain in a highly priced hotel!!!
The staff can be friendly at times. The General Manager is too occupied showing people around and does not interact with guests. 
One of the most annoying things was the perpetual construction, Saturdays and Sundays included from 08h00 in the morning. Not even an apology.
The next most irritating was the accounts, they overcharged and 2 weeks later are still posting amounts of $2.85 on my card. Ask for a bill and the printer does not work, do you think there would be an offer to email it. Out of the question.
The coffee at the coffee shop is good. But there is no other service in a hotel where it does not come cheaply.
Quite honestly, how travel & Leisure featured this hotel in the latest edition astounds me, certainly does not give this publication any credibility.
I would not aty here with the current price tag!!!

title: This is a horrible hotel
text: This is, simply put, a terrible hotel -- run by hipster clowns with no sense of how a real hotel should actually operate. It is very high concept: a former Episcopal seminary turned into a boutique hotel. But the execution is incredibly shoddy, especially for a place that charges such high fees. The rooms -- former dorm rooms -- still feel like... dorm rooms, despite the addition of fancy bath products. New features like motion-controlled water taps, don't help. (Try filling up a water glass using one of those. And don't look for a temperature control; there isn't on.) The rooms are also noisy and poorly laid out. And the night we checked in our room was so hot that we couldn't stay. The staff explained that this was because their climate control was "geothermic." It quickly became clear that the staff don't know what "geothermic" means. In this case, what they were trying to convey was that the heating and cooling were all done using an ancient water-based system. What this meant in practice was that the temperature controls in the room were completely cosmetic -- they did nothing to raise or lower the heat, and nor was there anything the staff could do to help. We tried another room or two, then packed our bags and left.

title: Fab location, funky feel
text:
Wood floors, non-generic furniture and a top-notch coffee and tea spot in the lobby.  Some things are a little uneven (I was there in the first couple months of operation).  Check in feels a little odd, though I approve of not taking up lobby space with a big check in desk. There is a paucity of hooks in bathroom for towels, robes, PJs.
The courtyard behind the hotel is lovely, and of course you are just across the street from a Highline entrance - perfect for a walk or jog.  I had to ask for extra housekeeping and the staff was very responsive.  Cool spot!

title: Wonderful Place in the Heart of NYC
text: We enjoyed our three night stay at The High Line Hotel. The rooms were large and the beds were very comfy. The staff was very sweet and welcoming. We also loved the Coffee bar in the Lobby. We look forward to our next visit in december. This hotel is pet friendly also ;)

title: Amazing bedding; oddly nonfunctional bathroom
text:
We stayed at the High Line Hotel for my husband's 50th birthday.  The room was lovely, with a European feel, but with a strange couch / love seat that was amazingly awkward to sit on.  The room needs more hanging closet space. The lack of even a single towel rack made the tiny bathroom nonfunctional.  For comparisons, we booked a Deluxe King room (purported to be larger)

The bed and bedding was top notch, and we slept better than we do at home.  The mini bar was well stocked with beverages but limited food choices. The pricing for the mini bar was very fair by NY standards. Free Wifi is wonderful.  The staff noted my husband's birthday and greeted him with a happy birthday.  A small token was waiting in our room as well.  We both found this to be charming and unique.

Overall, it was a wonderful experience.

title: Let someone use my room after I had checked in!
text:
Had a crazy experience here. I checked in, unpacked most of my stuff, and went out for a few hours. I came back and the room door was open. Surprised, I go in, and find a used towel on my bed, coffee container on my nightstand, etc. I immediately go to the front desk, and they say, "oh, We didn't realize someone was using that room so we let someone use it for a bit. We'll get you another one." ... They were nice enough, but no one seemed surprised in the least. Bizarre bizarre experience. 

In other news, the rooms themselves are actually quite cool. Similar style/feel as the Bowery hotel, but newer.

title: Such a shame it is so noisy!!
text:
We have stayed there for a week and honestly the hotel itself has full potential to be a hot spot! It's front yard is great for coffees and its bar is full of fashionable hip crowds! No food is served but the pastries are very nice. Rooms are comfortable and the beds are extra super soft - if you like sleeping on feathers!!! 
The location is very convenient with lots of zagat highly ranked places in the area. But...the main issue here is the noise! For a week I didn't get a days sleep!!! It's not not the location though, it's the building itself. We asked to be moved the first night and the staff happily did give us a new room but still chaos!! It is such a shame as the hotel is very recently renovated and it is obvious that no attention was paid to noise insulation. We were staying on the second floor and I could hear what people downstairs were talking about. 

I don't know if I would go again or recommend it to anyone. If they could guarantee a quiet room then I would have no second thoughts.

title: Some Bumps but Pleased Overall
text: This is a great location if you want to explore Chelsea and the High-Line. The interior rooms face a nice courtyard although there is construction on one side for new condos. It's a beautiful historic property and the rooms are nicely appointed and seem generally clean, though a few spots needed some more attention. The main problem was check-in. When I made the reservation I asked for a room on an upper floor away from the elevators facing the courtyard. So what did I get?  A room on the second floor right near the coffee bar and the elevator, plus facing the street. I could hear every clink of every spoon stirring a latte at the coffee bar. The staff was very accommodating when we asked to move and put us in a higher room facing the courtyard. Much improved.

title: Not worth the $
text: Stayed here for two nights and booked my room through Jetsetter and received a promotional rate of $229/night for a Deluxe King.   I was given a room on the ground floor, almost directly across from the Intelligentsia Coffee bar and just steps from the front desk.  Initially, I was worried about the street noise, as my windows were right on 10th Avenue.  Street noise was not the problem, but the noise from the coffee bar and the front desk staff was quite annoying.  At midnight, the front desk staff were laughing and yukking it up and I could hear every bit of it.  The lobby is tiled with no textiles to absorb the sound - terrible.  In addition, the young boy who showed me to my room clearly was uncomfortable and had a difficult time explaining the room features.  The room itself was quite pretty and the bed was very comfy.  Unfortunately, there is no clothing storage space to speak of.  The closet rod was about 8 inches long and with 2 hotel robes already hanging there, there wasn't room for anything else.  There are also no hooks in the bathroom for robes, etc.  Phone didn't work, had  no hot water before 8am.  I understand that they are still working things out and if you can get the $229 Jetsetter rate, then I would stay there.  Unfortunately the current room rate is well over $500 and the hotel is just not worth that.

title: Hard work for a soft opening
text:
During its first days of operation challenges, this hotel staff met the mark. After a long and difficult trip to NYC, we arrived early and were immediately shown to a room which was larger than the one we'd booked. The decor is interesting, dark and restful, reflecting the origins of the building.
It is a little disconcerting to arrive at a hotel with no reception however, the staff was attentive and thoughtful, and we were shown to our room within minutes of our arrival. The room itself was spacious and comfortable, if you admire the charm of an old residence. There were quirky selections of furnishings as well as luxurious linens to enjoy.
The location is perfect for a visit to the high line, as well as to shops and galleries in Chelsea. A visit to this hotel is more like a quick trip to Europe with all of the sensibilities of a bygone era.
